body: SIG: DAM: Data and Analysis Management

comments.body: People are still trickling in from the train, and so we'll be starting in 5 minutes...
Given the lines at registration there'll be plenty of late arrivals. About 60 participants in the room so far.
Taverna is free in the way that puppies are free. Everyone got that?
Carole Goble gives an introduction of Taverna. Now at 3000 public service operations; lists user and institute counts but not sure about the growth of the user base
Rewritten the workflow execution engine. Re-design of the interface.. but can't make out how the available services are organized which has always been my main problem with the system.
I quite like the rewriting of Taverna's provenance format to comply with an open provenance model.
Not heard of open provenance model -- good idea, thought, glad it's happening
[BioCatalogue](http://www.biocatalogue.org/) provides a curated repository of life science webservices. Didn't know about that one yet.
@Phil - yeah, not sure which one specifically they're referring to - there is a hit or three on Google though..
62% of respondents in the Elixir questionnaire didn't use any sort of minimal information guidelines. Wow!
Blog post available: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...
Next up: InterMine, an open source data warehouse: Gos Micklem, Cambridge University
This is going to get crowded. Might make sense to break things up by session or talk, one thread for each?

@Oliver I agree! Don't know - don't really want to start another thread - they do a one-per-speaker for the main talks during the week, but not for the SIGs. Perhaps we should just start a new thread for each speaker? That's what I would suggest... We can then link to each thread inside this thread...
Sounds good. Michael is using that approach over in BioPathways.
Go to http://ff.im/4uShd for the thread for Gos Micklem's talk
Go to http://ff.im/4uX7e for the thread for Christopher Lee's talk on Pygr and Worldbase
Go to http://ff.im/4uZVS for the thread for Jill Mesirov's talk on GenePattern
Session 1 notes at http://www.fiamh.info/article.... Nowhere near as extensive as Allyson's, of course ;-)
Go to http://ff.im/4v2Wm for the thread for Eileen Kramer, and putting semantic web services into Galaxy
@Oliver - I beg to differ - they look quite thorough to me!
Go to http://ff.im/4vb2l for the thread for Carol Lushbough's talk on the BioExtract Server
Go to http://ff.im/4vigi for the thread for Kathy Wolstencroft's talk on SysMO
Go to http://ff.im/4vcW5 for the thread for Philippe Rocca-Serra's talk on ISA-Everything (aka storing experimental metadata) :)
Go to http://ff.im/4vfm9 for the thread for Christoph Best's talk about electron microscopy data bank
Notes for Session 2 at http://www.fiamh.info/article...
Go to http://ff.im/4vnGO for the thread for Morris Swertz's talk on MOLGENIS
Go to http://ff.im/4vq84 for the thread for Robert Murphy's talk on PSLID
Go to http://ff.im/4vsfK for the thread for Mark Welsh's talk on BioHDF

Thanks so much for the incredible coverage everyone
Thanks for the organization ;-)
thanks all around, agreed! :)

body: FFers open thread

comments.body: I'm here and will be attending the BioPathways SIG.  I figured there should be some place to say non-talk-specific things like "I've arrived!", so here it is.
Will be switching between DAM, BOSC and the BioPathways. Once I've figured out which talk is when ;)
Uhoh. I sense a lack of places to recharge notebooks. This is going to be fun during the session breaks..
I forsee a problem with the SIG posts in FF - only one heading, and many, many speakers.... Hopefully will be OK for people following.
The projectionist kindly suggested I power up in the projection cubicle during the coffee break.
Network is slowing down to a crawl for me.
Sitting at home, following the conference. Great job folks! My only wish is that there was some place where the speakers would upload their presentations.
Help! Anyone got a UK plug adaptor with them I could borrow for an hour or so? Will happily exchange laptop charge for beer/coffee.

Oliver, I've been having that problem too.  There were some times when I had posted a comment and wanted to post another one, but the first hadn't finished posting, so I had to wait for the post to finish, hold my comment in my head, and also pay attention to what the speaker was currently saying...
Talked to the organizers. They are aware of the problem, IT is looking into increasing bandwidth. Yay.
@Oliver well done! Perhaps we could ask someone to look into more power extension leads? :)
Anyone up for a FF lunch / dinner / drink at some point during ISMB?
Sounds good.  I'm about to go orienteering, though, so will be out of reach this evening...

Monday and Tuesday are the only "free" nights, with poster sessions going from 5:45 to 8:30 pm. Shall we just set Monday night for the FF meet-up? When would people want to leave the conference at the earliest? 8 pm?

Monday's going to be busy meeting everyone; I'd probably try and stick around 'till 8pm. Meet at the registration booth close to the entrance at 8:15? Can decide on a venue depending on our numbers and whether people are willing to travel to the city center.

I think I would prefer 8:40.  I have a poster.  I haven't figured out yet whether it's Monday or Tuesday, but others might have posters too?  Last year, at least, I was explaining my poster to people pretty much constantly until the poster session closed.
Monday or Tuesday is good for me - either way, and any time is fine. It's a good idea!
8:45 on Monday then, same place (registration area)? Do we have any locals with suggestions?
ok - see you all in registration at 8:45 monday :)
If everyone has already seen Gamla Stan by that time, we could go to Södermalm--plenty of good restaurants.  I'm staying there.
@Ruchira: works for me as long as we have a guide to get us there :)
@Allyson There are lots of power extensions along the windows just inside the T hall. Let me know if those are still too full and I'll see what I can do about getting more.
@Oliver The conference organizers have bought high-speed internet. Anyone can go to the registration desk for a free login. Spread the word!
@Dave, yep, got mine this morning. World of a difference.
@Dave, any chance of getting extension cords to the other conference rooms? Starved for outlets at K21 :)
I'll be arriving today, would it be worth to pack a extension cords with multiple sockets?
@Roland: This is always a good idea. Problem is that some rooms only have power on the stage and in the projection booth.
Organizers also have extra extension cords for emergencies, but even the main conference room has no outlets. Best to recharge during the breaks, but that means leaving the notebook unattended...
photos from ISMB/ECCB, please put on flickr under tag "ismbeccb2009"

The projectionist here just unplugged my power cord from their outlet and said none of us will be allowed to use their outlet; we'll need to use the outlets in Hall C.  He said the organizers did not pay for extra outlets, so we will still have this power problem.
Well, at least I'll be able to sit closer to the front where I can see better.
Even the "free" network is considerably faster and more responsive today. Well… we'll see what happens when the first coffee break hits.
@Ruchira: Ouch. That's not going to help. We can get extension cords and use them in the smaller meeting rooms though.
@Johann agreed - I also think the network is faster today
I love the fierce, ofttimes violent competition for the limited resource that is power outlets during coffee break!
It seems a simple #ismb is the twitter hashtag of choice. Also note Burkhard's suggestion above to use "ismbeccb2009" as Flickr tag. (Hey! Flickr tags can has spaces! ;)
@Johann: Bring your own socket multiplier and you are loved by everyone ;-)
Any chance of leaving / recharging our desktops at the registration desk during the breaks? Would rather not leave mine in a conference room unattended.
Lonely FFer near the registration desk is looking for some chatting... anyone?
Sure, I'll wander by momentarily.
I'm sitting on the ground in front of the registration desk, waering a black t-shirt...
Any poster presenters here on FriendFeed? Maybe you can start a new post in the ISMB/ECCB room and attach your poster PDF?
Great idea, Egon! Not being at the conference, I would very much appreciate being able to see some of the posters on FF.
Lars, are you in Stockholm?
What about special sessions, I do not see them here.
I'm having a special FF sessions outside, but I am the only participant :) (after a nice meet up with Ruchira earlier)

@Egon - shame - I was offline for lunch. At least I assume it was lunch you said that. FF doesn't put up the time each comment was made - so add times please if you're talking about meetups! Hopefully see most of you this evening after the poster session anyway :)
P.S. The network seems to have slowed down again. Anyone else notice, or is it just me?
@Dave thanks for the power extension cable - except for the main victoria hall (as we discussed) it's really helped a lot :)
@Allysin, I'm still around... in front of E.A.T. now....
@Egon - ah, but I'm in a talk! :)
@Egon, no I decided not to go this year
@Allyson: As half of the conference is probably sharing the username / password for the closed network I am not surprised it is slowing down :)
Maybe it is because I am happily uploading Jmol 11.7.45 to SourceForge ? :)
@Allyson Glad to help!
@Oliver Hopefully it's that rather than someone downloading Genbank. :) Still plenty of FREE logins for the closed wifi are available at the registration desk for anyone who wants one.
Fun to see how quickly many of us have found a workaround for the 'Oops'... :)

Is there a place for posting jobs/student positions available to ISMB attendees? (i.e. http://tinyurl.com/brinkma...) I'm not at the ISMB this year, so am definitely checking out FF and related resources and thank you all for your posts!
Does anyone know how to 'filter out' all group:ismbeccb2009 messages in my main feed? So that I can just open the ISMB/ECCB 2009 group in a separate window?
Thanks to everyone - organizers, reviewers, presenters, friends, bloggers etc etc etc : I must away, but had loads of fun! :)
@Allyson, safe travels. @all, see you in Boston. Feel free to PM/mail me for tips where to stay, eat or party in the city.
nice meeting you, Allyson, and have a safe trip!
I am leaving too, was nice meeting you all and have a good trip back.
Conference finally closed.

i'm now at the Stockholm airport en route to Cambridge for another conference (!) http://www.functionalgenomics.org.uk/section... It was fun meeting some of you and microblogging together. Hope we'll see each other around at future conferences. Next year in Boston!
@Egon: if you go to the ismbeccb09 room and click the "(edit)" link to the right of "Lists" then you can deselect it from your Home feed.

A top-ten of talks (well, not really - just the top ten of my ISMB posts based on number of hits). What was everyone interested in enough to click through to my blog? Find out: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...

body: Biopathways SIG: Ron Pinter

comments.body: merge pathways instead of analyzing them separately
"conditional integration" : merge only if appropriate (same cell type etc.)
when merging p/w with common nodes, don't simply merge edges: add additional control edges to preserve original p/w logic
the conditional pathway algebra is commutative, but not associative (!)
PIE - The Pathway Integration Environment: a Cytoscape plugin
Cytoscape now includes hyperedges
applied to 3 well studied, highly curated yeast signaling pathways: filamentous growth, pheromone signaling, high osmolarity glycerol (HOG)
original filamentous growth pathway in STKE (signal transduction knowledge environment) includes a node that shouldn't be there
conditionally combined filamentous growth & pheromone signaling
finally conditionally combined all three
will improve UI and apply to PGx project: multiple sclerosis and psoriasis (human multifactorial diseases)
Alexandra Skolozub's homepage: http://www.cs.technion.ac.il/~sashul... (MSc thesis on this)
The plugin requires at least Cytoscape 2.6, which added the hyperedges, and will be among the Cytoscape 3.0 plugins
This will be published at the conference CSB 2009 http://csb2009.org/

body: SIG: DAM: Data and Analysis Management: InterMine, an open source data warehouse: Gos Micklem, Cambridge University

comments.body: I'm a fan of Model-Driven Architecture, too
Like their query builder to generate templates. Unclear how you find the appropriate template though.
http://www.flymine.org/ as an example if anyone wants to explore the capabilities.
Believes it's very important to annotate their data model. Nice :) (Though they haven't done it yet!)

Looks like a mature project. Only aspect I am unclear about is how they pull in the data from other sources (and how much maintenance is needed to keep that aspect running). @Allyson: agree! And given their focus on ontologies I'd hope they use a standard description to annotate their models.
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...
@Oliver - most definitely - a suitable ontology or ontologies (they mentioned the Sequence Ontology in the talk?) would be a great idea for annotating the data model.

body: BioPathways SIG: Nicolas Le Novére "The Systems Biology Graphical Notation"

comments.body: supposedly biologist-friendly pathway maps are completely unintelligible
by contrast, electric circuit diagrams, even very complex ones, can be understood by high school students
Systems Biology Graphical Notation http://sbgn.org a limited number of well-defined symbols for biochemical and cellular events
3 languages: process diagrams, entity relationships, and activity flow
Thanks for updating us - I'm reading with interest from the DAM SIG room in between talks!
process diagrams: biochemistry; entity relationships: molecular biology; activity flow: physiology/genetics
we're "projecting" the biological process onto different dimensions (the different languages)
process diagrams: entity pool nodes (things that can be counted): containers, and process nodes: pipes
also connecting arcs, which connect the various nodes w/ logical operators
syntactic rules define what can connect with what, and diagram rules show how to render well-formed expressions
can contract large diagrams into small ones
color is strictly insignificant, so can photocopy diagrams
entity relationships can be viewed as rules
a process diagram representation of the same process would result in combinatorial explosion; the rule expresses this much more compactly
activity flow never represents molecules, only the activities of those molecules
have also annotations (not strictly part of SBGN), e.g., GO annotations
SBGN is supported by many tools
new version is about to be released
have upcoming fora and hackathons
it is compatible with BioPAX
SBGN is more concerned about the graphic representation, so you can import BioPax pathways and visualize them with SBGN
Science Daily summary of the August 8 Nature Biotechnology article: http://www.sciencedaily.com/release... reshared from Jenny Morman http://ff.im/6uWIo

body: SIG: DAM: Data and Analysis Management: Exploring the future of bioinformatics data sharing and mining with Pygr and Worldbase, Christopher Lee, UCLA

comments.body: graph databases as knowledge maps - mapping how knowledge interconnects
Seems to scale well (multiple alignments as graphs) should be able to handle vertebrate genome alignments (ie, storing genomes as graphs with CNVs, Indels etc)

They would like to make obtaining a specific dataset as easy as a Python import foo.bar.you. To work with the dataset, all you need to know is its name. With the name and the import system, you don't need to know how the data has gotten there - you just have access to it. Globally unique identifiers, anyone? Sounds familiar... :)

Which means you have to link yet another identifier space to everything else. Sigh :) Looks powerful to store all project-related information in a single namespace though; uses PyGr to store the worldbase schema (relationships, dependencies etc)
@Oliver that's what I was thinking - yet another identifier space...
don't write scripts: write Make rules (and let the system find the right path for you). Where Make rules (here) == graph queries

Carole's observation: you've just described the Semantic Web (RDF triples etc).This graph model is like an RDF model. You've got the equivalent of SPARQL etc. Christopher: this is a client environment. Summary: more talk later this week required..!
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...
Absolutely agree with Carole: there's tons of stuff being replicated here (RDF, namespaces etc). An interface / standards compliant implementation would be wonderful though.

body: BioPathways SIG: Satoru Miyano, "Cell Illustrator Online"

comments.body: The Tale of the Heike: "The proud will surely be destroyed" illustrated by a picture
_The Biology of Cancer_ by Robert A. Weinberg http://books.google.com/books...
Picture "The Hallmark of Cancer" from Weinberg's Cell publication is similar to "The Tale of the Heike": English narration required to explain what is represented by the picture
Leloup & Goldbeter, 2003 modelled circadian rhythms in Drosophila with 11 equations, but these are hard for biologists to understand
Systems diagram much easier to understand
Cell Illustrator Online: A Java Web Start application http://www.cellillustrator.com
started in 1999 December with Petri net model
first Petri net for systems biology Reddy et al AAAI, presented at first ISMB
Petri nets invented in 1960
hybrid petri nets invented at the end of 1990's: combination of discrete switches and ODEs (continuous)
prototype hybrid Petri net: the toilet.  Flushing is a discrete action, the water level is continuous.
Cell Illustrator is a drawing tool like Illustrator.  Allows modelling, simulation, and analysis of pathways.
demands of the user skills in: biology, and math at the level of high school; no more complicated than a mobile phone
have place, transition, arc, in Petri net; can render with any picture.  Drag and drop icons.
Annotations to external databases: PubMed, GO, etc.
Select math reaction rule from the reaction library, or write your own script to realize any complicated function.
Includes tools for gene network analysis, e.g., via Bayesian networks.
Hybrid Functional Petri Net with extension (HFPNe): allow functions and any object-oriented data type
Genomic Object Net was a prototype, Cell Illustrator was released in 2003.  Cell Illustrator is now at version 4.0; next version will be released in April and is now in beta.
Can model frameshift in translation of mRNA using object function.
Springer book: _Foundations of Systems Biology: Using Cell Illustrator and Pathway Databases_ Full color, 150 pp., inexpensive. http://www.springer.com/compute...
If you have trouble buying it, please write to Satoru, who will send it to you as a present!
Cell System Markup Language: http://www.csml.org/ (now at version 3.0), native XML format for Cell Illustrator. Also Cell System Ontology 3.0.

CSO uses Web Ontology Language (OWL), enabling semantic validation and providing complete and consistent biological pathway models, in contrast with BioPAX, CellML, and SBML.  They couldn't wait for the completion of the SBML project.
CSML supports logic based descriptions, e.g., temporal logic for Bayesian network causal relationships.  CSML has CSO as a background.
Uses biologically sophisticated, space- and time-efficient pathway layout algorithms, incorporating the ontology information.
Can convert BioPAX, CSML, SBML to CSML, which is richer.
Have TRANSPATH Pathway Library Module (if you have a license for TRANSPATH).  Adds 100,000 unique mRNA and protein icons, so more detailed biological pathways can be modeled more accurately.
Have high performance simulation module; can run 100,000 simulations with slight variations in parameters.
Can export the model into Python, C, C++, Fortran, Java, or Perl, so user can simulate in language of choice.
Have Pathway Patameter Search module.
Ongoing: Model Checking tool, Data Assimilation, Interface of BIOBASE Explain, Release 5.0 with new architecture, Module for SNP Analysis (1.5 years), Module for Protein-Protein Interaction
Data Assimilation: integrate observed data into the model rationally.
EGF Receptor Pathway Dynamic Model: state space model with particle filter for selecting the parameters.
Need supercomputer: one billion particles for short time course.  (This is effective, per their PSB paper.)
Use RIKEN supercomputer available next year.
Apply to personalized medicine.

body: BioPathways SIG: Daniele Merico, "Enrichment Map: A novel visualization method for gene-set enrichment analysis results"

comments.body: Gene Sets, Pathways, and Networks.
Enrichment analaysis is performed on gene sets, e.g., after clustering of gene expression data.
Test over-representation using Fisher's exact test or hypergeometric test.  Or may use alternative null hypotheses.
Gene sets are interrelated by overlap.  Enrichment map plots these relationships as a network.
Applied to breast cancer cell signaling pathways: estrogen 3 receptor.  Found e.g. cluster related to cell proliferation.
Edge thickness represents amount of overlap.
GO hierarchy has three components; enrichment shows different kinds of relationships.
Nodes are colored red for upregulation and blue for downregulation; size indicates number of genes in the geneset.
Apply to disease signatures of genotype-phenotype studies.
Instead of color coding up/down-regulation, might map cluster analysis or principal components analysis results.
Can demote pathways to gene sets and run enrichment maps on them.
Enrichment maps can be used as an entry point for more detailed pathway-level analysis.
Can put in pathways and networks and re-organize using enrichment maps.
Have free Cytoscape plugin. Download from here: http://baderlab.org/Softwar... (website currently under maintenance).
Using too many gene sets may result in clusters that are too dense, making the map hard to navigate.

body: BioPathways SIG: Rainer König, "Analyzing enrichments of differentially regulated metabolic enzymes in neuroblastoma tumors using pathway topology"

comments.body: Want to find differentially regulated pathways, e.g., in cancer, so can specifically target them.
Three cellular networks: signal transduction, gene regulatory network, and functional response, biochemical network.  These feed back / interconnect with each other.
Used neuroblastoma study.  Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial tumor of early childhood (~1 year old).  650 new cases/yr in the US, from neural crest of the sympathetic nervous system.
Take metabolic network data from KEGG, arrange into 2d grid, map microarray data onto network.
Rank by significance using Wilcoxon tests.
Represent maps by bipartite graphs of metabolites and reactions.
Need 2d representation for optimized packing.  This is a linear integer programming problem; solve with CPLEX.
Want to find discriminating patterns.  Use Haar wavelet transforms and rank best discriminating features with significance tests.
Found one carbon pool by folate, and a switch in glutamate metabolism.

body: 3D SIG: Stefano Lise, "Prediction of hot-spot residues at protein-protein interfaces by combining machine learning and energy-based methods"

comments.body: Prediction of protein - protein interaction hot spots without modeling the complex formation or doing tedious alanine scanning
The accuracy of Delta Delta G predictions with this method are comparable to predictions by  Robetta
How does the energy-based methods come into play if there is no modeling of the complex? Do you mean no optimization of the complex ?

They consider basic energy contributions like van der Waals potentials similarly to the energy-based methods, but do not calculate explicit functional form for Delta Delta G. Instead interaction terms are input for the machine learning algorithm. They used alanine mutation data as training examples.

body: BioPathways SIG: Luis de Figueiredo, "Computation of elementary flux modes in Systems Biology"

comments.body: can't predict *new* pathways using KEGG: need to compute
Metabolic system in steady state represented by stoichiometric matrix.  Flux balance equations mean steady states must lie in polyhedrool cone.
State of system, "flux mode", can be decomposed into elementary flux modes (Schuster & Hilletag)
Tools for computing these: METATOOL, CellNetAnalyzer, YANA square
It is thought that these are too computationally complex to apply at genome scale; this is true with current algorithms.
Instead, compute K-shortest EFMs using integer linear programming.  These K-shortest are also interesting biologically.
integer linear program: decompose reversible reactions into irreversible ones.
Compute the top mode (shortest), then iteratively add constraints to the ILP to keep computing new modes.
Applied to lysine production at genome scale in E. coli
Proc. of the Vienna Conference on Mathematical Modelling, vol. 2 of ARGESIM Reports, and forthcoming in Bioinformatics.
computationally demanding for higher fluxes, and can only explore small fraction of the solution space.
possible solutions: use smaller flux values; make the constraint that iteratively eliminates previous solutions more restrictive; and/or block pathways by blocking specific reactions
I'm wondering about the relation of this work with that of my mathematical sister Anne Shiu on chemical reaction networks: http://math.berkeley.edu/~annejl...
to speed up computations, they applied genetic algorithms, which allowed them to take advantage of multi-core architectures (parallelize across the population).
alternatively, can use new processors for sexual reproduction (take two individual solutions from the population and perform crossover/recombination)
got agreement with previous results but 100% faster
would like to be able to predict # of EFMs

body: BioPathways SIG: Peter Gennemark, "Formal representation of the high osmolarity glycerol pathway in yeast"

comments.body: rule-based modeling
osmosis:flow of water to region of lower chemical potential, proportional to difference in chemical potential

Water would flow into cell due to osmosis, but cell counteracts, maintaining hydrostatic pressure.  In response to osmotic shock (addition of salt to medium), cell immediately loses turgor pressure and decreases in volume, but then produces glycerol, causing water to flow back in.  This can be modelled with a combination of biophysics (ODEs describing the flow) and biochemical control.

Introduced r ule-based modeling.  Biologists have accumulated evidence for molecular details of the HOG pathway.  It turns out scaffold proteins (which bind many others) are common.  Due to combinatorial complexity, the ODE representation breaks down.
Therefore use rule-based modeling in a language called Kappa.
Proteins are represented as agents with states and docking sites.
Model available at http://www.cellucidate.com
other tools: BioNetGen http://www.bionetgen.org, Potter's Wheel http://www.potterswheel.de

body: SIG: DAM: Data and Analysis Management: Standards and infrastructure for managing experimental metadata, Philippe Rocca-Serra, EBI

comments.body: I like these standards talks! :)
Love it already. Dentist vist, tax returns and data submission procedures... disclaimer: really fond of the BII system so somewhat biased ;)
Like Oliver, I should also add a disclaimer - I am probably biased as I have worked on many of the common efforts Philippe is describing, so I have a vested interest :)

Even with ISA-creator and other tools I think most experimentalists will still need help (if only a few hours of a dedicated curator) to make sure they identify all relevant fields and terms. Still a large step forward as they identified (imo) the right target audience.
@Oliver - agreed. Isacreator is quite slick looking, though, which should make it easier for non-programmers to use :)
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...

One additional note: the code that validates/loads/convert is structured in a way that should ease the job of mapping ISATAB (or any X-TAB) to object models and vice versa. For instance now I am using it for coding an SRA converter. The approach is drafted here: http://brandizi.webhop.net/mysite....

body: BOSC SIG: Frederik Decouttere, Bioinformatics simplified with seqpad -- http://trac.seqpad.org/

comments.body: Java based visualization tool built on top of BioJava. Active since 2003; released recently as LGPL. High level idea of projects associated with DNA/protein objects; can be loaded from common file formats: GenBank, Fasta, Swissprot... Information persisted as BioSQL database.

Can use for task scheduling. Not a complete workflow but rather useful for custom scripts. Visual representations for features, annotations, multiple alignments, 3D models, phylogenetic trees, BLAST results. Zoom in and get overviews with performance on very large data sets.

body: SIG: DAM: Data and Analysis Management: Grid/cloud data storage and computing for 3D image databases, Christoph Best, EBI

comments.body: wrt the Eelctron Microscopy Databank at the EBI
classification of the images from electron microscopes is very much a process of iteration, averaging and refinement
The resolution has now been pushed up to 4 angstroms.
Sweet. Fitting electron microscopy images to protein backbone models. Structure visualization down to 4A.
Ahhhh - Homer's brain! :)
Software a nice blend of 70s Fortran code with 90s C algorithms. And I thought proteomics had a lack of standards and communities already.
Image guys get all the best slides...
Best describes EMDB as "a bit like Ebay - and you won't make any money, either" :)
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...

body: M3 SIG: Tom Matthews, Pathogen Profiling Pipeline

comments.body: A series of reductive sets.: BLAST to refset --> assign hits --> calculate equivalent hits --> clustered BLAST and filtering
Last Common Ancestor estimation: sounds like the same algorithm as MEGAN
remove host contamination by  BLASTing against the host and removing the 100% hits from those
Looks like a very solid pipeline. No URL given. Tom Matthews is from the national health center of Canada.
The NML (National Microbiology Laboratory) is basically Canada's CDC. They did some great swine flu sequencing work recently. I'm very impressed with this pipeline. Very impressed indeed.

body: SIG: DAM: Data and Analysis Management: SysMO-DB: Sharing and Exchanging Systems Biology Data and Models, Kathy Wolstencroft, University of Manchester

comments.body: Part of Carole Goble's group.

Team needs to retrofit data access and model handling platform given that existing data standard adherence is limited, researchers across 91 institutes use their own data and collaboration environments and are reluctant to share data. Sounds like a nightmare.
Interesting hands-on approach. Probably the only way to make any progress in this environment. Code available at http://code.google.com/p...
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...

Shame I didn't know it's on (was sitting on BOSC next door). Any chance of the slides being made available online? I actually set it up a few weeks ago, would be interesting to know what future plans are.
I'll ask Kathy whether she wants to make the slides available. Sounds like they are looking into closer ties with the ISA folks which should be great.
That would be great, thanks!
That's a "yes" from Kathy; going to post a link soon-ish.

body: Biopathways SIG: Ian Donaldson: iRefIndex

comments.body: different sequence dbs are used in different dbs
generate SHA1 keys for sequences of interactors: see which interactions have exact sequence matches
RIG: redundant interaction group / ROG: redundant object group

want to unify interaction dbs, but find problems in dbs: outdated records, wrong taxon. e.g.: find correct substrains taxons. submit feedback to interaction dbs.
out of ~800,000 interactions from the sources, have ~50% redundancy.
data available in PSI-MITAB format (some dbs cannot be freely distributed).
cytoscape plugin: bypartite graph: proteins, complexes (edges denote protein--protein interactions or protein membership in complex).
look how many interactions per paper, see if low-throughput studies also support high-throughput results.
Wodak lab: iRefWeb.
question: why do different dbs get different interactions from the same paper? might be different splice forms.
can find out how common this is?
15'000 PMIDs cited by >1 db, only 10% have identical interactions in the databases. problems: isoforms, complexes, higher eukaryotes.

body: SIG: DAM and BOSC Joint Session: PSLID, the Protein Subcellular Location Image Database: Subcellular location assignments, annotated image collections, image analysis tools, and generative models of protein distributions, Robert Murphy, Carnegie Mellon

comments.body: Every software app he describes in this presentation are available on his website and is open source
Nice, professional bloggers have arrived at BOSC. Source code available from: http://pslid.cbi.cmu.edu/release... and http://murphylab.web.cmu.edu/softwar...

Like the machine learning approach for this. Uses the model as a means to communicate information on distriutions, handles mixtures of distributions. Claims better results / precision than those obtained by human curators.
If you want to do cell simulations, then you can combine models together. Interesting for things like the virtual cell, as you can model the proteins inside the cell with this.
@Brad - you were doing a great job all on your own! :)
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...
Pre-annotated image data sets are also available via http://murphylab.web.cmu.edu/data...
This now leaves me wondering how one goes about storing the locations and trajectories of subcellular structures in a more concise fashion.

@Jim - is there a common format for movement of cells? I've recently done some work on the Cell Behavior Ontology (http://cbo.compucell3d.org/index...), but don't know if there is an equivalent syntax for it.

@Allyson - no clue - I don't think I've come across one but I bet someone is doing it now. The technology seems to be there to deal with these resolutions - I guess its a cell ontology related issue though, too (there's at least one of those for neurons)

body: SIG: DAM and BOSC Joint Session: BioHDF: Open binary file formats for large-scale data management, Mark Welsh, geospiza.com

comments.body: ...aka Toward Scalable Bioinformatics Infrastructures
@Allyson: Thanks for setting up all those talk threads!
Ouch: "Byte-ing off more than you can chew"!!
HDF5 is a model and file format for large complex data: http://www.hdfgroup.org/HDF5...
@Oliver - no problem - I just check before posting that someone hasn't done it before me :D
Allyson -- seconded. Great work. Nice to have others here. I refuse to comment on that pun-filled slide.

Problem: handling mutiple next-gen sequencing data while still being able to drill down to the original sequence reads. Aim is to generate domain-specific HDF5 extensions to move away from a flat-file format.
@Brad - it's definitely more fun to liveblog in a community of bloggers :)

HDF5 is a fairly complicated API. BioHDF layers a biology oriented interface on top of it, targeted at next generation sequencing especially. Appears to sit on top of one or more HDF databases. Having trouble finding the code itself. Geospiza BioHDF page is here: http://www.geospiza.com/researc...
I wonder when the time is right to start referring to "current-gen sequencing", soon we'll have to start saying "next-next-gen" when talking about single-molecule sequencing.
The BioHDF page seems to be here: http://hdfgroup.com/project... Edit: Nevermind, that link resolves to the HDF front page...
He has a bagful of thumb drives with the HDF software pre-loaded. good idea!
@Andy - very funny :) I know people who, similarly, hate to hear the phrase "post-genomic era"!
Do we get to keep the drives :) ?
Aha, here is the page: http://www.hdfgroup.org/project...
Blog Post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...
plug for piotr's talk in the BIo* update session tomorrow
I'm still confused. Hierarchical data. Random access to the data. Is this not a file system? Why not use a filesystem?
Allyson — thanks for blogging my talk at BOSC / ISMB. And, I'm afraid we're already using the term "next-next-gen" to describe technologies like those of Helicos or Oxford Nanopore.
Ah, the pun-filled slide... in my defense, those were other peoples' puns; however, I'm guilty of propagating them (anything for a laugh in a technology talk).
You can download the current BioHDF prototype software from the "BioHDF Command Line Tools" link here: http://www.hdfgroup.org/project...
The BioHDF slides are available here on slideshare (along with all the other talks from the conference): http://www.slideshare.net/bosc...
There will be a scivee.tv presentation of our ISMB poster also — looks like its not up yet though.

HDF is kind of like a file system within a single binary file. However, those "files" (called datasets in HDF) are multi-dimensional arrays with each element being an arbitrarily complex data structure.
@Mark - thanks for the extra information and comments. It's always good to be able to go back and look over the slides.  :)

comments.body: larger scale, reusable presentation components
We should integrate bioinformatics libraries, db schemas, and web development frameworks (among others).
Sample implementation http://biosqlweb.appspot.com/ using the Google App Engine (http://code.google.com/appengi...)
@Allyson:  I wonder if you have a vested interest there ;)
@Jim - You mean in data integration? Certainly I have a general interest in getting data out there and integrated, but no knowledge of this particular talk or subject before this evening :)
question about plugin components view - is some kind of mozilla approach the way to go - Brads opinion is the organic approach (to get something working) needs to happen before plugins get organised.
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...

experience on using google app engine for bioinformatics apps- both python and java, has lots of additional goodness (Django, etc) - its free and probably underused at the moment - people have to get used to uploading code to appEngine rather than dowloading all components to local server
@Jim - interesting. I've used Google tools before, but not tried the App Engine... Perhaps I should look into it...
@Allyson - gregg Helt created a prototype das2/das1 proxy server on the amazon cloud but I haven't heard anyone else using GAE yet.
Commenting on my own talk. Totally meta. One choice for running App Engine locally: a MongoDB AppEngine connector: http://www.10gen.com/blog...

body: Biopathways SIG: Inkyung Jung: PostNet: Inferring post-translational modification network for multi-target drug development

comments.body:
try to come up with scoring scheme to predict chemical--disease assocations.
look for assocations: drug --> kinase --> kinase substrate --> disease.
1. get kinase--substrate rels from HPRD/OPHID 
2. protein--disease / kinase--disease map from CTD db
3. chemical--protein / chemical--kinase map from STITCH (yay! :) )
4. construct kinase--disease map
develop scoring scheme. get scores for drug--disease assocations; using post-translational/phosphorylation data is better; propose novel indications.
this was a nice talk, although I wonder how this compares to randomized data

body: Biopathways SIG: Teresa Przytycka: Application of combinatorial optimization to predict and study domain-domain interactions

comments.body:
uncover d-d interactions from protein-protein interactions.
non-specific d-d interactions can be detected by maximum likelihood methods.
in the case of specific interactions, one could be tempted to assign interaction to other domains of the protein. not necessarily the case!
hypothesis: interactions evolved in the most parsimonious way. method: find the smallest set of putative d-d interactions that explain all protein-protein interactions.
linear programming approach. have to deal with false positives: sample the network by randomly leaving out edges (choose 50% false positive rate).
estimate p-values: randomize edges. problem: promiscuous domains get bad p-values. thus, add other value: number of interactions for a particular d-d interaction. probabilty: (r = 0.5)^(# of interactions), use minimum of p-value and this value
papers: Guimaraes et al. Genome Bioloy 2006 and BMC Bioinf 2008.
iPFAM is not a good subset of all d-d interactions (as shown by various benchmarks).

body: SIG: Bio-Ontologies: Contributions to the formal ontology of functions and dispositions: An application of non-monotonic reasoning, Robert Hoehndorf et al.

comments.body: the function of my head is to ache in the morning

Larry Wright says that the function of X is Z and this means: X is there because it does Z; Z is a consequence (or result) of X's being there. The heart is there because it pumps blood, and pumping blood is a consequence of the heart being there. But this doesn't work for "the heart makes pumping noises", as the heart isn't there to make pumping noises. Therefore you need some refinements.
although the heart is there because it grew; it don't pump blood when you are dead
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...
What does Larry say "because" means ;-)
@Alan: For him, "because" is a causal relation. So, hearts pump blood (now), and hearts' pumping blood (in the past) causes hearts to exist now.
Does he give conditions for when causation exists?
that be-"cause" is a "caus"al relation doesn't add anything

Larry Wright does not say anything more about causation, he uses it as a primitive relation. Although we seem to have good intuitions about causation, in philosophy, there are probably more theories of causation than there are philosophers. So I agree, this remains a weak point in any definition of function that uses "causation".

body: SIG: Short-Read: VARiD: Variation detection in color-space and letter space, Adrian Dalca, Toronto

comments.body: Two different data types with inherent errors and biases, useful to combine into a single framework. Sequencing errors in color space is a change in one color; a SNP is a change in the underlying sequence resulting in two color changes.
Fully probablistic model. Can handle adjacent SNPs; low false-positive rates.
Looks great for identifying heterozygous SNPs

body: SIG: Bio-Ontologies: Abstracting and Generalising the FMA Ontology, Eleni Mikroyannidi et al.

comments.body: I like this idea - abstract the ontology to make it more manageable, then when required just expand it out again.
Conceptual lego -- it's the way forward!
The FMA shrinks by up to 57% (in the subset they've used). :)
@Phil - I like that imagery!
@Ally not mine, I'm afraid.
@Phil - ah well, it's nice anyway :)
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...
I wonder which version of the ontology is faster for reasoning.
Should be much the same, I would have thought. The smaller one will be quicker to parse in practice!
@Robert good question - @Phil but wouldn't that much of a reduction in that subset of the FMA make a difference to the reasoning as well as the parsing?
The reasoner would have to infer the existence of many more classes with a smaller version of the FMA, so it could go both ways, I guess.

body: SIG: Short-Read: Bayesian mixture models for detection of SNPs in ovarian cancer transcriptomes, Sohrab Shah

comments.body: Workflow for clinically relevant variations: alignment of reads, detection of variants (focus of the talk), confirmation of SNPs and distinction between somatic and germ line changes, annotation of SNP with frequency, functional significance etc
Pprobabilistic graph model with 3 states, obviates the need for depth-based thresholding
Fits model to data using EM
Expanded model takes mapping / base-call qualities into account
16 ovarian cancer transcriptomes from samples with different clinical outcomes. Identified recurring FoxL2 point mutation in granulosa cell tumours, not found in 800 other cancers.
I wish one of my methods would lead to a NEJM paper. Hooray Sohrab!

body: BOSC SIG: Robert Hanmer Software Patterns for Reusable Design

comments.body: if software components arent re-usable, then someone will re-invent it. Handbooks (documentation) really help this.
all design problems are different - yet similar.
poll: half the audience have heard/read? of the gang of four (23 patterns - not all there is!)
patterns are not simply applications of OO principles. They apply to other formalisms
leaky bucket counters - first pattern example
patterns vs algorithms - pattern guides what the best algorithm may be for a particular situation
Patterns are a resolution of forces
nice analogy to the firewall problem barring local data distribution globally
recurring patterns - canonical versus embedded variant of same pattern
poll:more people know what a singleton is than know the gang of four book,
5 common misconceptions about what patterns can do (make experts, generate code, make you rich,eliminate individualism, solve your problem completely)
patterns are the databook for software architects and engineers
Pattern Almanac by Linda Rising : http://www.cix.co.uk/~smallm...
Hillside Group: Pattern Communities - Hillside.net
Jim, you're too fast for me. Hillside community list of patterns is at: http://hillside.net/patterns/
@Brad sorry - I'm happy to stop typing and pay attention!!
Alternative to peer review used in pattern community for improvement of manuscripts: described as a writer's workshop and shepherding: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki...
@Brad this sounds like an excellent process - I'd not heard of it before
Agreed -- really interesting to hear how they do things in the patterns community; enjoying this talk quite a bit.
Can utilize patterns as a guide for refactoring code; some approaches described here: http://sourcemaking.com/refacto...

sounds like it is not necessarily easy to scan all the handbooks to identify what pattern you need - particularly if your crossing disciplines - (e.g. hci centric patterns - but some of these are almost canonical  - how do you identify them?)
@Brad - it'd be nice if ff allowed you to like comments!
BOSC patterns - need a 'pattern keeper' - to shepherd their design

Pattern discussion for bioinformatics this afternoon at BOSC: 4:15 to 4:50. Looking forward to that. Jim, they need to let you like your own discussion as well. Ways to search patterns based on keywords or tags so you can quickly find relevant patterns would be very useful.

body: SIG: Bio-Ontologies: An evolutionary approach to function, Phillip Lord, Newcastle University

comments.body: function has been ontologized heavily already - but what really is it? He has some alternate definitions for both function and role: definitions which are simple, clear, and (critically) applicable.
Alternate BF definition: A biological function is a RE where the homologous structures of individuals of closely related or the same species bear this same biological function.
What distinguishes a biological function from an artifactual function? It is the bearer that distinguishes it, not the process.
The function definition seems quite circular.
Function and Role should be defined subclasses.
@Robert I think Phil has an answer for that - ask him in the question section:)
The definitions seek not to change the current usage but just formalise that usage.
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...
It's also posssible to unwind the definition, but it makes the definition longer; might be easier to take it out if it causes trouble

@Phil: do you take every process that occurs in an entity and in homologous closely related ones as a realization of a function? I.e., my heart makes thumping noises, and so does the heart of every closely related organism. Then, would you say that the heart's function is to make thumping noises?

@Robert there are three answers to that -- the first is to argue that "thumping noises" is not end-directed. This is a fudge though; I don't know how to generate an assay which we can used to test end-directed. The next is to say "yes" but distinguish primary/secondary function where the distinction is "because the biologists care about it". The third was really presented in a talk by Hoehndorf et al. So. it's a problem for my definition, but no more of a problem than the current definition.

body: SIG: Short-Read: ISOLATE to identify the primary origin of cancers, Gerald Quon

comments.body: 5% of all new cases are cancers of unknown primary origin at presentation.
Usual approach includes supervised classification based on select marker genes from known tumours. Works well on differentiated tumours, poorly on secondary tumours from metastatic cancer
ISOLATE is a probabilistic mixture model to identify the site of origin in an unsupervised way and estimate the composition of the tumour and finally identify differentially expressed genes
Cooperative model, does not try to sequentially answer these three questions
Available as a python package, see http://www.cs.toronto.edu/~gerald...
Compares ISOLATE to LDA, KL; ISOLATE tends to match/beat the reference approaches.
Need to look at the paper for details on the algorithm

body: SIG: Short-Read: Pindel, pattern growth approach to detect break points, Kai Ye

comments.body: Pattern growth algorithm for string matching to detect minimal/maximal substrings
focuses on cases where one paired read cannot be mapped; break up the unaligned read into two parts and try to align them independently within a certain range of the anchor

Simulation of deletions on chrX using 20 instances of different deletion sizes, 36bp reads at different coverage. Parameter of expected deletion size, at 10bp recovers 80%, decreases gradually to 100k, 1M bp with high FDR. Can be improved by longer read lengths.
Peaks in a size of deletion vs frequency chart tend to be repeat elements (SINEs, LINEs)
Available at http://www.ebi.ac.uk/~kye...

body: SIG: Short-Read: Next generation algorithms: detection of SNPs, InDels and CNV in massively parallel short-read oligonucleotide ligation sequencing, Fiona Hyland

comments.body: Starts with a general overview of the SOLID system (improved accuracy due to reading each base twice allowing for distinction of errors and variation).
Overview of diBayes, combination of bayesian model and empirical filters.
Comparison to HapMap, full detection of SNPs at 27X, 99% of heterozygotes. Low FDR even at 5X.

Insertions/Deletions, similar method to the previous talk on pattern growth using the mapped read of a paired-end read as an anchor followed by a gapped alignment of the second read within a given window size.
Article at http://genome.cshlp.org/content...

CNVs: Calculating local score in a window size without a paired sample (observed / average vs expected / global coverage). Normalize for mappability (length of the read and the distance of the reads) and GC content are crucial important steps.
HMM with one state for each CN count
Partial overlap with results from McCarroll, higher overlap with the Toronto DB
normalisation for mappability done empirically by sampling sequences from the genome and attempting to map them back.

body: SIG: Bio-Ontologies: Prototyping a Biomedical Ontology Recommender Service, Clement Jonquet et al.

comments.body: It's hard for people to find data - annotating data with ontologies is a solution, but which ontology to use? There are many different formats, platforms, versions. Which is relevant to you? What happens if you get it wrong? The Recommender will help...
The recommender has a nice-looking web interface that has a resulting ontology tag cloud - a good way of displaying the results.
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...
why not just use the union of all ontologies, and then just relate the matched terms across ontologies using some sort of index?  does that index exist?
Judy Blake:  won't you know what ontology to use based on your question?  (good point...)

@Andrew The best place to look right now for a "union" of ontologies is BioPortal, and they have web services. Trish Whetzel is at ISMB, & is the person to ask. Not sure you need to actually unionize the ontologies. *If* I'm interpreting Clement correctly, and I may not be, he is querying multiple ontologies - a query translation method of integration rather than data warehousing, if that analogy holds. If that's the case, then you'd get the same result and it's just a question of which is easiest/quickest
continued... but BioPortal doesn't merge ontologies, just makes lots of them available for people :)

@Andrew re: who would use this? I would use it. I have knowledge, I'm supposed to annotate with ontologies, but I don't know the first thing about what's out there. This will help me very, very much if it works well! :)
I agree, I'm an ontology idiot, but then again, why wouldn't I just use then all ontologies available?  Might not I have terms in my text that cross multiple ontologies?
@Andrew yes, I think that it should return multiple terms from multiple ontologies - maybe I misheard - doesn't it do this?

body: BOSC SIG: Jim Procter, Application of VAMSAS enabled tools for the investigation of protein evolution -- http://www.vamsas.ac.uk/

comments.body: Fundamental goal: integrating graphical interfaces with custom command line programs with custom output. Combines Jalview (http://www.jalview.org/), TOPALi v2 (http://www.topali.org/), AstexViewer (http://www.astex-therapeutics.com/AstexVi...)

Use case: positive selection with PAML (http://abacus.gene.ucl.ac.uk/softwar...). Workflow: get sequences, align, build a tree, model rates of synonymous and non-synonymous mutation, visualize sites under selection.

Overall structure: have a shared XML document. Push data into the document from various applications. Allows synchronization between applications: get shared selection between interfaces; Copy/paste between different programs.
Nice comment from Hilmar, VAMSAS synchronization structure similar to Google Wave: http://wave.google.com/

Interesting algorithm, takes a bit of time to wrap my head around it though. *Seems* intuitive.
Results in improved sensitivity in repeat regions / segmental duplications, claim better resolution compared to depth-of-coverage methods as mappings do not have to be unique.

body: SIG: Bio-Ontologies: Keynote: We-Key, or Professional Wikis?, Barend Mons

comments.body: What is Web 4.0? wwww? Why Would We Wiki?
The key to successful wikis is that we are prepared to share our knowledge
The very important thing is that we recognize authority in a wiki
"We need to recognize authority and reviewed articles in wikis..."  I disagree -- hopefully to be brought up during the panel...

"Authority" and "wiki" does not seem to go together well: wikis are all about freedom and collaboration, and authorities may just prevent this. But it would be nice have something like a web-of-trust in a wiki.
@Andrew - not sure where I stand yet, which would make the panel discussion and talking about the "authority in wikis" very interesting for me
"everybody wants structured data, but nobody likes structred data entry"  agree 100%.  So, who's responsibitly is it to structure data?
@Robert, google wikitrust -- Gene Wiki is planning on working with them...  based on editors' editing history to assign author trust scores and text trust scores
DBpedia bridges the gap between structured data and free-text enties; at least for structured forms as they are used in Wikipedia.
I like structured data entry -- perhaps I am just sad
@Andrew looks at the problems they had with wikipedia when they didn't. Now they do.
@Robert, agreed, dbpedia is a good start, but is all the free-text contributions just lost then?  We need a way to structure that data too.  SMW-like solution?
@Phil, sorry, lost the train.  they=who?  didn't/do=what?
@Andrew they is wikipedia -- no authorities, people start editing their own wikipedia pages

@Andrew, SMW would be a real progress. We had to be careful that we don't scare people off who don't get the extra syntax, and that we won't get scalability problems - at least for wikis in the size of wikipedia, or the size a biology wiki would likely become, this may become a problem. DBpedia can work offline and take as much time as it needs for analysis.
Any hardcore SMW people in the room?  Would love to discuss a bit during a break...
Did I miss something, what is SMW?
sorry, semantic media wiki...  allows you to add semantic context to wikilinks via "properties"
ah okay; also worry about extract syntax of this, but more extra semantics. If everyone has a different interpretation will it advance over normal wiki

@Phil: That's the problem with semantic wikis such as SMW: they store RDF, but they cannot do type-checking, and people may just use different semantics for their relations; on the other hand, if you use reasoning as in the IkeWiki or the BOWiki, you will just get tiny knowledge bases in the wiki...
I'm not worried about type checking -- I mean it everyone uses the semantics differently when applied to the same biology
Barend says you may get "nano-credit" by putting your hypothetical triples in that are later found by labwork
If only "nano-credit" where a unit of assessment at RAE/REF
@Phil - indeed :)

"next generation especially students will be the primary source of triples"  also 100% agree.  Not becuase of the technology/generation gap, but because there are more of them, and because they have more time...
integration between wikiprofessional and omegawiki is very cool -- allows viewing (and presumably querying) triples in the user's native language.
see the triple as a nano-publication with nano-credits - see how innovative you are rather than how many papers you've written

@Duncan - he has talked about it - how wikiprofessional works as opposed to normal wikis, and how CWA differs from SW - have a look at my post once I publish it in a minute - though I may not have got everything :)
@Duncan, not directly.  after lunch panel will be the head-to-head... ;)
@Duncan - ah, I thought you meant discussion of differences, not popularity - or perhaps you mean both?
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...

@Duncan, Barend ended with a good point.  At the end of the day, Wikiproteins is more than just a wiki.  I think Wikipedia / Gene Wiki wins that comparison every time if you only view it as a wiki, but the Wikiproteins idea is a lot more.  In the end, I think the two can and will be synergistic (and this coming from a big WP / Gene Wiki proponent)...

ooof, some tough questions on actual usage of and contributions to WikiProteins...  Barend's answer on what went wrong: requiring structured data entry (100% agree) and commercial backing (unfortunate the this perception is hindering things).
stay tuned for the panel.  Gene Wiki has some hard usage statistics!  ;)

body: SIG: Short-Read: A method for detecting small-scale human microsatellite length-polymorphisms using Solexa/Illumina paired-end sequencing data, Weldon Whitener

comments.body: Bridging reads that are uniquely anchored on either side of a repeat locus; using hanging reads (one paired-end read in the non-unique region). Model assumes normal distribution of reads and an upward bias of bridging reads.
As the number of bridging reads decreases the number of hanging repeats increases.
Test set at 40X, 1106 loci with triple repeats, 90% of reference repeats called correctly.

body: BioPathways SIG: Thomas Pfeiffer, Estimating publication bias for multiple datasets with similar bias

comments.body: problem: published results are not representative of actual results (e.g. more likely to be statistically significant)
problem: small sample size
but: can combine datasets with similar bias
extension of weight functions approach (Hedges, 1995)
publication bias: well-known jump of p-values at 0.05
we would expect the results to be normally distributed, but only one side is positive results, skewing the observed curve of published results
proteus effect: Initial study is strongly positive, second one is strongly negative, further ones less significant
(might be related to http://dx.doi.org/10... )
dataset: case/control studies on the genetic basis of Alzheimer's disease: AlzGene db
have several studies for markers
case/control studies: 2x3 table
have known within-study variance, unknown between-study variance and unknown mean effect size
weight function corrects the skew
have different weight functions for 1st and 2nd publication
weight function for 2nd publication depends on outcome of 1st publication (Proteus effect)

body:
BioPathways SIG: Tomer Shlomi, 
Predicting metabolic biomarkers of human
inborn errors of metabolism

comments.body: study metabolic networks because they contain less errors than other types of networks
hundreds of in-born errors of metabolism (IEM), affecting 1/5000 of babies
there's a scale of methods from kinetic models to topological analysis, in between: constraint-based modeling
known method: predict steady-state flux using stoichiometric matrix
modeling human metabolic network is harder than microbes: can't assume exponential growth, can't control nutrient intake
goal: predict metabolites whose concentration is altered upon mutation
find out which metabolites are processed when the enzymes works / does not work. predict changing concentration of chemicals which aren't taken up / secreted
apply to metab. diseases in OMIM, get 223 metabolites which conc. changes
most disorders have few biomarkers, about half have a distinct pattern of biomarkers
benchmark: text-mining on OMIM data (noisy): get moderate correlation w/ predictions
also manually extract data for amino-acid metablism. enrichment over random: between 6 and 15.8
won't work if there are other metabolic routes. need stoichiometric info and network topology for correct modelling
article: http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/article...

TopHat publication best contribution in the short-seq field in bioinformatics journal during the past year
TopHat - spliced short-read alignment (expands on Bowtie)
Cufflinks - isoform assembly and quantitation
New TopHat version is faster (fully threaded based on Bowtie), semi-canonical intron support, support for micro-exons
Split up reads into 25mers, map independently, look for linear alignments (that might miss some of the fragments). Running time independent of maximum intron size.
Cufflinks to handle ab initio assembly of reads in few, highly probable transcripts.
Cufflinks and UCSC agree for most moderately and highly expressed transcripts (85%) for biological test set, low false positive rate
http://tophat.cbcb.umd.edu/

body: SIG: Bio-Ontologies: Panel Session on the emergence, use and success of wikis for collaborative knowledge capture for biology

comments.body: First question: Wiki's work for general, widely accepted knowledge where there are many readers, few contributors. Does wiki-style crows-sourcing work in science?
Everybody says yes. Judy Blake disagrees.
"Credit is critical, because we need it to survive" -- Robert Stevens
Second question: Wiki's are great for reading, but produce uncomputable free-text. Does the growth of the bio-ontology community not suggest this is the wrong way forward?
"make structured data entry really easy" Barend
"uncomputable free-text" is quite suggestive. I hope some text-miners or NLP-people will disagree.
And I think that the DBpedia people have already disproved that wikis produce uncomputable text.
Andrew Su says that you don't ask your domain experts to structure your data: you value them for what you know, and not for their knowledge of structuring and ontologies.
Anyone feel like submitting grants in RDF?
Yep, if it increases my grant hit rate
@Phil indeed - Robert said another benefit would be that it would reduce the number of people applying for them!
Absolutely.
Helen makes a good point -- the data is getting too big, people have to share. Perhaps the research councils should remove all funding for disc drives
There must be a strong ego incentive
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...

comments.body: Missed the software tiltle: rQuant
Biases introduced by cDNA library construction, sequencing, read mapping; naive read counting not ideal
Normalized positional read coverage along the transcripts based on the relative transcript position (different profiles for different length bins).
Compared rQuant (position-wise method with profiles) to itself without profiles and segment-wise approaches
Additional biases such as the exonic GC content (higher GC content results in higher read coverage)
Software available "soon" at http://www.fml.mpg.de/raetsch...

body: BOSC SIG: Finn Drablos, Computational discovery of composite motifs in DNA -- http://folk.ntnu.no/drablos/

comments.body: De novo binding site prediction: identify set of co-regulated genes, extract likely regulatory regions and look for overrepresented patterns in these regions. 2005 paper summarizing de novo prediction techniques: close to random prediction; too many false negatives.

Approach using discrete models with a motif search tree. Able to efficiently prune the tree to reduce the search space. Output ranked by significance; based on position, sequence and hit probabilities: http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-21...
Benchmarking based on TransCompel database (http://www.gene-regulation.com/pub...), paper here: http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-21...

body: BioPathways SIG: Joanne Luciano, EPOS: Enhanced Pathway Optimal Systems

comments.body: new title of the talk: A naive notion to apply computational methods to medicine: a case study modeling unipolar depression
[shows some slides from her thesis defense in 1995]
cognitive behavioral therapy starts improving depression in around 1 week, drug therapy in around 3 weeks
CBT improves symptoms sequentially, one after the other, whereas drug therapy loops around in which symptoms it is improving and doesn't start until later
used backpropagation to model whether an idnividual would respond; hard to get time series data
problem is that treatment depends on the training of the clinician

suicide is paradoxically one of the side effects of anti-depressants.  knowing in what order symptoms will improve can alleviate this: whether people will still have suicidal thoughts at the point at which they gain the strength to act on them
take home message: different treatments have different order of symptom alleviation
cf. Eytan Ruppin's co-chaired 1995 workshop on Neural Modeling of Depression http://www.cs.tau.ac.il/~ruppin...
this work led her to get involved with pathways, ontologies, and BioPAX
EMPWR project: reasoning over BioPAX brought up issues with it
then she started working on Type 2 Diabetes
usually begins with insulin resistance; many factors incl. age, obesity, family history, etc.
integration of the genomic, proteomic, metabolomic data; work with Mary-Louise Patty NCBC-I2B2

diabetes risk factors result in altered gene expression, leading to insulin resistance and inflammation.  this results in long-term tissue damage, further insulin resistance, beta cell failure, and ultimately type 2 diabetes
study looking at microarray and proteomic data: what causes a cell to go from insulin-sensitive to insulin-resistant
used whole cell models of muscle and adipose tissue; try to use genomic data to predict the proteomic data
both researchers independently found dysfunctions in nuclear-coded mitochondrial genes
finally, last year, after 15 years sold patent to Belgian company last year.  Take home message: 15 years is way too long!

body: SIG: Short-Read: de novo transcriptome assembly with ABySS, Inanc Birol

comments.body: New paradigm in assembly: large number of short and uniform reads
Old approach of overlap/overlay/consensus no longer viable. Alternative in the de Bruijn graph method to characterize the order of the reads with respect to each other in a digraph.
k-mer extension require higher coverage with increased k; with k less than the read length the virtual coverage increases (e.g., 8-mer reads with 5-mer sub-reads)
Assembly branches / false branches / bubbles due to misreads, repeats. Need to be trimmed, remove lesser supported branches in bubbles to come up with a linear assembly
No mis-assemblies of contigs > 100bp for E.coli test case (325X)

Difference in transcript assembly: coverage levels depend on expression levels, split assembly paths can be isoforms, contig sizes vary with product sizes (small!), contig clusters are the expressed genes
ABySS explorer (in review in IEEE Tr Vis and Comp Graphics) to explore contigs.

body: BioPathways SIG: Michael Kuhn: "From protein-chemical interaction networks to human phenotypes"

comments.body: drug-protein interactions may be direct or indirect
may also have interactions with protein families, so don't know about specificity
or drug may interact with complex, not with subunits in isolation
activation/inhibition: additional annotation for higher resolution of drug-protein interactions
STITCH database/webserver: http://stitch.embl.de integrates information now in separate dbs, e.g., ChEBI, KEGG, BindingDB. PubChem does much of the aggregation already.
some dbs do have stereochemistry & isomer info, some don't
import data from SuperTarget, DrugBank, BindingDB; PDSP, KEGG, Reactome, BioCyc; get network
373 genomes, 68000 chemicals in v1; working on 2nd version w/ 630 genomes
11800 human genes, 38000 chemicals, 2100 drugs

Biologists often do screens; some compounds usually have similar activities in high-throughput screens.  Can look at the known interactions in STITCH, predict possible modes of interaction of the other screened compounds.
Drugs screened through in vitro models, animal models, human safety testing, and human efficacy/side effect testing.  Computational biologists can predict side effects before going through all this.
Knowing the drug targets leads to prediction of side effects.

Conversely, they decided to turn this around: look at the side effects and see if can use to predict targets.  Unfortunately, only ~1000 drugs, ~1000 side effects, ~500 targets--not enough data for machine learning.

side-effect similarity between drugs: text mine to find side effects for 746 drugs, weight them, compute side-effect similarity, and benchmark using DrugBank, Matador, PDSP Ki database to assess prediction of probability that drugs share a target
Also look at correlation data; some side effects have similar drug patterns.  Some side effects are related (e.g., nausea and vomiting).  Use weighting not to overestimate importance of correlation.
make network with drugs as nodes and shared targets as edges
found Rabeprazole had similar phenotype as several others known to have GPCR targets, proposed that it did also; similarly for 13 of 20 drug pairs
downloaded side effect data from FDA et al. Parsed, and for some could also get a frequency (e.g., "frequent" or "2.5%"). http://sideeffects.embl.de/
888 drugs, 62269 drug-side effect pairs, frequency info for 32.5% of all pairs, and for 14% of those, placebo information as well
http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi...
highlight medical terms using Reflect, http://reflect.ws See HIghlights Talk by Sean O'Donoghue, Monday 3:45
info about drugs makes human phenotypes accessible
STRING http://string.embl.de/ STITCH http://stitch.embl.de/ SIDER: http://sideeffects.embl.de/ Matador http://matador.embl.de/
currently won't include pharmacogenomics data
would be good to have the data from the actual clinical trials rather than the drug labels

body: SIG: Short-Read: Increasing the coverage of a metapopulation consensus genome by iterative reading and mapping, Bas Dutilh

comments.body: Wild type as the average of the species.
Using a reference genome: 65% of genome covered, lots of gaps after Maq mapping. Only 9% of the reads map at all to the reference genome
Use BlastN for a lower mapping stringency
Assembly as a better representation of the community, so a re-mapping of reads against the assembly should provide a better wild-type representation.
Results in a decrease of zero-coverage positions
Confirm convergence to wild type by contamination with 50% of reads from a different species; hardly any of the contaminants get incorporated during the iterative assembly.
Reference based assembly cannot incorporate large genomic changes. Hybrid approach (de novo assembly, mapping de novo contigs to reference, remap to chimera assembly) might address this.

body: BioPathways SIG: Erik Sonnhammer: Using FunCoup to find novel disease genes

comments.body: FunCoup is a framework/db for predicting functional coupling between proteins using genomics data and orthology
Alexeyenko & Sonnhammer, Genome Research 19:1107, 2009, doi:10.1101/gr.087528.108
want as much coverage as possible
data: protein-protein interactions, co-expression patterns, phylogenetic profiles, domain interaction, shared transcription factor binding, shared miRNA targeting, subcellular localization
use orthology to transfer between organisms
compare incoming data with training sets using bayesian framework
use also curated protein complex data and signalling pathways from KEGG
translate the new information from the input data into a score; if the score is zero, the data is discarded
raw score is correlation coefficient; discretize and split into different bins
have different scores coming from different models, e.g., FC-PI model from protein interaction, FC-CM, FC-ML, and FC-SL
convert log odds score into confidence score
translated networks between human, mouse, rat, ciona, fly, worm, .... the ciona network comes almost purely from orthology
integrate support over species
get a lot from integrating over orthologs
FunCoup is at http://FunCoup.sbc.su.se
can ask for data from multiple species
comparative network analysis of the Alzheimer pathway: dotted lines stand for orthology coupling, solid lines for functional coupling
orthology as predicted by InParanoid
clearly there are a number of orthologs so this is a very well-conserved pathway
for some pathways when you do this you don't find anything
red link means physical interaction, blue link means co-expressed, various others
did similar analysis for Parkinson; here only human and yeast networks
they collapsed groups of nodes, o/w couldn't look at it all at once
found new candidate Parkinson's disease genes
all the data that went into this is uncurated, so may very well find links that no one else has seen before
validation on genes mutated in glioblastoma tumours (The Cancer Genome Atlas)
completely independent test
6 of 9 lists enriched with internal FunCoup connections compared to random networks
next, not yet published work: more systematic screen for disease genes
if have known disease genes, others that are highly connected in the network may also be relevant
Have they verified the functions of orthologuous proteins?
Maxlink screen for novel cancer genes found 1891 candidate novel cancer genes.  See poster A33.
110 of these are linked to > 10 known cancer genes (made sure to leave out network hubs)
got highly connected blob of the network, very enriched with cancer genes
to validate the Maxlink method: 1. Crossvalidation, 2. Gene Ontology annotations, 3. Cancer tissue differential expression in the Human Protein Atlas (see Keynote Thu morning--also from Stockholm!)
5-fold crossvalidation: 45.1% of the removed Q genes were identified (but there was a theoretical maximum of 50%)
validation by GO enrichment in sets of candidates with increased Maxlink score
validated by cancer tissue expression in HPA, using differential expression (co-expression was in the network, but not differential expression)
screen for novel Alzheimer and Parkinson genes; found less novel candidates, 30 and 50
would like to validate these candidate disease genes with collaborators
see http://sonnhammer.sbc.su.se
linked to supporting evidence
if, e.g., protein has 100 links in network, and cancer genes are 10% of the network, require the protein to have more than 10 links to cancer genes; still, may have some network hubs
Ron Pinter thinks J should be like the trace of a program.
the nodes are less important; it's the flow through the edges that is important.  the node may not just be a protein, but e.g., a protein with phosphorylation
PEKE will be released to the public by the end of the summer

body: BioLink SIG: Lynette Hisrchman: Text mining for BioCuration

comments.body: report from 3rd international biocuration convference in berlin, April in Berlin
how can text mining help in the curation workflow?
information cycle for biological databases: ideally experimental data and metadata --> databases, but more often experimtnal data --> literature --> standards/ontologies --> databases

attempted to document biocuration workflows to increase "cross-talk" between curators and textminers; translated to UML; goal to identify bottlenecks and use for training; BUT, found that workflows are complex and different, therefore difficult to identify pain points
many different points of focus: bioentitites, taxonomies, etc; may different types of concepts which groups wanted to capture (chemicals, GO terms, phenotypes, genes, etc.)
bioCreative III-IV: annotation jamboree, assess usability, etc. (use Gene Wiki as a source of text?)
Why is it ideal to put data directly in a database instead of an ontology? An ontology can describe the data a lot better than a database could.

@Robert, good point, I don't think it was her intention to suggest that ontologies aren't useful.  Mostly to stress that the people generating data aren't the ones depositing knowledge in databases.  They publish in literature, necessitating the text mining.  (excuse my poor summarization...)

body: SIG: Short-Read: Design of association studies with pooled next-gen sequencing data, Su Yeon Kim

comments.body: Identify major/minor allele (here: minor for the rarer allele) associated with complex diseases using large-scale genotyping platforms in a large number of case/controls.
Aim to identify rare alleles with a minor allele frequency (MAF) less than 5%
use pooled examples as we only need the MAF across the population to reduce cost
Adds another source of variation (pooling variance) on top of sequencing errors, mapping problems.
Also focused on just capturing exons which exhibits addtional variation (but further reduces cost)

Optimal design using a two-stage design with re-sequencing in the first stage. Only select top SNPs out of the initial sequence data. Developed a likelihood ratio statistics (LRT) taking into account uncertainty in genotypes, the pooled structure and sequencing errors.
Extensive simulation studies with different case/control numbers, pool size and sequencing error rates. Other variables include sequencing depth, pooling and exon variance.
More individuals with lower depth more cost effective than fewer samples at high coverage.
At fixed sample size balance coverage and pool size; high depth at larger pool sizes beats low depth with smaller pools.
