body: BioPathways SIG: Eric Neumann: An Ontology and Knowledgebase for merging pathway information with genomic and text-mined data

comments.body: will eventually release it to the public; Pfizer w/ other companies, e.g., Merck, will make a public version available in the coming months
phrase used a lot in places like Pfizer: Systems Genetics.  Use genetic information in combination with pathway info, clinical info, etc.
want to integrate: current pathway knowledge, genome-trait studies, perturbation studies, and clinical studies with personal genomics (PGx)
got interested with Vincent Schachter, Aviv Regev, et al in starting BioPathways for the purpose of integrating these data
how to annotate knowledge?  need to go beyond canonical pathways
What is meant by "integrate" here? Put together in an RDF-based triple store, or develop a common semantic model to describe the data, and then use OWL reasoning or similar for queries?
in Pfizer, have PEKE (Pfizer Environment for Knowledge Engineering)
all converted to RDF and stored in knowledge bases (knowledge representation)
have reasoning component and visulaization component
stack: web services, Jena, OWL Ontologies, Triple Store
reusable, could use same stack for other things
capture and aggregate facts and knowledge from multiple sources
I would be interested to see how well OWL reasoning performs on this amout of data. With sufficiently complex ontologies, it does not go beyond a few hundred instances, if at all.
allow researchers to review and mine complex relations
more about faceted browsing than querying
faceted browsing: have in sidebar sliceable compact table of terms used in the data
when you click, instantly drills down to that; no SQL query involved
what to do when data doesn't fit the model?
aggregation requires an ontology for organizing concepts and common semantics; e.g., T2DO, ontology for Type 2 diabetes, built bottom up w/in 4-6 months
formalisms also support classification and satisfiability, drive new insights from humans
ontologies are not for coming up with new knowledge, we're 5-10 years away from that; better for doing the bookkeeping to drive insight
system model and biosystem sub-ontologies need to have slots for, e.g., stem cell research, which is very big in Pfizer
take evidence from various sources of data: facts with provenance
disease is a multi-faceted concept
genome wide associations (BPSNP), text-mined knowledge, target genes, pathways
apply statistical models to get GWAs (genome wide associations)
PEKE and its ontology can connect to in-house databases, federating them
now can find all associated traits for any gene involved in pathways? ask questions, e.g., other traits associated w/ Type 2 diabetes traits through genes in common pathways
want the process to be very fluid; don't want getting an answer out to require scientist to ask developer to spend two weeks
visualization tool: Exhibit
this is reminding me a little of Google Squared (which admittedly I haven't played with much)
it looks like a table, but it's easy to rearrange, and it goes several links deep, so can test ideas quickly
scientists really enjoy using this
unfortunately, this system is written in Javascript and can't handle more than 1000 entities; other tools like this are only available commercially

next steps: want to support modeling new interactions from high-throughput perturbation studies.  The Interaction Model (I) as in BioPAX needs to be augmented by the Activity Network State (J), where J is to I as Expression is to Gene.  J can be modeled, but not observed.  It's a projection.

body: SIG: Short-Read Keynote: Edwin Cuppen on biologically relevant advantages and limitations of short read sequencing data

comments.body: What is the biological benefit of going for 10-50 billion reads, bioinformatic challenges aside?
Importance of knowing details of machine and experimental procedures to troubleshoot and identify biases.

Experimental issues: isolate smallRNA fraction in different ways (SREK kit, modban linker, poly(A)-annealing; rat brain, 3 sequencing platforms). Sequencing platform did not matter, but completely different top ten smallRNAs dependent on isolation method.
No strong correlation to Taqman PCR results. Probably with its own biases.
On an equimolar pool of 500 synthetic RNA molecules all methods show four orders of magnitudes variation around the mean...
(ouch?)
Can't count molecules in a sample reliably, but at least can compare across samples as biases are consistent
Not only read length but also fragment length of libraries matters
Rigorous fragmentation before IP in chip-seq selects against large DNA complexes, gentle shearing results in fragments too large for sequencing. Added a post-IP shearing step to address this
Do we want to sequence things we do not understant (yet) from a clinical perspective? Enrichment of regions of interest (exome, GWAS regions) might be useful.
Noticeable coverage difference based on strands
Polymerase errors look like SNPs, cloning biases like quantitative differences
Might need to tweak bioinformatic tools depending on the experimental approach used

body: Keynote: Tomaso Poggio - Computational Neuroscience: Models of the Visual System

comments.body: Not a talk about bioinformatics but computational neuroscience
Learning in supervised and non-supervised settings to understand the processes in the brain.
Just now computational neuroscience can feed back into more classical disciplines.
15 years ago, machine learning techniques were developed for face recognition. Now present in many consumer digital cameras.
Now, detection of pedestrians with Daimler and the future will be detecting people in cars.
No brain research involved so far, only engineering.
Basics on learning theory, the mathematics of learning: Poggio & Smale, 2003
[...] How the ventral stream works.
Build quantitative models, only modeling feed forward connections.
A good place to start because we can quickly recognize e.g. animals in pictures, no time for real feedback[?].
A model of visual representation based on the neuroscience of the cortex, described by Riesenhuber and Poggio in 1999, 2000 and Knoblich, Kreimann and Poggio in 2005
Iterations between tuning and maximization steps in the step wise neuronal graph.
agreement of the hierarchical model was surprising given that it used only data from anatomy and physiology, not psychophysics
adding layers decreases the number of examples needed for a given accuracy
Empirical motivation for hierarchical learning: sensitivity increases by adding more layers.
consider images as functions mapping the square to {0,1}
similarly, function spaces on subpatches
there are multiple embeddings of the subpatches into the larger patch, e.g., from different translations
have finite sets of templates, which can instantiate on different subpatches
now define a kernel based on composing the embedding with the template and taking the dot product
just made this clean mathematical formulation, now there are many open problems
One interesting conjecture: small effective dimensionality at each layer.
extend model to videos: sequences of images
Extensions of the model to videos and sequences of images
computational mechanisms of invariant recognition
system: computer vision of mice in cages
The system based on this model is looking for mice in cages.
classify simple behaviors by watching a couple of seconds of video: grooming, walking, etc.
Patterns like grooming or walking should be quantified.
Collected ~100 hours of videos and then try for an automated analysis
Hand labelling of the videos to train the system.
The automated analysis of 100 hours agrees at 71% with a human labeler. Two human laberlers agree at 72% only.
Two human labelers agree 72% of the times. The system achieves 71%.
Can use markov chains to analyze movement / mouse behaviour
24/7 survey of well-being of mice or other animals possible.
have 4 different strains of mice; can infer the strain from behavior given long enough video
You can infer the mouse strain from the behaviour with about 50% accuracy with 10 mins of video
Behavioral comparisons of mice being model systems for psychiatric diseases.
Vision still remains more than simple categorization: it is image understanding / inference / parsing.

Limits of present FF models: vision is more than categorization or identification: it is image understanding/inference/parsing. Our visual system can "answer" almost any kind of question about an image or video (a Turing test for vision)
want to *understand* the image, not just categorize or identify
Vision is more than categorization, the system would fail a visual Turing test.
vision has to do with general intelligence
blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...

body: HL15: Katrin Huebner - Analyzing risk factor of heart disease by a computational lipidology approach

comments.body: model with 6 lipoprotein components, each one may take part in up to 20 kinetic processes
e.g. synthesis, uptake, exchange with tissue/lipids, ...
simulation of lipoprotein particles, particles have an internal state --> observed kinetic heterogeneity
test if simulation results correspond to clinical data
virtual blood profiles closely match experimental values

hypercholestrolemia: accumulation of cholesterol, especially LDL cholesterol. decrease parameter of LDL receptor to mimick malfunction of the receptor in vivo. simulated lipids follow clinical observations
lipoprotein profile depends on initial composition (e.g. influence by diet)
however, there are some dissimilar initial compositions which result in similar lipid profiles
increase resolution to make sure this is not a sample artifact
look for alterations in the high-density profile, but no difference in the low-resolution profile
? i.e. they can see transient profile changes?
model still needs to be further validated against clinical profiles

body: PT14: Duygu Ucar - Predicting Functionality of Protein-DNA Interactions by Integrating Diverse Evidence

comments.body: background about TFs. ChIPchip, ChIPseq can define binding (but noisy data). Even when we know binding occurs, knowing when binding is functional is less well characterized.
Detecting interaction events between TFs and targets is important, can be observed via chip-chip/seq
Semantics of interactions is important, but difficult to characterize (context dependency of TF binding event)
Binding and gene regulation are context dependent

Estimating TF binding and gene expression response based on three data sets (chip-chip, PSSM and nucleosome occupancy). Binding considered functional if it changes gene expression (determined from microarray data)
combined into a probabilistic bayesian model
Integrated model outperforms individual three data sets in a five-fold cross validation
Used two expression data sets to distinguish putatively functional and non-functional binding events
Data is from yeast. Many TFs. Conditions are Normal Growth and various Stress.
Functional binding rate for a TF was context dependent. They could rank the TFs in order of their impact in different conditions

Considered factors potentially discriminating between functional and non-functional binding. Distance from the start codon, orientation wrt to direction of transcription. Presence of absence of co-factors on the same promoter.

Multi-variate random forest to determine discriminatory factors. Found that this too was context dependent, but that in most cases it was the co-factors that had most impact. Used this data to determine significant TF-TF co-factor interactions.
paper: http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/picrend...
Friendfeed blocked access temporarily. Notes at http://www.fiamh.info/article...

body: HL14: David Pollock - Visualizing Genomic Dark Matter: Repeat Probability Clouds in the Human Genome

comments.body: Distribution of sequence types in the human genome: 1.5% exons; 44% repetitive sequences; 54.5% unknown (dark matter).
RepeatMasker is not performing too well at identifying repeats; it misses ~50% of MIR fragments in the human genome, for example.

The dominant approach to repeat identification is based on the search of consensus sequences for repeat families (e.g. RepBase). Drawbacks: slow; not very sensitive to fragmentary matches; unable to identify novel repeats.
De novo methods: RECON, PILER, RepeatFinder, RepeatScout.
Evolutionary de novo repeat analysis: better detection of imperfect repeats and fragment left over from extensive duplication and divergence.
Consensus based methods reduce multiple sequences to a single one; P-clouds group similar, high-copy L-mers together (16-mers for mammals, E<1 per genome).
Next step: mapping P-clouds onto the genome using a sliding window.
Example: human chromosome X. Time required on a single workstation: 45 min (vs. >10 days for RECON and 8hrs for RepeatScout).
Application to the whole human genome. 38% repetitive (P-clouds and RepeatMasker), 7% (only RM), 27% (PC only), 28% non-repetitive.

body: PT10: Adam Smith - Clustered Alignments of Gene-Expression Time Series Data

comments.body: Usually restricted to discrete measurements of a continues attribute, requires reconstruction or interpolation.

Time warping/alignment to maximize the similarity of the compared point helps. Warpspace diagrams are an alternative way of showing alignment between two time series (think two sequence alignment matrices)
SCOW: efficient method for sparse time series

Known algorithm (1978) for dynamic time warping (DTW), minimize sum of euclidean distances. Parametric time warping (2005, Eilers, PTW) fits alignment function from given family. More limited in expressiveness than DTW

Segment-based warping splits warps into individually scored segments, sits in a happy intermediate between DTW, PTW, but very slow (n^5 complexity). Correlation-optimized warping (COW, Nielsen 1998) looks for good 'knots' (one dimensional). SCOW searches in each dimension independently until convergence.
Evaluation with EDGE toxicology database, SCOW does better than other algorithms (little less so for distorted test data) in identifying the correct matching time series.

Cluster gene time series to get a regularization effect; algorithm based on k-means. Each cluster defined by an alignment, initial clusters calculates by a greedy algorithm, assign genes to cluster, re-calculate alignment for each cluster, iterate until convergence.
Does clustering help? Test with Mop3 knockout (circadian cycle gene); five clusters with exemplar genes identifies genes with a strong phase shift.
Talk notes at http://www.fiamh.info/article...

body: PT08: Abhishek Garg - Modeling Stochasticity and Robustness in Gene Regulatory Networks

comments.body: Looking at stochasticity in nodes and in functions within gene regulartory (GR) networks.
How does the system behave when it is subjected to stochastic behaviour?
uses boolean modeling for this work
Boolean model: each protein can either be present or absent. The interaction network can be encoded with a set of boolean functions exhibiting steady states.
Previous work: some nodes behave stochastically.
With SIN (stochasticity in nodes), they had an example of stochastic cellular differentiation. You understand what the probabilities are in SIN by looking at a population of cells.
Example: stochasticity introduces cellular differentiation into a popolation.
The SIN method overrepresents noise in the system.
This work employs a different approach: stochasticity in functions. The boolean function itself becomes noisy.
Advantage of this approach: the noise can be selected depending on the biological function it applies to.
Measure of robustness: probability of a steady state returning back to itself in the presence of internal pertubations (or faults).
Once you start introducing faults, the robustness is much lower the more faults you add for SIN, but the robustness is only marginally lower using SIF.
In SIN, 3 faults are sufficient to make all the states go into each other (results for the T-cell activation network).
Nice to "see" you here @Gabriele - it's good to have more than one person commenting :)
@Allyson: I think this is getting addictive ;-)

@Gabriele - yes it is - just make sure you control it, and not the other way around! ;) But seriously, if a person is going to take notes anyway, why not take them in a way that 1) other people can see them, and 2) is nicely indexed and searchable ...
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...

body: PT04: Stefan Schulz - Alignment of the UMLS Semantic Network with BioTop Methodology and Assessment

comments.body: ontology alignment - link two ontologies together semantically
Why decide to create BioTop and not use BFO or DOLCE lite directly, I wonder? It's not that I would necessarily suggest that these be used, I am just curious...
The methodology is first to provide DL semantics to the UMLS SN, and second build the bridge between BioTop and UML SN.
Interestingly, semantic relations were reified as classes, NOT represented as OWL object properties.

subsumption hierarchies are assumed to be is_a hierarchies, but is that a safe assumption in UMLS SN? I don't know, as I am not familiar with UMLS SN. For instance, in older versions of GO this would have been a problem (some things marked as subsumption were not in fact is_a, though I am pretty sure GO has fixed all of this now).
There were inconsistent categorizations of UMLS SN objects which exposed hidden ambiguities (e.g. that Hospital was both a building and an organisation).
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...

body: HL03: Eitan Rubin - Whole genome analysis of mtDNA natural evolution in human and in cancer

comments.body: in advance of 1000 genomes, can we use mitochondrial dna sequencing?  advantages: small size (16kb), and maternally inherited (allows human phylogeny)
mitochondria have known role in cancer, but unclear if the mito genome (and mutations therein) are relevant
method: compare tumor and normal mtDNA -- patient-matched.  --> mutational landscape --> eliminate SNPs in normals --> find high recurrence.  BUT, nothing found...
method 2: from mutational landscape, look for co-mutations: two patients with multiple mutations observed
one "flip-flop" observed -- mutation in tumor in one patient and in normal in another -- bi-stability?

compare evolution in normal population as reference; create trees via nieghbor joining, create inner nodes, find deepest branch with mutation; conclusion: cancer uses snps that arise early in human evolution
relates to african vs european haplotypes?
conclusion: mtDNA is under selection in cancer; strategy of finding multiple SNPs in subset of tumors; functional prediction of 25 mtDNA snps
philosophilcal question -- are tumors different species?  unicellular parasites?
A tumor is like a parasite branching off as a separate species from the human
Some cancers have actually become infectious, like a separate species. Eg Tasmanian devil

body: TT02: Janet Thornton - ELIXIR: A sustainable infrastructure for biological information in Europe

comments.body: Planning Project for EU infrastructure for bioinformatics. Goals: Co-ordinated data resources, integration & interoperability of data, links to data in other domains, open access to data, enhance euro competitiveness in bioscience, address need for increased funding and its co-ordination.
Reports from initial committee meetings (userbase consultation) due now - will define the scope & remit of ELIXIR. Then work on international agreement for goals, costs then look at how to fund.
Will provide: core and specialist data resources, compute centres, infrastructure for tools and services integration, support for Bio ESFRI projects, community support and training.
Survey of existing EU database resources. See Poster E41 for details

DB size / number of users / cost etc follow power law - many small dbs, few users, low cost. A few massive ones. Notably, 90% have no funding security beyond 3 years. So - ELIXIR needs to co-ordinate, prioritise and stabilise funding for these resources.
Databases relatively under control compared to other aspects: Standards and ontologies, Literature, Other domains (medical data, biodiversity data etc), Integration
Don't need to centralise standards devel, is fine for them to come out of communities, but do need to encourage and publicise standards. OBO.
Timeline. Dec 2010: end of preparatory phase. Dec 2016: end of construction phase.
Literature: integrated, open access text-based literature resource would be good :)

Compute resources: Modularise organisation of dataresources. Build network of biocomp resources. Catalyst devel of web services and cloud computing. More program to data rather than other way round. Work with EU supercomputing centres.
Questinon: DB developers should have to abide by standards in order to publish / be funded by ELIXIR
Question: is ELIXIR taking into account collaborations with groups outside Europe?
Question: differences between ELIXIR and national nodes

May call for proposals for nodes from EU countries, although no actual funding and no mechanism for deciding which would be accepted yet so proposals a bit hypothetical. Something for people to ponder...
blog notes: http://www.cassj.co.uk/blog...

body: PT02: Warren Kibbe - From Disease Ontology (DO) to Disease-Ontology Lite (DOLite): Statistical Methods to Adapt a General-Purpose Ontology for the Test of Gene-Disease Associations

comments.body: paper: http://bioinformatics.oxfordjournals.org/cgi...
want to simplify the DO to make results more easy to interprete
DOLite is a CV whereas the DO is an ontology.
using two parallel clustering steps and expert curation
DO: ~12,000 terms, DOlite: ~600 terms
FunDO: http://django.nubic.northwestern.edu/fundo...
"FunDO takes a list of genes and finds relevant diseases based on statistical analysis of the Disease Ontology annotation database. "

The same query using a gene list with DO and DOLite gets better clustering with DOLite (where better == more distinct clusters, greater number of clusters in the example we were shown - 2 clusters rather than 1).
future plan: reduce GO (Gene Ontology) in a similar way
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...

body: HL02: Eric Alm - Modeling Ecological and Genetic Diversity in Bacteria

comments.body: So far this is similar to http://ff.im/4x4Vg of the BioPathways SIG yesterday
this lets us study sympatric speciation in the ocean

inspired by Mandel, ..., Ruby, "A single regulatory gene is sufficient to alter bacterial host range": what is the genetic basis for adaptation to the niches we found (zooplankton-associated vs small-particle associated)?
want to do ecologically-driven population genomics
wanted to sequence all genomes in each of the subtrees
asked for 20 genomes in grant application, was met with "?!"
sat next to Eric Lander at a dinner, who said "20 genomes? why not 100?", so got funding from Broad Institute
want to model changes within a population of genomes; gene flow and recombination within the population
wanted to find recombination breakpoints
dimorphic sites, with one nucleotide changing: supports splits, leading to tree with single mutation
however, in one site find a dimorphic site which is *not* consistent with the gene tree(s) consistent with the previous splits, so this must be a double muttation or recombination breakpoints
STARRIinIGHTS uses dynamic programming to find the regions that are consistent with the same phylogenetic tree; what's left is due to either recombination or double mutation

unfortunately, to determine which (recombination or double mutation) would make the algorithm NP-complete.  use single mutations to estimate the rate of double mutations and expected number of trimorphic sites
infer recombination breakpoints between self-consistent chunks
different regions support different groupings
e.g., for the particular ecological split, most of the support for the split is on an 18kb region
this turns out to be an operon responsible for chitin catabolism, which makes sense since zooplankton are covered in chitin
Shapiro, ...., Alm Trends in microbiology paper suggests usual selection tests may not be applicable to prokaryotes
STARRInIGHTS is not up on the web, but will be happy to send it to people to run from the command line

body: HL01: Paul Boutros - The Plurality of Prognostic Gene Signatures for Cancer

comments.body: lung cancer is highly heterogenous in classifications and outcomes -- how to separate those patients that would and would not benefit from chemotherapy after surgery
previous studies based on gene expression analysis have not replicated.  why?  weak statistical methods
method: "modified steepest descent"
first assess genes individually, then take best gene and evaluate best pair, take top pair and screen for top triple, etc.
identified 6 -gene marker set -- stx1a, hif1a, cct3, mafk, rnf5, hla_dpb1
classier in training data, survival difference 1E-5 (not surprising)
8 separate studies: p = 0.02 (409 patients
evaulation: take 10 million random six-gene sets, better than 99.9999% of backgorund, drops to ~90% on other training data, merged 99.98%
but, what are the ~450,000 random sets that are better?  Could this explain non-overlap of previous microarray studies?
evaulate gene based on marker pluraily -- how many good predictors does a gene occur in?
e.g., calca -- not a good predictor on its own, but a part of many prognostic gene sets
top 10: calca, ccr7, stx1a, cct3, sprr1b, selp, pafa... cpe, ...
pathway analysis: reinforces previous network by Jurisica et al.  plurality genes in particular help to reinforce links

body: Keynote: Pierre-Henri Gouyon - Information and Biology

comments.body: intro by Gene Myers: 2 PhDs, 1 Master in Philosophy (after the PhDs)
Dr. Gouyon, PhD in Genetics and Evolution and master in Phylosophy
Biodiversity is at the same time a treasure and a danger
biology is a young science, even compared to physics
What is biodiversity? Long standing question in biology
1605: leaves fall from a tree and become fish / birds
Many good scientists have had problems with society, but it is not sufficient to have problems with society to be a good scientist. :)
not much progress in bio during 17th century
Linnaeus changes everything! http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki...
Biodiversity from Linnaeus' POV: "eternal law of reproduction and nultiplication within the limits of their proper types".
biodiversity, variability between species. Individual variations are unimportant
Cuvier: species go extinct
Lamarck: didn't like Cuvier, proposed idea of transformation, but decided that no species goes extinct
Then came Darwin, and natural selection, mid 19th century
revolution: seeing Nature as set of individuals, not as set of species
Nature is individuals, not species: big conceptual revolution
Birth of biology in 1859
Origin of Species: The *only* figure in the book is of the first phylogenetic tree.
Darwin: no clear demarcation between species, sub-species
Continuation of variation
biodiversity is not count of species
need integrated concept of biodiversity
Diversity within species studied by geneticists (heredity)
heredity is amnesic, no inheritance of acquired characters
Weissman: you don't pass on your own characteristics to your progeny, just the hereditary info you already received
genetics; born in 1906
With genetics, could start to look at species from a systematic, genetic point of view.
target of selection: genetic information, not individuals
but look at the species as only one of the components of biodiversity, other equally important are individuals and genes
individuals are contingent artifacts invented by genes to be reproduced
Notion of selfish genes
Next came the concept that individuals are contingent artefacts invented by genes to be reproduced.
Information will either grow or disappear according to the efficiency of the avatar it produced.

Biologists historically have had problems dealing with thinking about material things as information. DNA -> RNA is *not* equivalent to C + O2 -> CO2. The information appears in RNA without any transfer of material
Biologists not trained in thinking about information (or no distinction between matter, information). Genetics about the fluxes of information, physiology about matter and energy
we do know what matter is, but have no idea about what information is
Can information act on matter?
humans are systems transforming encoded information into action
Encoded info can act on matter if there is a system to transform it.
in nature: DNA == encoded information
Analog to the molecular machinery acting on the DNA encoded information transforming it into action and matter
(Fantastic - this thread is turning into a lovely story of the keynote!)
biology is an empirical science. couldn't have predicted that there are horses/zebra hybrids
Biology an active science, theory in construction
Nature is neither moral or immoral: it is non-moral.
founders of genetics also founded eugenics, e.g. Galton: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki...
Karl Pearson: "the right to live does not connote the right of each man to reproduce his kind"
Pearson (student of Galton): right to live does not grant the right to reproduce
eugenics movement stopped after Nuremberg trials
in todays society gene are right wing, environment is left
genes are right-wing, experiment is left-wing (interview Sarkozy / french philosopher)
"Genes are right-wing, environment is left-wing" results in lots of chuckles from the audience
Quote of the conference, amirite?  ;)
@Johann - definitely the quote of the keynote - do we get a final vote at the end? ;)

Proportion / contribution of genes and environment difficult to determine -- which part of the observed variation is due to the variation in genes vs variation in environment? We are just partitioning a given sample.
results are contingent on the data, change in the data e.g., environment change results/inferences.  Must be make clear to the public.
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...
Conclusion: We need to build a concept of information, we need to be able to measure it
information remains a fuzzy concept in biology.  Effort by computer scientist and biologist must be put into clearing this up

great first question -- nuremberg was the transition between near-unanimous support among scientists for eugenics to opposition.  What was it that changed?  (not sure I understand the answer, which focused on analogy to current GMO debate)

Personal view: Not sure that the definition and conceptualisation of information, per se, need to be greatly extended beyond that provided by Shannon and his intellectual progeny. This may simply be another case where expertise accumulated in other fields has yet to be applied fully to Biology. Open to being corrected on this…
Open Question: Would it be possible that eugenetics is a manner by which people in favor of eugenetics express their instincts of survival?

body: Special Session 2: Ortholog Inference; Erik Sonnhamer: InParanoid, InParalogs, and OrthoXML

comments.body: Definitions of orthologues and paralogues

homologs are descendants of a common ancestor.  orthologs are related by a speciation event at their most recent common ancestor.  in-paralogs are paralogs that were duplicated after the speciation and hence are orthologs to a cluster in the other species.  o/w they are outparalogs.  see Sonnhammer & Koonin 2002
InParanoid algorithm
InParanoid starts with reciprocally best matching pair as orthologs, but if there are other genes within the same species that are closer, then they are inparalogs.  So the cluster expands this way.
New InParanoid, version 4.0. increased specificity and coverage
InParanoid 4.0 increased specificity by better low complexity filtering and stricter match length control.  Low complexity is a problem e.g., in Dictyostelium.
The match length control ensures it is the largest domain on each sequence that gets accepted; before one might have had fragmentary matches.
They lowered the cutoff from 50 to 40 bits, increasing coverage.
Improved web interface to the inparalog database (version 7)

A new web interface supports the same types of analysis. For an ortholog group, the tree of all orthologs is calculated, and the domain architectures are displayed adjacently. http://inparanoid.sbc.su.se
(Erik Sonnhammer has the first of a series of 20 minutes talks in this session).
Get an orthophylogram: the UPGMA tree based on %orthologs appearing
Get more or less the same species tree as the accepted one, but some surprises, e.g., guinea pig C. porcellus clusters with dog C. familiaris.
Reconstruction of phylogenetic tree suggests that marsupials have  a reduced genome compared to  mammals. (?)
There exists many ortholog databases, at least 25.
One utility of orthologues, link model organism databases among each other
Issues in the field include crosslinking model organism databases.
Mine, PHOG, appeared at the bottom of the list: http://phylofacts.berkeley.edu/ortholo.... Woohoo!
would like ortholog interoperability
Ortholog interoperabilty requires comparisons. Comparison problematic due to different input data sets.
Proposes a new standard for input and output of orthology algorithms, both in XML
Proposal: Define standards for orthologue detection algorithms, e.g., share data, quality control, easz parsing
Suggests a standard for orhology databases using XML, enabling simple and easy parsing..
The output is OrthoXML.
The input is SeqXML.
Besides the orthologues in OrthoXML, some basic info about the parameters used in orthology detection are stored, as xml notes
call to be informed of other possible formats (don't make yet another format)
http://OrthoXML.org under construction; http://InParanoid.sbc.su.se; and http://sonnhammer.sbc.su.se/
Commenter would like sequence coordinates, especially as different domains of a protein may have different orthologs.
Inparalogs are co-orthologs , all should be considered
orthoxml.org does not yet resolve - (follow Inparanoid for news on XML format I presume)
@Jim Yep, sorry about that. Nameserver problems -- should be temporary. Will try to put a pointer on the Inparanoid page when it's up.

body: Special Session 2: PAINT: Ortholog Inference; Suzanna Lewis: The GO Workbench for Protein Family Annotation

comments.body: GO database has 101 species with annotations
243530 gene products (including proteins and functional RNAs) are included (so, even for the covered species not everything is covered)
49,270 annotations are based on bench experiments (~20%)
113K are curated
Most of the annotation though are inferred, only 0.1% have experimental evidence
The GO consortium is interested in orthologs because the majority of annotation is transferred electronically, only 0.1% is experimentally verified.
there are 42 million annotations: 0.4% are curated and 0.1% have experimental evidence
GO reference genome project picked 12 reference genomes
Orthology as a tool to transfer knowledge, annotation
Mouse, Rat, S. pombe, Zebrafish, yeast, Dictyostelium, C. elegans, Human, ...
12 reference genome project such as yeast, fly and human (all eukaryotes)
orthologs often conserve function, though of course there are exceptions
i.e., all the reference genomes are eukaryotes
MODs (model organism databases) are doing BLAST to find "orthologs", each a little differently
two steps in functional inference: propagate up to ancestor, then down to orthologs
Gang Fang, February 2009, found loss from identifier mismatch
Loss from ID mismatch substantially as demonstrated by Gang Fang (Gerstein group).
id mapping really must be solved; each set loses many orthologs
Start with core set of proteins for each MOD:
got every MOD to generate a core set of genes; preferred UniProt ids, but would take what they could get
finally got FASTA file of all proteins for each MOD
Gang Fang did ID cleansing, found much dissimilarity (see Venn diagrams)
Not in XML, only a simple FASTA set as proposed by Erik Sonnhammer previously, but she considers this a mere formatting issue.
generated protein families, ran through PANTHER and through OrthoMCL
Pascale Gaudet, lead curator, checks each out
Don look at the ortholog sets as just venn diagrams, look to the phylogeny of orthologues: PAINT tool
The annotation therefore considers all major model organisms on the protein family level.
Get PAINT orthology: protein family tree from PANTHER on the left, overlaid with orthologs provided by different methods on the right
Still requires manual inspection but decision is on the ancestral node of the ortho-tree.
Overlay alignment with the tree
wishlist: standard protein sets; single site: ftp://ftp.pantherdb.org/genomes/pthr7.0
Use standard protein sets for orthology detection and knowledge transfer among MODs
would like ortholog database, as Erik did, for direct comparison between methods
Her desiderata include standard protein sets, responsible persons can be addressed, use a single site, comparability of the DBs.
working on PAINT as inferencing tool
Q by Ruchira: Ortholog method (PhyloFacts with Uniprot input, why use a different set of standard sets, why not standardizing on Uniprot?
A (by Alex Bateman if I am not mistaken): Uniprot is not considering all proteins, not complete because its being curated. Main resource though, recommended but not present for e.g. Zebrafish.
Chicken and Zebrafish were the main ones not represented
Roland, I asked the question, and was referring to PhyloFacts: http://phylofacts.berkeley.edu/ortholo...
Q: Experimentalists want nucleotide sequences. Is it there? A: To many sequences to be matched to each other.
@Ruchira, (Hi) I updated the comment.
Judith Blake of Jackson Lab gives mouse protein-coding genes as an example
Erik Sonnhammer remarks that in OrthoXML has GeneID as a required field
FASTA headers are notoriously freeform, so OrthoXML will help but is not a complete solution
Fairly technical session so far, hope to hear some debates over principles later.
The webpage for Lewis's group: http://berkeleybop.org/softwar...

body: Special Session 2: Ortholog Inference; Albert Vilella: EnsemblCompara: comparative genomics in phylogenies

comments.body: multiple alignments and gene trees
Describing the ENSEMBL orthology set up
How to define what a famil, sub-family or super-family is? quite arbitrary
pipeline has two basic parts: defining the clusters of orthologs, and doing things with them
load genes and longest translation from all species in Ensembl
wublastp + SmithWaterman all against all genome-wise
build a graph of gene relations based on wublastp scores
hierarchical clustering using hcluster_sg (some 20,000 clusters)
About 20000 clusters are produced.
Multiple alignment using M-coffee, a meta-aligner.
build a multiple alignment (MCoffee: consensus of different alignments)
(Very good politically he quips)
good politically: if anyone complains their alignment method was omitted, include it!
TreeBeST to build a reconciled gene tree with internal duplication nodes
Build reconciled gene tree using TreeBeST.
then infer orthologs and paralogs using OrthoTree
Generates good topology, including biased genomes.
Reconcile the CDS alignment (back-translated)
TreeBeST computes many topologies, then merges the best parts into a final one
PhyML using amino acid distances
for very close species (e.g., human & chimp), use nucleotide distances
Curated tree topologies can be included.
TreeBeST appears to be very useful (http://treesoft.sourceforge.net/treebes...)
if have very long branches in one subtree produced by one method, and in another subtree produced by the other method, merge the other subtrees (with good short branches) produced by the two methods
infer timing of duplication event from species seen in subtree, topologically
Examples of large eukaryotic phylogenies in trees.
some apparent gene losses are just gene prediction errors
able to infer whole-genome duplications by mapping all the duplication events back to the species tree
Timing and testing of known duplication events, e.g whole genome evolution in early eukaroytes or teleosts. Quality depends on the outgroup.
can get back nucleotides and spot the synonymous substitutions
then compute dN/dS for every column of the alignments
Calculation of dN/dS for every column of the alignment.
have some highly conserved columns, and some very noisy
Can be used for detection of misalignments, e.g different exons.
Help gene annotation.
http://www.ensemblgenomes.org
All sequenced organisms are going to receive the ENSEMBL treatment, incl. prokaryotes.
shared models for classification, e.g., HMMs shared among e!PanC Panther, PFAM, TreeFam; have HMM hierarchy
Q: How do you root the gene trees?
A: Always based on the species tree.  The outgroup is on the outside; then based on the largest middle distance.
A: Based on the deepest outgroup of species tree and the middle distance.
Uses only topology of the species tree, and can handle multifurcations in the species tree.
Q: Is genomic information such as synteny included? A. Not currently, testing some approaches, in particular for co-linear copies.
See Yeast Gene Order Browser http://wolfe.gen.tcd.ie/ygob/

body: Special Session 2: Ortholog Inference; Yuri Wolf: Archaeal clusters of orthologous genes

comments.body: From Koonin's group; presumably COG analogue.  Yes, arCOGs
Dec 2006: had 41 archaeal genomes
Most ortholog predictions focus on eukaryotes but here we'll hear about 41 archaeal species.
not a lot of domain-shuffling, not a lot of low complexity regions
all vs all protein BLAST, construct similarity graph
lineage-specific expansions identified (Jordan et al 2001, Lespinet et al 2002)
Construction of arCOGs from 91951 protein sequences, established similarity, line specific expansions, then classical COG algorithm (triangles of reciprocal best hits).
initial clusters based on triangles of symmetrical best hits using modified COG algorithm as in Tatusov,....,Koonin 2007
key innovation: make multiple alignments using MUSCLE, mask to find maximal alignable core
Key innovation using muscle focusing on the maximum alignable core to construct PSSMs.
all reciprocal best hits methods include sequences that are not fully alignable
make a PSSM profile for a PSI-BLAST search, then search the original db of Archaea proteins
this expands the clusters; also, multi-domain proteins can be split between clusters, due to maximum alignable core
Multiple domain proteins can be split in this manner.
the clusters obtained in this way are overly strict
Very strict initial clustering are brought together by PSI-BLAST, only inspecting similarity between clusters, using minimal linkage clustering.
now merge these very fine clusters: build a similarity graph for the expanded clusters from the PSI-BLAST result, then use minimum linkage clustering to make a tree of clusters
analyze the phyletic patterns for all clusters and merge clusters belonging to subtrees with (nearly) complementary phyletic patterns
Merge further clusters if phyletic patterns are complementary and sub-paralogs - small subfamilies within a larger famiy).
BLAST against the COG 2003 db to associate arCOGs with COGs
Compare to the COG data base with COGNITOR.
COG is heavily curated; if an arCOG is associated with multiple COGs, then split it
same clustering of clusters to make superfamilies of arCOGs
Super-COGs with PSI-BLAST and minimum linkage clustering.
High coverage (87%)
Q: Why using MUSCLE instead of MAFFT or T-Cofffee? A: Historical reasons

body: Special Session: Ortholog Inference: Avril Coghlan, TreeFam

comments.body:
TreeFam is database of phylogenetic trees, 5 years old as a collaboration between Richard Durbin, Beijing genomics institute and recently the Sanger centre. 
TreeFam infers orthologs and paralogs.

TreeFam uses trees which is more robust to rate differences in different genes. That claim has not been tested on a large scale. 
Duplications and losses can be easily recognized.

Use outgroups for rooting the tree. Build from seeds, now using previous versions of TreeFam. When adding a new genome each seed family is expanded by a full-length HMMer.
Build the alignment using Muscle and build the tree using TreeBeST, comprising a WAG, phyml, a HKY-PhyML tree as well as . NJ-dN and a NJ-dS tree.
Gives a confidence for the orthology assignment.
Perl API, database is online. (Excuse the leaky coverage, FF is no longer accepting comments from this IP address, we think).
Analysis of Schistosoma mansoni genome by analyzing losses and duplications.
Why using MUSCLE?  Their algorithm is robust to the alignment program/algorithm used, as they only used well conserved sequences.  Poorly aligned regions are discarded

body: Special Session: Ortholog Inference: Paul Thomas on Panther 7.0

comments.body: Even ortholgs can diverge in function, paralogs can conserve function.
Functional annotation previously done using sequence similarity only.
A small example is the MTHFR present in E. coli and eukaryotes showing accelerated evolution in insect species, a functional, experimental ortholog in one the yeast copies and the coli protein.
Paralogs in yeast show different behaviour, one no longer involved in methionine biosynthesis.
Desiderata: Complete gene sets, stable tree nodes,  duplications and importance of dN/dS
Panther 7.0 is annotated by GO.
Important issues are sequence alignments, different rates of evolution are problematic as it becomes more problematic to estimate parameters.
Recommended papers for these problems are  Rasmussen and Kellis, GR 2007 and Marcet-Houbet & Galbadon PLoS ONE, 2009
TreeBeST and Synergy all use the species relationship
Idea for the GIGA algorithm: Use species tree as constraint, how simple can we make an inference algorithm.
Minimize gene loss events, hypothesize a change of rate of evolution.
Comparison with TreeFam 6.0 shows robustness as estimated by Robinson fold distance.
Q: Any clear cut of idea of incorporationg the uncertainty, e.g. bootstraps? A: Use multifurctations in the GIGA (...)
Please visit my poster, W95, to learn about our new orthology inference method & webserver, PHOG.

body: Keynote: Trey Ideker - New Challenges and Opportunities in Network Biology

comments.body: Trey Ideker has an impressed career. He obtained his PhD in 2001, now at UCSD
The curse of systems biology: you will be a jack of all trades, rather than a master of one.
How does one automatically model systems and pathways from a variety of data
Ideker et al.: Ann Rev Genomics Hum Genetics 2001 - his PhD work (Systems Biology: A new approach to decoding life.
Given basic knowledge of a pathway measure the global response to systematic perturbations, compare predictions and observations and determine the goodness of fit, revise and repeat
Ideker (Sciene 2001), GAL metabolic flow as an example
Use systematic interaction data (Protein-DNA, PPI, biochemical reactions) to zoom out from a well-understood small pathway to a more global view
The final figure of that Science manuscript, he feels, launched his career.

Change to the 'modern area'. Querying large biological networks for active modules, colouring graphs with expression states, enzyme activity, any kind of activity. Automatically extract subnetworks / modules from the global 'hairball'
Interaction Database Dump, aka "Hairballs", which aren't good for a whole lot.
Projection of siRNA phenotypes on a HIV protein interaction network (human-human and human-HIV) to identify active modules
For what @Oliver said directly above: (Konig et al. Cell 2008).
A working map for moving network biology to the clinic: does not have to be complete and can tolerate false positives. Innovation in how to assemble the map (what pieces / input)
Key problem: moving past the pretty pictures and interpreting them
The cell is actually a hairball
Path- and NetworkBLAST for cross-comparison of networks. Apply techniques that work well for genomes and apply them to networks
Looking for matched protein pairs (by sequence similarity) with conserved interactions between species
Human vs mouse TF-TF networks in brain (Tim Ravasi)
Using the FANTOM4 data
Subsets of tissues with perfect alignment of TF subnetworks
Sharan & Ideker. Nat Biotech 2006
What follows is a very nice slide on the timeline of both biological sequence comparison and biological network comparison. Can't write that! See @Diego above for citation for this
Trey thinks there are better things out there now than PathBLAST and networkBLAST.
Genetic interactions form a distinct type of network maps. Comparison across network types instead of across species
Here, there exists a genetic interaction between gene A and B if phenotype of mutant a is OK, mutant b is OK, and mutant ab is sick. (Tong et al. Science 2001)
Identify biological pathways / physical interactions that support genetic interactions
Kelley and Ideker Nat Biotech 2005 worked on systematic identification of parallel pathway relations.
Genetic interactions run 'between' clusters of physical interactions, not within them
(Kelley and Ideker, Nat Biotech 2005)
Results in a functional map of protein complexes linked by 'bundles' of genetic interactions between complexes
(Roguev, Science 2008) Genetic interaction maps are conserved between species (S cerevisiae, S pombe)
http://www.cytoscape.org
Change of networks and methods again: ChIP-chip to integrate cause-and-effect networks with physical networks
TF-promoter binding, PPI and effect of perturbation on expression (regulation)
"If you have a problem with [Cytoscape], please, don't change software; just join us".
(Yeang, Mak, Genome Biol 2005)
What if a lot of transcriptional binding is real but inconsequential to cellular function?
What if a binding event is real but inconsequential to the cell?
Results of the method in Workman, Mak, Science 2006
K/O TFs and look at expression data to help identify real and functional binding
This is a great keynote: it's like a review article in presentation form (plus more)!
Over 90% of ChIP-chip interactions not significant in the combined network
around 90% of the binding events (ChIP-chip) appear to be inconsequential to the cell
the remaining 10% is very significant, more than expected by chance
Physical location of TFs: subset exhibits bimodal chromosomal localization, enriched in the subtelomeric regions
Gal4 among them
Regions are enriched for stress genes. Binding of factors to the region seems to be condition-specific
Factors being sequestered away from their target genes under certain conditions?
Network-based disease diagnosis and prognosis
Changes to a breast cancer metastasis classifier using additional features. (Imperfect) diagnostic sets of genes have been identified previously, ROC at around 0.65
Lack of robustness across studies (overlap between three classifier sets not larger than random expected overlap)
Overlay with PPI data to identify informative subnetworks (Chuang, Mol Sys Biol 2007)
Taylor et al. 2009 Nat Biotech, better approach recommended by Trey
blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...
Thank you for the notes. Allyson
@Kuan-Ting no problem at all! Me and the other bloggers enjoy making them!

body: PT32: Timothy O'Connor - Genotype-Phenotype Associations: Substitution Models to Detect Evolutionary Associations Between Phenotypic Variables and Genotypic Evolutionary Rate

comments.body: Can we detect a change of rate in evolution. Model is sperm competition in apes.
Phylogeny is important to look at the independent signal, also use the past nodes for inference.
Problems arise from the use of extant taxa and neglecting internal states. Trying to map the rate of evolution using Markov Models, including the error of the internal state reconstruction.
Independent and dependent Q-matrices are introduced.

Several szenarios for primate sperm competition, split into low and high cases, looked at 13 candidate genes and 2 controls, more than in the submitted paper. Model slightly modified by setting W1> W0.
The known gene SEMG2 stands out after multiple testing corrections, other genes not that dramatically.
Current work on the electron transport chain to look into max lifespans and body size, referring to the metabolic and the longevity hypotheses.
Metabolic hypothesis slightly supported, ongoing work.
It's a first model that incorporates rate changes in genotype-phenotype associations.
Q: For this method, what is the statistical power (sensitivity)? A: Typically, its fairly sensitive.
Q: Do more data improve the quality? A: Yes.

body: HL32: Rui Jiang - Network modeling of human interactome and phenome

comments.body: most current methods to predict disease genes are based on "guilt by association"
e.g. approach based on protein-protein interaction networks
these methods depend on seed genes, which limits the power of such methods
Question: can one borrow seed genes of other diseases for predicting the basis of a disease without known genetic basis?
consider disease as a multi-layered network: sequence -- molecules/proteins -- clinical traits -- disease
sharing of nodes and edges between diseases
can calculate similarity of diseases in their clinical traits
linear regression model to explain similarity between diseases based on contributions from genes (that are close in the PPI network)
approach called CIPHER
concordance score for gene--disease links
[different methods of validation, seems to work...]
genetic landscape of human diseases: 5000 disease vs. 14000 genes
clustering reveals phenotypes which have a similar genetic basis
network alignment: previously used to align PPI networks
AlignPI: align phenome and interactome using gene-disease links. output: bi-modules
use NetworkBLAST as method
get 39 bi-modules, alle of them are enriched with a specific disease category
can try to predict new disease genes by assuming disease-gene links
[I don't get how he ranks the genes]
Back online. Neither do I, Michael. Some details move past a bit too quickly.
See http://www.fiamh.info/article...
great notes

body: HL29: Lawrence Hunter - Biomedical Discovery Acceleration

comments.body: single genes don't explain phenotypes, have to understand gene sets. genes work together in complex, dynamics groups. need to be able to apply data from other disciplines to our data. but: knowledge has increased so much that it's impractical to screen all potentially relevant papers.
example : Relaxin I. Why do some people not respond to beta blockers during heart failure? Cardiologists didn't know about relaxin I, well known in context of child birth.
"Genes do not respect disciplinary boundaries."
3R system: "Hanalyzer", Reading (import dbs, extract knowledge)/Reasoning (infer additional knowledge)/Reporting (help biologists explain data / generate new hypothesis).

idea: align knowledge networks with data networks. nodes: fixed entities, e.g. gene db ids or ontology terms. links: potentially uncertain relations between the nodes. (i.e. probabilistic network). compare multiple sources of info into combined edge
data network: data from experiments; knowledge network: data from literature. combine data and knowledge, visualize in two ways: either equal weight, or logistics (emphasizes data)
cyotscape plugin "common attributes", also see Hanalyzer demo on YouTube, have links to data sources

can look at correlated genes, first check out which genes are known and then extend the network to find new genes that may be developed in the process: get new hypothesis. check localization of proteins: could validate predictions.

body: TT23: Steve Pettifer - Utopia Documents: The Digital Meta-Library

comments.body: Good luck with the demo!

he says "most computer science papers are rubbish" in that in CS, the thing itself is the result, which makes it a different form of literature to life scientists, where papers are about finding out things that already exist.
We all want easy access to paper, the information in the paper, the auxillary data
What does the community think of a paper? My friend?
pubmed grows at about 2 papers per minute. and that's not all of them!
A live demo? Risky with this wireless connection
When looking at a paper, it will highlight things/sections it recognizes, such as the title and the references
If errata/comments have been added to the original paper, utopia will update your pdf with them too.
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...
@Allysson, I really like how you summarize the full microblogging in your blog!

@Egon thanks! When it's only me blogging, that's very much what it looks like. Actually, the order of events is 1) write notes in my blog, and 2) take any interesting tidbits out of the blog (as I'm taking the notes) and copy them into FF. It seems to work well. Of course it works even better with lots of FFers commenting, as it means we get different perspectives, as well as conversations!
@Allysson cheers for blogging too! I would have commented more but I'm biased as I'm on the team, but it was great to see how it went! Apparently they had a wired connection for that demo ;o)
@Philip that makes sense - wired is much safer here! And as for bias, I generally will still blog if it interests me, but just state plainly at the beginning any biases I have :)
@Philip P.S. I'd like to meet up with you and Steve at some point during the meeting, as I know Alice V. and she mentioned you :)
@Allyson ah - yes she's sitting right next to me! I'm not at ISMB, Steve and Dave (Thorne) are there from our group. have to catch you at a conference another time soon though!
@Philip no worries - I remembered Alice told me "Utopia" but forgot the names associated with it :)

body: HL27: Igor Ulitsky - Regulatory networks define phenotypic classes of human stem cell lines

comments.body: want to understand molecular basis of pluripotency; need to ensure safety of stem cell therapy (don't want to create cancers)
mRNA profiling of pluripotent and multipotent stem cells. using negative matrix factorization to group the cell types
12 clusters work well, get mostly homogenous clusters
Matisse approach, Ulitsky & Shamir BMC Systems Biol, 2007

create subnetwork of genes upregulated in pluripotent cells, have reason to believe that the subnetwork contains most of the pluripotency machinery. highly expressed in plurip. cells, not highly expressed in differentiated cells
also look for microRNAs; profile 800 miRNAs in 26 cell lines: Laurent et al., Stem Cells 2008. stem cell groups share similar miRNA profiles
look for differences between embryonic and other cells lines. clustered miRNA had a tendency to be differentially regulated in embr. cell lines
major seed sequence (AAGUGC) contained in miRNAs from 4 clusters (21 miRNAs, 18 are upregulated in embr. cells), also have such families in other species (non-homologous to human)

find complement of seed sequences in differentially regulated genes; look for pathways co-regulated by miRNAs, identify 57 such "PRMs"; find subnetwork of proteins which are jointly regulated, e.g. in cell cycle progression; find new submodule, which could be important in protection from neurodegeneration
Login servers still down. Talk notes at http://www.fiamh.info/article...

body: PT23: Manfred Claassen - Proteome Coverage Prediction with Infinite Markov Models

comments.body: Predticiton of proteome coverage in shotgun proteomics for maximum coverage, to find a stop criterion, and to direct study design
estimating the limit of theoretical coverage first requires a quantification of the distribution of observable peptides. The computer science analogy used is the chinese restaurant process
Chinese Restaurant Processes, i.e. the rich get richer, "dish" distribution: many proteins are observed over and over again
customers map to spectra, dishes map to peptides
a hierarchy of chinese restaurants (== dirichlet processes) ensuring support for likely observed peptides in the root distribution of observable peptides
adapting the infinite markov model to the case where identifications are false positives (account for target decoy strategy based FPR estimation)
(... simply add an extra dimension that samples over the identification database - ie model the FPR random chance distribution)
maximal coverage!=saturation coverage - more experiments means the quality of discoveries are worse, ie the less certain you can be about your real matches

Answers that the proteome coverage prediction can provide: How many peptides can be identified?
More experiments deteriorate quality of discoveries: quality constraint restricts maximum coverage

I think this is really important - but I am not expert enough to understand how this diriSim model can be applied to the 'limits' of proteomics studies, where one is looking for very specific types of proteins (e.g. PTM characterisation, etc).

body: HL24: Jason McDermott - Discovery of a hidden sequence motif conserved in the bacterial type III secretion signal: implications for structure, drug discovery and host-pathogen systems models.

comments.body: Salmonella typhimurium is the main model organism for this work. It builds its own niche using the T3SS in the macrophages, kills many people each year. In the US, it's mainly a food pathogen.
Good model system for Salmonella typhi, the agent of typhus, a narrow range human pathogen.
Includes two T3SS, injecting effectors into the host cell. 47 known effectors.

Problems in T3SS, consisting of the injectosome and the secreted effectors, is the remote homogy of the efffectors. N-terminus of the effectors required for secretion but no similarity could be found.

Typically not part of the 3D structure, appears to be disordered. How could the diverse sequences have the same function? Different mechanism ´for every effector? Cognate chaperones help the effectors to thread the protein into the injectosome. But you can delete the chaperone.
Hypothesis for this talk: There is a common mechanism in the effectors. Typically BLAST was used to identify the secretion family.

Previous analysis have been working for some organisms but not across species. The group developed a machine learning method (SVMs) from the primary sequence, including the nt-.sequence and used an unaligned input of the sequence. Used Pseudomonas syringae with 35 known effectors. Used the rest of the genome as negative examples.
ROC is in the 0.05 range.
Applied this to Chlamydia trachomatis, an almost untractable obligate intracellular pathogen.
A similar paper appeared back to back with this paper, another paper was published recently. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed...
Identification of a T3SS motif by in silico mutagenesis.
Experimental validation is in the making.
3D-prediction of the N-terminus, using a variety of 3Dand 2D-structure prediction methods and disorder prediction. Found a little initial beta-sheet followed by a short helix.
NMR and CD data being analyzed.
Systems biology approach, looking into transcription and regulation, network topology studies ties in nicely with the effectors work, being at the interface of two networks in host and pathogen.

body: HL23: Sven Nelander - Models from experiments: combinatorial perturbations of cancer cells

comments.body: What happens when you change more than one thing in a cell?
A defining feature of cancer cells is a breakdown in regulation.
A defining feature of cancer cells is a breakdown in regulation by aquired GOF (gain of function) or LOF (loss of function) mutations.
One of the advances in cancer pharmacology are compounds that target the function of the proteins in these pathways.
Approaches to CP (combinatorial perturbations) include metabolic flux models, and what we need is an equivalent for the cancer cells.
Each perturbation pattern consists of 1, 2 or 3 perturbations in sequence. This pattern is converted into a phosphoprotein and phenotype pattern.
use a linear differentiation equation
Start with good tradeoffs between model fit and simplicity.
They use a MC simulation, which results in the probabilities of functional interaction.
They adapted CoPIA to cancer genomics data, and the main issue was speed.
"To see what's in front of one's nose takes a constant struggle" George Orwell
Their method for this data is derived from the S-System (Savageau 1969 J Theor Biol)
Network issues, could not post during the talk. Summary of notes over at http://www.fiamh.info/article...

body: PT21: Jose Caldas - Probabilistic retrieval and Visualization of Biologically Relevant Microarray Experiments

comments.body: Trying to find a method to relate results in large array databases based on expression information rather than annotation.
Standard approaches like spearman correlation coefficients, but it would be interested to use sets of experiments as a query rather than a single array.

Query with a binary phenotype comparison and try to get back other, similar comparisons. Requires encoding of the phenotype comparison such as a vector of t-tests (0/1 vector for differentially expressed genes)
Using differential GSEA (shorter vector, more robust)
GSEA is gene set enrichment analysis and compares gene sets with -1,0,+1 vectors
Uses standard GSEA, number of genes in leading edge as vector value, ignoring the directionality
Latent Dirichlet Allocation for the retrieval algorithm
Latent Drichilet Allocation (LDA) from text analysis works intuitively: uses documents to build up topics -- in bag-of-words text data.
Bag-of-words from gene sets, represented as combinations of sets, relevant distance measures can be applied
750+ binary phenotype comparisons from 288 experiments, focus on 105 comparisons for this analysis. Gene sets assigned to topics are coherent across a wide range of biological processes
Cell cycle gene sets in "topic 2": BRCA genes show up in 4 comparisons all related to cancer, as expected.
Retrieval performance better than random, but seems to have low-to-moderate recall for reasonable precision numbers (?)
Blog post at: http://www.fiamh.info/article...

comments.body: Trish has recorded her talk as a screencast as she wanted to do a demo, and she can't trust the wireless - true enough!
RESTful services for BioPortal: http://rest.bioontology.org/bioport... (Note this is the prefix for all services, and if you just go to this URL there isn't anything visible)
main BioPortal site: http://bioportal.bioontology.org
Can store ontologies in OWL, OBO and Protege frames formats.

There are also ontology widgets that you can put on your own site, including jump-to feature and term selection widget. This latter one is especially useful because it allows your web app to use term auto-complete without having to code it yourself!
The search function is especially important for ontology re-use. For instance, if you're developing a new domain ontology, then you want to make sure you don't reinvent the wheel
As with all of these functions, the search features are available both via the website and programmatically
BioPortal also allows you to annotate, or add notes, to ontologies.
Nice - a tag / term cloud for annotation
You may see duplicates in the tag cloud - designed to be this way to show that more than one ontology has that term.
they have a visualization of the hierarchy that is dynamic and you can play with.
Questions? support at bioontology.org
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...

body: PT19: Mikhail Zaslavskiy - Global Alignment of Protein-Protein Interaction Networks by Graph Matching Methods

comments.body: Motivation: identification of protein functional orthologs
Standard approach like reciprocal best BLAST hits have problems when several top hits have similar scores -- which pair to chose? Additional information helps to resolve ambiguity.
PPI networks (the usual hairball) can be used to resolve this. If ortholog assignments conserve PPI interactions are ranked higher
Maximize number of conserved interaction and the sum of BLAST pair scores
Used message passing clustering approach for the InParanoid/protein cluster approach; each node is a protein cluster
Balanced alignment uses graph matching approximation (gradient ascent and path algorithm)

PPI networks and InParanoid clusters from the Ideker paper, 2244 clusters (1552 with only 2 proteins / orthologs, 692 ambiguous clusters that need to be resolved). No cycles in this graph means constrained alignment approach can be used, results in 238 conserved interactions
Constrained algorithm with message passing is an exact solution, graph matching algorithms deliver good performance for balanced alignment problems
Additional notes: http://www.fiamh.info/article...

body: HL22: Dannie Durand - Sequence Similarity Network Reveals Common Ancestry of Multidomain Proteins

comments.body: Multidomain proteins are difficult to categorize because different parts have different histories.
Multidomain homolgs - finding homologs is an important aspect of functional genomics.
Song et al 2008 PLoS Computational Biology 4(5)
http://www.neighborhoodcorrelation.org/
Paper: http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/article...
Genes that share common ancestry tend to have similar structure and function.
also use to build comparative map of synteny
Sequence comparison can be used to identify chromosomal regions that share common ancestry.
this is called "spatial genomics"
How multidomain proteins fit this picture?
Example tyrosine kinases associated with many different domains.
example: protein tyrosine kinases
one family with many domain architectures, all sharing a kinase domain
Multidomain sequences evolve via gene duplication and domain shuffling.
multidomain sequences evolve via gene duplication and domain shuffling
The same domain may appear in multiple, unrelated proteins.
A definition will be presented that is in line with Fitch' proposition of homology.
can have case where genes share common ancestry, but domain architecture has changed
Difference between sequences related by vertical descent and related by domain insertion.
Two kinds of relations among genomes: relation by vertical descent or relation by domain insertion.
similarly can have the converse: through domain shuffling, genes that are not homologous can come to have the same domain architecture
It is possible to distinguish such two cases?
Given two sequences with similarity: Can one distinguish the two szenarios?
homologs are related by vertical descent
orthologs are related by speciation
orthologs are a subset of homologs, and homologs intersect with the set of significantly similar sequences
also have distant homologs which don't appear to be significantly similar
A Venn diagram, including orthologs, homologs, distant homologs and significantly similar sequences with modification.
inferences that can be drawn from vertical descent (similar molecular functions) and domain insertion (bindng partners) are different
Biological interpretation of vertical descent: molecular function; regulation; comparative mapping; processes of gene duplication and genome rearrangement.
Interpretations of domain insertion: protein specialization; ligand specificity; localization; process of domain shuffling.
vertical descent implies similar: molecular function, regulation, comparative mapping, and is useful for processes of duplication and genome rearrangement
domain insertion leads to relationships of protein specialization, ligand binding, and cellular localization
In animals and plants multidomain sequences become more important than in bacteria.
The more higher eukaryotes will be sequenced, the more the problem needs to be addressed.
therefore, among similar sequences, want to distinguish which are related by vertical descent, and which by domain insertion
people look at sequence similarity E-value, and at alignment coverage
Alignment length is typically used to distinguish domain re-arrangements. Needs a decent mode model.
Good example that sequence similarity or e-values are not capable of distinguishing the two caes.
The goal of this method is to identify sequence pairs related by VD and DI,and should work on a broad range of families
And needs to be computationally feasible.
To test, they looked at 20 well-studied families related by vertical descent.
They had a much larger set of negative examples (40,000).
PSI-BLAST performs worse then BLAST for sequences with variable architecture multi-domain proteins(!) as it pulls in non-homologous parts of sequences.

All methods do well with conserved multidomain proteins. They were more challenged by Variable multidomain, where Psi-BLAST doesn't do as well as BLAST. Both methods are extremely challenged when all the sequences were put into the analysis together.
Pairwise comparisons are not sufficient. Try networks instead.
Pairwise sequences might not be enough, use the structure of the similarity networks.
Two sequences are compared in the context of their respective neighborhoods (i.e. other sequences that show similarity).
Domain architecture is implicitly present in the network.
Open question. The model is explicitly based on insertion and deletion. What about de novo sequence formation?
Comment by Kevin Karplus: Use log scale for false positives in the ROC plots.
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...

body: HL20: Burak Erman - Prediction of Binding Sites on Proteins Using the Gaussian Network Model

comments.body: Energy and environment are a closed system, thermodynamic modeling of system with entropy, energy, volume and position of the residues
A probability function over the average values of the system can be used to formulate the average of the extensive variables and the conjugate variables.
Harmonic fluctuations models the relationship between the residues in the system.
Higher order correlation can be used to obtain the energy fluctiuations and the residues, which is proportional.
The highest mode is the interesting end of the decomposition.
HIV protease as a model system, active site and binding interfaces are identified as important residues as fast modes. System behaves as an energy sieve.
Residues at the surface are energy gates, residues connecting two surfaces are hubs. Residues along the interaction pathway are anticorrelated to the important ones.
Example of the peptide binding HLA protein (1OGT) shows 6 important residues by highest mode analysis.
One AA is binding the peptide, other stabilizes the interaction.
[Structure pictures not shown]
Spatial arrangement of residues emerges as the important factor that defines function.
Residues located at the topologically important sites are the functionally important ones.
Tested in several systems.

Q: What do you need experimentally to use the method on other proteins other than the 3D structure. A: Nothing, only the residue contacts. its scale free, you can use very large proteins (in principle).
Q: What about the next highest modes? A: We get overlapping results, the same residues come up. Others show up later, not explored.
Q: Do you look into lower modes? A: No, the highest mode find the important residues.
These are not MD results, where highest modes merge with the noise of the system, every mode has his special meaning.
Some drug binidng sites not identified with the highest mode but the following.
Q: In standard elastic models you do not consider the AA, only the position. What does this mean? ~ A: We use 7 Angstrom as a contact, no further residue specificity.

body: HL18: Christophe Dessimoz - Phylogenetic and Functional Assessment of Orthologs Inference Projects and Methods

comments.body: Types of homology according to Fitch, 1970
Orthologous relationships are not transitive
In-paralogues and out-paralogues, defined by the relation between speciation and gene duplication
Genes with the same function: equivalogs or isofunctional homologues
Homologues in the same genomic context isopositional orthologues
No biological meaning in the COG clustering algorithm
InParanoid, only pairs of genomes
Orthology inferece: by best bi-directional hits or species/gene tree reconciliation
assessment of orthology inference methods
assessment; previous work: Hulsen, Huynen et al., Genome Biology, 2006 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed... and Chen, Mackey et al., PLoS ONE, 2007 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed...
9 different projectcs: COG, KOG, eggNOG, orthoMCL, inparanoid, ensembl, homlogene, roundup, oma
methos analysed: COG, KOG, eggNOG,OrthoMCL, InParanoid, ENSEMBL, Homologene, RoundUp
>300 million pairwise orthologuous pairs
intersection of all projects: empty set
use OMA as the reference
use six different benchmarks, see article
Measurements: species tree discordance, gene ontology, enzyme classification, gene expression, genomic context
the paper for this talk: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed...
use species tree discordance as test
test which method on avg yields trees that are most consistent with the accepted species tree topology
surprisingly BBH is quite good
shows (updated) figures from paper: http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/article...
all methods are able to capture/resemble to a large extent the species tree
COG/KOG/eggNOG are more inclusive, so higher coverage, but lower similarity to OMA
for phylogeny: oma homologene, function: strictt: oma, homologene, moderate: orthoMCL, loose: eggNOG
best method depends on the application. For phylogeny: OMA, Homologene; Function: OMA, Homologene (strict); OrthoMCL (moderate)
tree reconciliation not (yet?) better than pairwise approaches
Tree reconciliation is not better than pairwise methods
poster D19

Perhaps worth mentioning: in the paper the authors conclude that eggNOG groups are too loose. However, they used only the ones that are defined relative to the last universal common ancestor (LUCA), which are the broadest groups in eggNOG. The much narrower and thus more specific groups (e.g. mammalian orthologous groups) were not included in the published benchmark.
