body: HL17: Gregory Kryukov - Learning from Resequencing Data: What To Do When the $1000 Genome Arrives?

comments.body: If it were not for the great variability among individuals medicine might as well be a science and not an art (Ostler 1892) (did I get this right? :))
Mendelian diseases can be characterized by linkage analysis (classical association studies)
Currently method of choice is GWAS. Today, talk about another type of AS that is based on sequencing and is based on rare rather than common SNPs.
Association studies based on sequencing will allow for understanding rare SNPs
New sequencing technologies, ways to collect clinical populations and exon capturing approaches can revolutionize the search for genes underlying human phenotypes
@Allyson: sounds about right :)
Sequencing will uncover low frequency variants

All genes have rare coding variants, and while sequencing will uncover low frequency variants the power to detect their associations is reduced and the multiple testing correction becomes very stringent

resequencing AS (RAS). The theory here is that most new missense mutations are functional, most new missense mutations are only weakly deleterious, and most functional missense mutations are likely to influence phenotype in the same direction.
How many individuals need to be sequenced to find variants with minimal effect.

58 genes from 768 individuals (existing population sequencing data), estimate parameters of demographic history (from non-coding variation data), simulate genotypes, simulate phenotypes (quantitative traits), simulate a sequencing study to estimate the power
For 20.000 genes we need a p-Value of 2x10^-6 to associate mutations with phenotype
They do not assume pre-existing variation with pheontypic effect, they simply rely on the mutation rate.
Small sample of 1000 individuals have 75% power to detect genes which shift the phenotype deviation by 2 std devs
If consider pathways rather than genes, the same number of individuals would have over 60% power.
2x10^-6 would be the genome wide significance level which is below the 1x10^-8 level currently considered genome wide significant in GWAS
Sample sizes approaching 10.000 individuals re-sequencing based association studies are feasible (with phenotype information from 100k individuals)
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...
More notes: http://www.fiamh.info/article...

body: Keynote: Daphne Koller - Individual Genetic Variation: From Networks to Mechanisms

comments.body: aka Understanding Gene Regulation: From Networks to Mechanisms
(as some results only arrived last night)
There are many mechs (chromatin modification, rna degradation) that modify gene regulation
use 'omics' data to understand and infer GRNs
mRNA level of regulator an (imprecise) indicator of regulator activity
So you can model RNA level of a gene as a variable in a model
The expression of a target genes can often be predicted by the expression of its regulators
Regulators: transcription factors, signal transduction, chromatin remodeling . . .
Broad view of a regulator gene: TFs, signal transduction proteins, RNA processing factors, anything that *might* play a direct or indirect role in gene regulation
Second assumption: co-regulated genes have similar regulatory mechanisms, group genes into modules and predict expression profile for the entire module
Modules provide increased statistical power.
A critical aspect is the structure of the regulatory program.
(Segal 2003 Nat Genetics): notion of a regression tree for regulatory programs
has disadvantages such as poor regulator selection lower in the tree, misses lot of regulators due to lack of statistical power
another disadvantage: arbitrary choice among correlated regulators
Instead: Lasso (L1) regression approach
Simple linear regression doesn't work well because the minimization procedure assigns a nonzero weight to each regulator.
This can be solved by using regularization: an extra termn penalizing nonzero weights.
The Lasso regression pushed the effect of many regulators towards zero, likely keeping only the significant regulators
Elastic net regression to avoid arbitrary regulator / feature choice
Used for examples in this talk

Cluster genes to modules, learn regulatory program for module, repeat for all modules, iterate after re-assignment of genes to modules based on how well a program predicts the expression of a gene in the module
initial assignment of genes into modules is often poor at the beginning, must be reiterated down in the analysis
It's a special kind of Bayesian network
Test using eQTL data set (Brem, 2002 Science), two different yeast strains
eQTL dataset (Brem at al, 2000) from yeast. Microarray measurements of 112 individuals over 6000 genes.
Adapt the regulatory network approach by including the genotype / markers. How do markers affect the expression level of a given module?
She then show us one of the modules that comes out, the telomere module (40/42 of genes are in the telomere).
Example: the telomere module. Enriched for telomere maintenance and helicase activity.
Controlled by a region on chr XII (which includes a regulator gene)
23 modules out of 165 have 'chromosomal features', 16 chromatin regulators
Puf3 module: 147/153 genes are pulldown targets of mRNA binding protein Putf3.
But Puf3 is not the most significant regulator of the module.
P-bodies are places where mRNA are stored temporarily and while they are there they are transcriptionally repressed.
What regulates sequence-specific localization of mRNAs to P-bodies?
They did a microscopy experiment to test this, which demonstrates that PUF3 is specifically localized to p-bodies.
Microscopy experiment: fluorescence shows that puf3 localizes in P-bodies.
So what regulates the regulators of the P-bodies?
What regulates the p-bodies? What is one level higher up in the hierarchy? A locus on chromosome 14, but this is a large region and covers 30 genes and 300 polymorphisms.
Therefore she came up with the idea of regulatory potential. The motivation is that not all SNPs are equally likely to be causal
how to rank the polymorphisms (SNPs) by their regulatory potential?
Again use the bayesian LASSO
Prior distribution is a Laplacian.
Weight can more easily deviate form 0 and the regulator is more likely to be selected.
Each regulator with its own prior determined by regulatory features of the regulator
it is better to give to each regulator its own prior
Each regulator now has its own probability distribution about how likely it is to diverge from 0.
Metaprior Model (Hierarchical Bayes.
Each regulator has its own prior dictated by the regulatory features (inside a gene? protein coding region? strong conservation? TF binds to module gene?)
Start by learning regulatory programs as described earlier. Second, learn regulatory weights (betas). Then compute the regulatory potential of each SNP in the genome. Then interate
Empirical hierarchical bayes
Regulatory potentials do not change the selection of strong regulators, but helps to disambiguate between multiple weak regulators
Regulatory potentials do not change selection of strong regulators. They only help disambiguate between weak ones.
Strong regulators teach us what to look for in the putative weak regulators
Some important features learned by the algorithm: conservation, cis-regulation.
Important factors: cis-relationship, conservation, stop-codons, (combination of gene functions such as RNA modification, DNA binding, ...)
Statistical evaluation: uses PGV: % of genetic variation explained by the predicted regulatory program for each gene. It's a form of test data validation.
These factors are *learned* from the model, not set
Explained about 50% of the variation in about 50% of the genes
http://dags.stanford.edu/lirnet...
Back to the P-body regulation from a region on chr 14.
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed...
Regulatory potentials are specific to organisms or even datasets.
Understanding the process underlying differentiation with the ImmGen consortium
Can identify shared regulatory programs for all 60 cell types, but lumps together very different cell types
By using G-Regulators, you allow programs to depend on genetic variation, but you don't have G-regulators here, you have cell types
One network for each cell type overfits the data, but can bias towards shared regulation. Use the _ontogeny_ to guide conserved regulation.
Two extremes: lumping every cell type together you "average" effects; working on a single cell type you overfit.
use ontogeny to guide conserved regulation. You do this by looking at differences, and penalize every place you change the regulatory power - penalize changes/divergences in the regulatory
Expression changes and underlying phenotype. What are the mechanism underlying them?
Example: transformation of FL to DLBCL occurs in 40-60% of patients, and diverse mechanisms seem to drive transformation.
DLBCL (Diffuse large B cell lymphoma)
Represent each module as a metagene expression profile, and use machine learning to id modules distinguishing FL-t (pre-transformation) from transformed DLBCL
Represent each module as a metagene, use ML technique to learn classifiers to distinguish FL-t (pre-transformed) from DLBCL
Can you use a module-based approach to understand metabolic syndrome?
pheontype network, where the nodes are modules and the edges are learned regulatory programs.
An important module in this case  is the biosynthesis liver module: the genes are almost disjoint but are all in the same module, therefore you would have missed it without these modules.
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...
Few extra notes at http://www.fiamh.info/article...

body: Special Session 3: Membrane proteins – from biosynthesis to drug design Organizer: Gunnar von Heine

comments.body: Hypothesis for polypeptide translocation by SecY channel (Rapaport group): SecY decides whether or not the polypeptide chain is translocated through the membrane or inserted in the membrane. Two helix finger structure would move the chain to the lipid bilayer using energy from ATP hydrolysis. A conserved tyrosine residue at the tip of the finger is crucial for the translocation.
Erik Lindahl: Calculated the free energy change of insertion for amino acids, compared the scale to the experimental insertion energy scale

Patrick Barth: Modeling membrane protein structures at atomic level (Rosetta-membrane). The use of constraints from known helix - helix structures improves the prediction dramatically. Even one constraint improved the bR structure prediction accuracy from 7.1 A to 3.6A.

body: Global alignment of protein-protein interaction networks

comments.body: we are interested in finding protein functional orthologs
e.g. compute BLAST similarity scores for all pairs and identify reciprocally closest pairs as functional orthologs: RBH (reciprocal blast hit)
may not have any reciprocal hits, leading to ambiguous assignments
if there are more than two proteins in one InParanoid cluster, we need more information to resolve the ambiguities
use protein-protein interactions to align the networks; use to disambiguate orthologs
Bandyopadhyay, Sharan, and Ideker, 2006, used Markov Random Field approach
their contribution: Message Passing Algorithm
Balanced alignment algorithm also is known;
their contribution: Graph Matching Algorithm
message passing is based on forward-backward recursion similar to the Viterbi recursion for HMM
see here for further coverage: http://friendfeed.com/ismbecc...

body: Birds of a Feather session: Beyond microblogging, Wednesday, 1pm  confirmed.

comments.body: Thanks for setting this up, @Roland!

Some thoughts I've had: Pre-annotation of papers and posters prior to the meeting, as is done by David Shotton in "Adventures in Semantic Publishing: Exemplar Semantic Enhancements of a Research Article" at http://dx.doi.org/10... . Don't think it's automated, but you get the idea - and David Shotton gave a talk here this week (http://ff.im/4xwI9) ; and also Reflect (http://ff.im/4yVO1)
Also, how should scientists start with microblogging and social networking? http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...
Let's meet for the 4.15 coffee break at the coffee bar in front of K1, @Allyson and other interested people. If you have ideas, it would be good to prepare them.
sounds good :)
http://ff.im/4BEXJ might also be of interest (Utopia )
I COMPLETELY forgot about the meetup at coffee today! I'm sooo sorry! Was anything decided? Can you put up any summary points that might be of interest tomorrow? My apologies!
@Allyson: Wednesday. It's Tuesday :o)
@Oliver - I missed the pre-BOF meetup today at 4:15 at coffee - see above... :(
Oh. I did not even SEE that comment. Sigh.
No problem, we can meet over nibbles at the reception now. I can tell you what I have in mind.
@Roland - I'm afraid I'm not available this evening. Morning? Or just write your ideas here? I'm a dork - sorry! :)

This should not take long at all, but please leave your ideas here. This is going to be an interactive session anyway, so we don't have to be all that prepared. My slides are more of a moderation prop than a standalone presentation.

I would like to have some meta-discussion: why are we live blogging? How is this useful and how can we make it more useful? Does it mainly benefit those not attending the meeting or is it also useful as an archive of what has been said?
Which room the BoF takes place?

In addition to what Michael Kuhn (@biocs) said, meeting microblogging can also benefit the presenter - giving them valuable feedback. Also links posted to papers, websites, etc. are great, to easily view more info about what someone is/was talking about.
I'll miss this, due to my time difference (Can. west coast) but I look forward to all your thoughts and thank you for setting this BoF up!
@Fiona - we'll make sure to post (maybe microblog!) the BoF :) Thanks for your input - benefits to the presenter is a really good point.

Last year at ISMB, even though I was already on FF I took notes as I habitually do, with calligraphic fountain pen.  During the course of the intervening year I would find myself trying to refer back to those notes while in conversation with others, but had difficulty finding what I wanted in time.

Paradoxically, I perceive myself as being slower when taking notes electronically than by hand (I think I tend to spend more time formulating them).  But since we're doing this cooperatively, if one of us doesn't catch something another will.  The notes will be searchable any time on the web; I won't have to dig up a particular file on a particular computer.  The same effort provides the same resource for others.
I did revert to the fountain pen at various points this year though!  It's more reliable than depending on the availability of power, wireless, and FriendFeed.
@Peter - the ISMB website tells me we will be in C8 for this session

The BioSysBio 2009 conference report (http://genomebiology.com/2009...) just came out (disclaimer, I'm an author). Simon Cockell had a wordle used (http://www.flickr.com/photos...), and FF and Twitter get a mention, if a short one: "A new feature for BioSysBio 2009 to extend participation in the conference was to a wider audience by communicating live content through microblogging (using FriendFeed and Twitter; Figure 1) and live blogging (providing an immediate and permanent log)."
Roland, where is the BoF going to be?
The location is still given as C8.
Set up an Etherpad for collaborative note taking: http://etherpad.com/EOOgB1Y27Z
I will be there from 12:40 onwards, if you have left suggestions here, please be there a little earlier for a quick roundup.
Getting started. Mini-overview of past/current/future
Disclaimer for presentations -- what is allowed and what isn't (mail, blogging, film...)
Reference to Cameron Neylon's logos for presenters: http://blog.openwetware.org/science...
A need to make presenters aware of what might be distributed how
Reference to CSHL and recent "controversy": http://scienceblogs.com/genetic...
Conference blogging ideas from nature: http://www.nature.com/news...
Brief discussion of CSHL controversy
Journalists and bloggers should abide by the same rules at a conference - whatever those rules are
Classical blog posts, twitter and friendfeed: surprising how effective friendfeed is given it's basic nature
Find it quite difficult to make sense out of Twitter (best - wordle aka Simon Cockell?)
Oliver says FF isn't perfect, but it does have a very low barrier to access and start using
Where do personal opinions come into it? In general at ISMB we are all being polite. What level is acceptable?
Roland: the discussion culture in science has changed a litle. He read that 50 years ago they were having much more open discussions

Maybe people might be away from the conference and following remotely, or at the conference and shy - such people could pose questions on friendfeed, and then chair (who is monitoring FF) could ask them at the end of the talk
Differences to last year: increased depth of coverage (due to ISCB support, raised awareness?)
We all thanked the organisers from this year
ISMB people (Reinhard?) will do some basic stats of the coverage of this conference
Many of us bloggers feel that the first to benefit are ourselves
First person to benefit from blogging: the blogger
Live blogging especially useful for keynotes - for recording the presenter's thoughts.. and not always an accompanying paper available.. ?
Andrew: heavily blogged talks are more useful for external people than delegates
liveblogging is complementary to webcast etc as it takes less time - if you like the liveblogging and the blog posts after scanning, then you go and look at webcast
Also, people liveblogging tends to pick out the key points quickly
webcasting also has many time and technical issues
oliver: Perhaps much of the commenting is too sober. Not enough meta-information, e.g. "here is X's main competitor's paper..."
it would be nice to have more background - yes
Roland: can you have two streams - one light, one serious. Allyson: but it would be difficult in practice, if you have to look at two different things
Three levels: factual information/transcript. notes to self, public commentary / context
Feeds are important feedback for the presenter ?
technical issues: there can be issues with internet / wireless
(Like right now?)
@Oliver - yep! Back now, though :)
Should we have TLAs or abbrevs to indicate personal comments or uncertainty? Maybe not TLAs (makes barrier for newbies) - how about single symbol at the beginning, e.g. '#' for personal comments

We should write up a boilerplate: what it means to liveblog; if you don't want it, then... (e.g. logo from Cameron) ;why scientists should liveblog; *suggest* that your FF account should link to something that identifies you; you might want to consider only posting things that you would be happy saying to people's face.
no legislation, though - don't want to force people to do anything
ISMB will certainly do it next year
imho: Official Facebook group etc. should be more advertised..
@Peter - I agree - the embedded FF threads within the ISMB site were advertised, but more should have been made of them - it's quite cool to see!
Some great points made here - thank you!
see here for the Google Doc to make a write-up out of this discussion: http://docs.google.com/Doc...

body: Keynote: Thomas Lengauer - Chasing the AIDS Virus

comments.body: Background in mathematics and Computer Science
protein bioinformatics, computational drug screening and design
previously full prof at U. Paderborn
on steering board of ECCB since its founding
an exciting story, downstream of the bulk of computational biology in the medical field
process flow usually ends with finding and optimizing potential drug targets
Start when the drugs are available on the marketplace and they support personalized medicine, and which drugs to give to AIDS patients.
Personalized medicine, they start when the drugs are in the market place
in this case, support difficult decision of a doctor: what drug to give to the AIDS patient
33m HIV infected patients in 2007
25 M deaths since 1981
greatly affected in Africa
Aids awareness is waning
Europe appears little affected, but this may be deceptive
...and increasing infection rate nowadays
AIDS awareness campaigns have waned in recent years, and as a consequence there is an increase in infection rates again.
At least in Germany, AIDS awareness is reducing
'AIDS almost a lost cause' (no way it is under control currently)
AIDS is rampant and almost a lost cause.  AIDS is nowhere near under control.
small molecule: 10000 letters
HIV virus: small genome (10k bases)
double single-strand RNA genome
virus attaches via surface proteins to the T-cell
HIV has a duplicated single-stranded RNA genome
transferred into nucleus via viral protein called integrase
no way to get the virus out of an infected cell
It's not possible to remove the virus from the infected cell.
viral particles assemble in a complex process, not completely understood
during maturation process, strings of proteins are cut into their functional parts
viral protein protease makes virus effective at infecting a new cell
AIDS virus is by far the best understood of all viruses
Drug design starts with understanding the life cycle. Best understood virus.
life cycle of HIV is already understood very well
HIV is the best understood virus
Various drugs blocking different phases of the virus infection.
There are a number of drugs that blocks the fusion of the virus with the cell, 17 blocking reverse transcriptase, etc.
17 drugs blocking transcription
one new drug blocks attachments of virus to cell; another blocks fusion; 17 drugs block reverse transcription; 1 drug blocks integration; 8 block maturation
will explain why just one drug doesn't suffice
HIV is extremely dynamically evolving, possibly the most dynamically evolving virus known
moving target: over 10 million virus particles turned over per day per patient
A drug may be efficient against the wild type, but not against mutants.
wild type viruses are most fit under natural condition; drug will be very effective on wild type but will very quickly select for resistance
Always going to be minority variants resistant to the drug which will escape drug treatment
reverse transcriptase is a bad copier, enabling variation every time the virus replicates
There is no drug targeting all mutants.
Hence drug cocktails that catch all variants. Doesn't work, best we can do is postpone the onset
therefore need drug cocktail that catches all of them, but this is utopia and doesn't happen; there is no drug therapy that works forever
The virus always wins, we can only postpone the loss
HAART: highly active anti-retroviral therapy; administer at least two drugs of different classes (targetting different proteins, working in different ways)
number of viral RNA in the blood is a major clinical indicator
therapy is effective for some time, until new strain develops that is resistant
50 copies is the current limit of detection for blood tests (unclear per what?)
Detection limit: 50 copies of the virus.
this is the main question in treating patients, and is very difficult
so far only viral genome, not host genome, is being considered
people have built mutation tables: synopsis of global clinical experience of how virus responds to treatment
Mutation tables: collection of responses of the virus to various treatments.
In the past, they've built mutation tables - global collection of clinical experience
e.g., protease inhibitors
Gotta love the overlap in comments! :)
Allyson: heh
@Allyson: too many bloggers here ;-)
An expert group will build this table.
(I am now waiting before posting.. only to see everyone else waiting, too... gah)
Mutation table created by a group of experts, after heated discussions
a particular SNP suggests that the virus is resistant to Atanovir
I say just go with the flow and just get some overlap - it's good!
Allyson: knowledge of the crowd.. :-)
can't collect a lot of data: if have seen resistance, don't want to subject future patients to this therapy
@Peter - definitely!
but if there are too many mutations in the table, won't be able to administer therapy to any patient--every patient will have some of these
Tables limited because mutations are not acting independently.
mutation tables carry not enough information..
-> expert systems ?
interdependencies cannot be captured by mutation tables; need rule-based expert systems
Mutations act in the context of the remaining genome (and the host genome)
Mutation table ignores the context of mutations and synergies
unfortunately, the medical community calls these "algorithms"

virologists ask: "Is this kind of resistance analysis objective?" "Can we not let the clinical data speak for themselves?" i.e., circumvent political process of decisionmaking of what goes in the tables
Started by building a clinical database.
Then the comp biol at his group enter, by request from MDs, into the picture
at the start, no clinical database existed
Avoiding community decisions by querying clinical databases.. which did not exist at the beginning of the project
phenotypic data: extract patient's virus and expose it to drugs
phenotypic data: expose the virus to different drug concentrations in cell culture
observe fitness of resistant vs wild type curve of how much drug needed to suppress replication
measure the "resistence factor": how much more drug is necessary to keep a mutant under control as the wild type
One value: drug increase required to overcome mutation effect
quantify as "resistance factor"
map viruses to drug concentrations that are effective
only a few labs can do this kind of analysis
but this data is too expensive and too slow to make for clinicians
people have resorted to viral genome, as sequencing the viral genome is easy and fast
bioinformatic resistance analysis can replace phenotypic lab test
now: sequencing individual virus' genomes
Multivariate statistical learning approaches
multivariate statistical learning on db of genotype-phenotype pairs
Training on a genotype-phenotype pairs database (1000+ HIV variants).
The training data is the genotype-phenotype pairs of 1000+ HIV variants
"Every HI virus is ugly"
want statistical model that will either regress or classify
quality criteria: predictive power, interpretability
A statistical model that regresses or classifies. Statistical power is not the only factor, results need to be interpretable
doctors in the field want interpretable models, and will sacrifice a few % accuracy for this
regression: estimate resistance factor
Clinicians require interpretable models, why they make the predictions they do
Classification into two classes: susceptible or not.
classification based on cutoff values
interpretable model is a decision tree
Decision tree classifier: tease out interdependence between different mutations
along branches of decision tree, query different amino acid positions
Decision tree encoding the ammino acids conferring resistance.
Beerenwinkiel et al. PNAS 2002 99 (12) 8271-6
much more informative than mutation tables.
virus can be resensitized by multiple mutations
Allows to find re-sensitization (sp?) effects
one decision tree for each drug
Web tool: www.geno2pheno.org
http://www.geno2pheno.org, so far most used clinical tool by them
one particular patient was a difficult case, convinced doctors that this tool has some use
Genotype is aligned to the wt and mutations are identified
Identifies genome variations (alignment to the wild type)
on server, using regression with linear SVMs, not classification with decision trees
now uses SVMs instead of decision tree
List of drugs by estimated effect (based on SVM).
gives estimated resistance factor
Using linear SVM for regression: a line for each drug and have est resistance factor, and normalization with Z-score, and the scored mutations.
use z-scores, as absolute values of resistance factors are not comparable btw drugs
Each drug with an estimates resistance factor, Z-score (for comparative purposes) and a list of scored mutations based on their weight
this difficult patient is full of mutations, has resistance to every known drug per the mutation table
"out-therapy" - doctors say positively they can't  help him any more
but they saw that some of these mutations actually resensitize!

Some mutations, which confer resistance to some things (e.g. 76V in the anecdotal example) actual confers re-sensitisation and therefore would have a positive effect. Couldn't have been done with mutation tables!
Give one drug to retain re-sensitation mutation, add second drug to exploit the re-sensitation effect
one mutation conferring resistance to two drugs, resensitized the virus to other two drugs
this could not have been found via the mutation table; the patient was on the recommended therapy from March 2003 until April 2009 and blood was clear of virus
natural next question: predict in what direction the virus will evolve under a given drug therapy
Now: model the viral evolution
Next question is: how the virus will evolve in reaction to a certain drug?
not possible by mutation table
hacking viral evolution neat. :)
The virus does not change randomly; it follows specific mutational paths.
The virus "chooses" mutation paths, do not know why
simulated by fair mutations, but the virus does not mutate by flipping a fair coin, it chooses useful mutations (!) don't know how it does that
virus follows specific mutational paths into resistance
('chooses' is probably not the right word for this :) )
want to find such paths in the database
Oliver: hopefully not, it's very strange
What are the preferred directions the virus goes?
Not enough data to make accurate models.
Longitudinal data missing
would like longitudinal data, but have cross-sectional data: lots of patients, but few data points on each one
used to build mutagenetic trees
Viral evolution is modeled using tree structures.
the TAM1 path is found by seeing the virus does *not* follow every possible path
mutagenetic trees with probabilities on branches
method derives mixtures of mutagenetic trees, not single ones
22% of data follow one tree, 78% another
can make time models, to estimate average time until a mutation is acquired
predict length of tunnel created for the virus by drug therapy, on its path to resistance
Estimate probability that a virus will acquire a certain resistance within a given time
applet predicts which therapy appears most promising
Can try to maximize that duration
Now: Algorithm calculates success probabilities for a certain therapy suggested by the software
Do they actually follow the other tree? Could they be transitioning through the other mutations faster than you are sampling?
therapy optimization with THEO
this strange sampling of effective paths reminds me of quantum computing
Doctors still do not trust computers to the very end. Good!
EuResist: Europe-wide collection of resistance data
Rosen-Zvi, Altmann et al BIoinformatics, 2008
server akin to geno2pheno on the internet; ROC curves show it has better performance than expert systems
Most 'fun' consortium he's been involved in (would love to know the criteria for that :) )
so does THEO
http://www.euresist.org/
German database of ineffective therapies (thanks to honesty of doctors)
without THEO, chance of failure is >24%, without <10%
Error in therapy classification: 24% without THO, below 15% with it.
geno2pheno accessed from 30 countries
2/3 AIDS patients in Germany treated with geno2pheno server
also need to keep finding new drugs
Constant need new drugs as the virus _will_ evolve with time towards resistance
one target: the viral entry
the cell cooperates in drawing the virus in
nice movie showing HIV infection of the cell. Wish I could link that
CD4 receptor and coreceptor on human cell; first GP120 attaches to CD4, then to coreceptor
then virus drills down and the particles fuse
so coreceptor protein will be the target; there is one drug targeting this, from Pfizer, Maroviroc (sp?)
some people cannot be infected.
1% of Caucasian population does not have this coreceptor, and cannot be infected with HIV
1% of caucasians do not have the coreceptor
Close enough: http://www.scienceinreview.com/2007...
some viral variants can use a different coreceptor (CCR5 vs CXCR4)
once you're in therapy the virus can switch
people with the CCR5 deletion don't get AIDS, so the virus first goes through here, but it later switches to the other one
@Oliver, thanks for the link
have duotropic strain; need genotypic assay
have genotypic prediction of viral tropism; this server has the most hits
the lab is in San Francisco; German doctors don't want to send samples all the way there and are incented to use the genotypic test
35 amino acids in V3 loop; used to look at residues 11 and 25, but multivariate server does much better
supply method with structural descriptor of the V3 loop, and use it in the predictor, which increases the sensitivity
results shown were toy, based on clonal data - lab sample of *single* virus strain
Viral sequences are ambiguous in numerous positions.
in patient have several strains, so ambiguous base calls; in practice, these are "bulk data" and greatly reduce sensitivity
therefore add clinical correlates such as virus load, CD4 load, etc. that are easily drawn from patient
Add extra information -- clinical parameters -- to increase sensitivity
still phenotypic test gives much more accurate result, so clinical value is contested
Sensitivity goes from 80% to 40% if you move from clonal to bulk data.
study shows that in clinical picture, no difference btw genotypic and phenotypic test
still not satisfying, so want to increase accuracy
go away from sanger sequencing to increase accuracy
move away from Sanger sequencing; if virus occurs in only 10%, won't even see it
therefore use deep sequencing
Sanger sequencing can now be replaced by deep sequencing, solving ambiguities.
need to assemble 454 reads
coreceptor of 35 aa can be resolved by single read
ultra-deep sequencing for getting sequence information for the whole quasi species
Up to 130k sequences (reads?) from a single drop of blood
elbow shaped curve in one case, less of one coreceptor type => drug against coreceptor likely to be effective
need to establish cutoffs; with prediction specificity of 90%, size of X4 minority must exceed 5%; call this R5 and use the drug
o/w, call it X4, drug will be ineffective
but need to choose parameter values
There might be better descriptors, but establishing these in the community is going to be difficult
Zero delay between results and bedside application (unlike traditional drug development with lead times of 10+ years)
Niko Beerenwinkel worked on haplotype prediction, now at ETH Zürich
this is not just academic software, need this to be highly available, not just dependent on grad students
Rolf Kaiser, w/o exposure to computers, conceived of this project; thankful for his vision
formed society for furthering the software, stable under various losses of funding
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...
(only to get the blog on top of the ISCB portal site)

body: PT47: Oliver Stegle - Predicting and Understanding the Stability of G-Quadruplexes

comments.body: G-Quadruplexes are stable structures of RNA and DNA
Typically of the from GGGACTAAGGGACTTCCCACTTGG
Will form spontaneously, have role in transcriptional control and telomeres.
Are these patterns really stable? It's the first indicator of a functional role. Melting temp will be a proxy for stability
Overrepresented in promoter regions [Hupper and Balasumbramanian, 2007]
Melting temperature can be predicted and experimentally verified. It's low throughput though, rules are limited, complicated non-linear relationships.
Gaussian processes (GP) regression with different error rates across the sequence.
Gives the posterior distribution of function values given a training set.
Needs a covariance function (kernel), a likelihood model and hyperparameters.
Product ansatz to construct a joint covariance function of concentration and sequence.
Uses common k-mer substrings.
Use the squared distance of the sequence features such as composition, length of spacers etc.
these structures are so stable sometimes they never melt.
Training data is noisy with outliers, sometimes only gives a bound.
Non-Gaussian likelihood model is robust, incorporates observations as bounds.
Hyperparameters estimated either  with MAP or MCMC sampling.
they look at 260 quadruplexes (one of the first data sets available for quadruplexes)
Dataset with 260 G-quadruplexes, compared to SVMs and GPs.
GPs outperform SVMs in mean squared error and mean log probability.
Gives confidence in the prediction.
With a 50/50 training split, the predictions (with the error bars) always overlap with the "truth" line, sometimes with a large uncertainty. Everything is predicted within 10 degrees C.
The relevance of the features for the hyperparameters can be shown, one of the length parameters is most important.
Genome-wide GQ prediction in human identifies 359,548 candidate sequences.
60% is in the 10° Tm range (which is pretty good).
Are they functional and in promoter regions?
Quadruplexes are overrepresented in the promoter regions by order of magnitude than anywhere else
Weak hint, may not to be expected much more from only 260 examples.
Just about significant.
Future work includes further biological validation.
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009... (Interesting talk - some of it was a little over my head though!)
My question: Are GQs connected to high-GC promoters? A. Only further validation will tell.

body: HL49: Andrei Zinovyev - Robust simplifications of multiscale biochemical networks

comments.body: model reduction: simplify models in order to understand
e.g., "Consider a spherical cow..." A farmer hires a physicist to help with milk production, who takes  half a year to produce a paper beginning thusly.
complexity of data and complexity of models: non-identifiable models still have robust properties
See e.g. Chen et al, Molecular Systems Biology 5:239, 2009
given only the order relations between the model parameters, can we provide robust first and second order solutions?
biological systems are hierarchical and multiscale (an observation, not a theorem)
structure: functional modules, motifs; scales: time scales, concentratio scales
this makes it possible to neglect small quantities in favor of larger ones, given proper theory
aymptotic approximations in chemical kinetics: quasi-equilibrium (fast reactions), quasi-steady state, ..., quasistationary
enzymatic catalysis in quasiequilibrium vs quasistationary approximations gives very different results
rate limiting step: steady state rate is determined by slowest reaction in the chain
what is the equivalent for a complex network?
dominant dynamical system (DDS): auxiliary minimal dynamical system which gives the main asymptotic terms of the stationary state and relaxation in terms of well separated time scales
not unique
monomolecular networks with time separation can be solved without exact knowledge of kinetic rates
Theorem: for such systems, the eigenvalues have only -1, 0, 1 values.  These are determined only by the network topology and the order of the parameters.
DDS for linear networks: cycle gluing; cut into cycles and contract until have noncyclic system, then solve that
what about non-linear systems with non-monomolecular reacionts?
if one concentration changes much more slowly, treat it as a parameter
1) identify linear or pseudo-linear subsystems; 2) neglect small quantities (use idempotent algebra)
model reduction preserves dynamics; need to identify critical and non-critical model parameters
characteristic functions are ratios of monomials in the initial parameters
http://www.biomedcentral.com/1752-05...

body: HL48: Israel Steinfeld - Architecture of CpG methylation in the human genome

comments.body: DNA methylation: modification of cytosines in CpG dinucleotides, maintained across cell divisions
CG dinucleotide content in HG: 1%, expected: 4.5%
CpG islands: regions on DNA that contain many CpGs. 28000 islands annotated in HG. almost all of them are near gene promoters
mDIP: methyl-DNA immunoprecipitation assay, similar to ChIP-chip. 244k DNA methylation array
array methylation score (IMS): average signal for all probes mapped to it. bimodal distribution. house keeping genes are methylated (ie, on one side of the distribution)
approx  15 samples (different tissues). almost all are not methylated (~70%)
Nature: Sp1 elements protect a CpG island from de novo methylation, Michael Brandeis et al, Nature 371, September 1994
DRIM Discovering Rank Imbalanced Motifs: http://bioinfo.cs.technion.ac.il/drim
use machine learning to distinguish between methyl. and nonmethyl. islands.
UMR: undermethylated region (?)
designed a new tiling array that covers all predicted UMRs

conclusions: 4400 predicted regions were confirmed as UMRs. 923 of the UMRs are placed near known TSS. no one-to-one correspondence between CpG islands and nonmethylated regions. also: yes, there is tissue-specific methylation (didn't go into detail)

body: TT42: Karim Chine - Computational Biology in the cloud, towards a federative and collaborative R-based platform

comments.body: Eamonn Maguire talking on behalf of Karim Chine
Java program (web app or web start app) built on R and Scilab
Biocep-R
RESTful API.
Website: http://biocep-distrib.r-forge.r-project.org/
BIOCEP-R has advanced graphics - more than with regular R
Built on top of R and Scilab
wow - their software is an "ecosystem" :)
Computational scripts: R / Python / Groovy
The BIOCEP computational open platform ecosystem: computational data sources, resources, components, GUIs, web services and scripts
Data storage: local, NFS, FTP, S3
Components such as R, Bioconductor; GUIs with collaborative views; Scripting (R/Python/Ruby); stateless web services; NFS/FTP/S3 storage; cluster/grid support
The R Virtualization is like a mini-desktop.
Server side spreadsheet sync'd on all clients.
Visual GUI builder in Netbeans.
Creation of EC2 workers on demand. Supports multiple worker pools.
Biocep can automatically add workers on the cloud on demand given a certain load
Demo
Uses Amazon Elastic Cloud (Is that right?)
A bit of free ads for AWS...
Looks like the kind of tools needed to get people to utilize the cloud...
Showing us the R console and some simple operations
FYI: AWS are giving grants for use of their services: http://aws.amazon.com/educati...
The web services part means you can use BIOCEP to connect to a cloud instance.
(It's actually an incredible wrapper / workbench to tie together all kinds of different tools and algorithms)
Showing client - server interactions on a single machine. The automatically synchronized spreadsheet.
Go find Eamonn if you have any questions!
http://www.biocep.net
Looks very promising.. I especially liked the easy selection of spreadsheet cells and using them in the virtual R workbench.

body: PT45: Hamid Reza Chitsaz - A Partition Function Algorithm for Interacting Nucleic Acid Strands

comments.body: First part presented by Raheleh Salari
Increased interest in RNA-RNA interaction prediction requires computational target prediction.
ncRNAs bind to mRNA and regulate translation, including the specificity etc.
Several models have been described, e.g. PairFold, RNAhybrid, RNAup, IRIS, InteRNA.
Problem np-complete
All current approaches do not include the probability and stability of the joint secondary structure.
Interaction energy model and interaction partition function over all SS without pseudoknots or crossing interactions and zigzags.
The standard model by Matthews et al (1999) assumes an energy model with independence between hairpins, bulges etc.
More than one loop-loop interaction in a real example, ignore interhybrid loop, other loops termed kissing loops.
# that was a little fast
A kissing loop is intramolecular loop that makes interaction with the other strand.
Give the energy functions for the new structures for the interaction partition function.
Second part given now by Hamid Chitsaz
Main interest in the strength and stability of the RNA interaction, which is challenging because all structures must be accounted for exactly once.
Make use of a dynamic programming approach using divide and conquer. Compute the partition function for bits of the structure.
McCaskill's algorithm (1990) is introduced, describing a participation function for single strands.
For two unpaired strands, McCaskill's algorithm can be used directly,
98 cases need to be considered, not even in the paper but in the suppl. mat.
# sounds like a complicated model, it's not completely presented
Explanation for the no-zig zag assumption motivated by less running time, one arch describes them all.
Can predict the equilibrium concentaion, the melting temperature and the UV absorption.
Presented algorithm (piRNA) outperforms existing ones by an order of magnitude, experimental validation with Tm shows little deviation.
Algorithm is available.

body: PT43: Tobias Marschall - Efficient Exact Motif Discovery

comments.body: Unsupervised motif discovery on a string with no previous knowledege in an automated fashion.
issues: How to measure over-representation and how to find them.
184 publications in pubmed for "motif discovery algorithm"
aim to establish an (almost) exact method based on a rigorous motif statistics
given: query text, IUPAC motifs, random text model (background) - for now, iid
Calculating a p-value of a given query text, a IUPAC motif and a random text model.
want: a p-value for a motif
use a novel device called probabilistic arithmetic automata  - won't go into details
Need to compute the distribution of occurrences by chance. Not a straight forward task, recently proposed a new approach by building a probabilistic arithmetic automata.
an exact calculation
The problem is that computing p-values is infeasible due to large number of motifs.
matches occur in clumps. use compound possion approximation (almost exact) to calculate exact distribution of clump sizes. approximate number of clumps by Poisson distribution
Use of a Compound Poisson Approximation on a set of clumps (sets of overlapping motifs)
clump = overlapping occurences
The clump size can be used the probabilistic atutomata.
nice: clumP SIze is abbreviated with an uppercase psi
How to bound the p-value to prune the search space?
p-value: the probability of observing >k occurences (when found k in the real data)
bound no. of occurences using the no. of clumps
Motifs with the same composition have the same expectation.
iterate over all possible compositions, not over the motifs themselves to take advantage of the same expectation
but iid model for DNA isn't very appropriate
Use of a suffix tree of the sequence, iterate over the motifs, use the lower bound for pruning, walk the tree and identify overrepresented motifs.
so re-evaluate the motifs producing a good p-value with iid on a Markovian text model
designing a good benchmark set is hard
other tools: Weeder, MEME
Benchmark sets are not easy, used a set by Sandve et al. http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/article...
Outperforms Weeder and MEME at the cost of higher running time of ~12 hours.
algorithm is not as fast as the other tools. is easily parallelizable
with a 4.4 Mbp genome of M.tuberculosis, found motifs in ~250 CPU hrs in a parallelized setting
best motif: AGACSCARAA (or sth like that), found in literature
computationally demanding, but possible with modern computers
List of models, the first is described, others are under investigation.
in the future: use modern hardware (eg GPUs)
optimise wrt Markovian models directly (rather than iid)
Future work could incorporate Markovian models directly or use phylogenetic information.
Q. Is the implementation available? A: Given in the paper.
question: is the tool available? yes, URL in the paper
you have to take into account overlapping motifs for doing proper statistics
Q. Are the data in Jasper or Transfac? A. Had an expert looking at it.
# Jasper and Transfac do not really cover Mycobacterium motifs
Q: Performance of the algorithm on short motifs. A. Length 10 is the upper bound for the algorithm which is quite dependent on the length.
Q: applying to protein models? A: problematic because alphabet is larger and indels would need to be modelled

Q: how is the iid text model? how do you justify that the text fulfills the model? A: the iid model is estimated from the text. dependencies between characters are incorporated by using the Markovian model
Q. (Marcel Schulz) Differences in Markov models of different orders. A. Shorter orders give spurious results.
Q: why only a part of the motif space? A: tried to come up with a plausible set that includes most motifs

body: HL44: Luis de Figueiredo - Benchmarking tools in Metabolic Pathway Analysis

comments.body: how to represent a metabolic system?  it's a thermodynamically open system, we need to draw a boundary around it
we approximate that the system reaches a steady state
certain metabolites form a pooll and are removed from the representation of the steady state
Metabolic system can be represented as stoichiometric matrix
get the stoichiometric matrix; the solution set is a polyhedral convex cone.  similarly if using other constrained representations
Elementary Flux Mode: minimal set of enzymes that can operate at steady state
See also here: http://ff.im/4vaOK
1st bench mark system - conversion of fatty acids to carbohydrate
how to convert fatty acids to carbohydrate?  Weinman et al 1957 showed a certain pathway is not possible
model used by Weinman et al in 1957
Conversion of AcCoa into G6P - Humans
use EFMs to show how conversion can take place
2nd model ....explain ... Nucleotide metabolism in human red blood cells  .
nucleotide metabolism i human red blood cells, lose nucleotides to hypoxanthane.  Is this loss reversible?
de Figueiredo et al (2009) Bioinformatics
have 3 metabolic models relevant in biochemistry that can be used for benchmarking metabolic pathway analysis tools
find EFMs of interest, K-shortest EFMs; again, see http://ff.im/4vaOK
tools that just treat the pathways as a graph are only the first step, but are missing the chemical information
this is not the same as Petri nets

body: PT41: Shai Lubliner - Modeling Interactions between Adjacent Nucleosomes Improves Genome-wide Predictions of Nucleosome Occupancy

comments.body: Nucleosome position affects transcriptional regulation, models for position are required for understanding of TR.
75-90% of the DNA is associated with nucleosomes, play an important regulatory role.
Use a recently published model to produce the affinity landscape, showing the suitability of nucleosome occupancy.
Genomic nuceosome affinity landscape based on a thermodynamical model
The model is probably published here (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed...)
Can interactions between nucleosomes introduced into the model?
Two kinds of interactions: direct or bridged by transcription factors or other proteins.
Additional interactions are important for chromatin organization. DNA bending proteins, TF, histone modifications, etc.
First approach focuses on direct interaction, including the distance between the nucleosomes.
Trying to capture interactions between adjacent nucleosomes (cooperative effects)
What types of functions can represent cooperativity types?
Notable features include a right shifted main peak, followed by exponential decay.
Tested Exponential, Stepped Exp, S-ES, Stepping-Off and Stepping-On
Sampled 5000 configurations and compared it to the linker length preference.
Can the model properly learned?
Repeat with data samples, add noise and try to fit different models to the sampled occupancy landscape
Used synthetic data, including experimental noise, then forgot the algorithm to generate the data and used the previously described models.
Exponential function shows a good correlation in five-fold cross-validation, with the model incorporating the interaction outperforming the ones without.
Are the interactions relevant in vivo and in vitro?
For an in vitro validation the Exp, Step functions work better than the no cooperativity model
Short linker lengths are favored.
Interactions are also important using in vivo data, data from several chromosomes and different organisms (yeast and C. elegans) show similar results.
The interesting part -- biological basis for this preference?
The in vitro system consists of nucleosomes and DNA only.
shorter length may allow for interaction of nucleosomes, energetically favoring their shift from otherwise better binding positions
Hypothesis: electrostatic interaction between nucleosomes, which has been described previously but not shown in the data.
# Surprised that the very model was not presented in the talk.
# Wonder whether there is a difference between promoters, other nucleosome covered regions (or other genomic subsets); with the role nucleosome displacement plays in regulation I'd expect some shift
Blog notes: http://www.fiamh.info/article...

Q: When you started motivating the model, there was a peak at 10 but the sample data did not have that.[?] A: These are effects of histone H1, which are not modeled. There are a lot of question marks about the role of H1 in yeast.  The interaction that we modeled are global and can occur anywhere on the DNA. More complex model would incorporate additional local effects, e.g. other factors.

Q. Have you finished the model for the higher eukaryotes: A The model is independent of the organism. There might be differences, although this is debated. Differnces between yeast and human are known.

body: HL42: Curtis Huttenhower - Exploring the human genome with functional maps

comments.body: HEFalMp: data integration for human genomic data.
Integration of genomic data and prior knowledge using bayesian integration.
Each resulting network is based on a specific functional context.
Input data is huge: 10,000s of experiments, billions of data points.
But also very sparse.
Our prior knowledge comes from GeneOntology
Human case sources: genomic data (interactions, microarrays, sequences); prior knowledge (229 biological processes from GO and KEGG).
There is so much information about humans that the independence assumption at the base of naive bayesian classification is violated. Used mutual information for regularization.
start with predicted gene or gene product interaction network
Functional mapping methodology. Start from gene interaction network.
each edge is an integration of hundreds of datasets, going from low to high confidence
Average strengh of relationships defines associations.
take subnetworks associated with one process and another, use strengths of edges to quantify how related the two processes are
Four measures of functional associations between two gene sets: edges between genes; edges within each set; background edges incident to each set; all edges in the network.
any tow sets of genes  4 measures 1. edges between their genes 2. edges within each set,  3. the background edges incident to each set 4. the baseline of all edges in the network

any sets of genes G1 and G2 can be compared 4 ways: 1. edges between their genes, 2. edges within each set (e.g., BRCA is well-studied, so easy to get high confidence; want to normalize this out). 3. the background edges incident to each set, and 4. the baseline of all edges in the network (i.e., the baseline of the average confidence will vary from place to place within the network)
Such measures are combined into a single score.
normalize wrt the background, like TFIDF
get bootstrap p-values wrt the null hypothesis: random gene sets
null distribution is approximately normal with mean 1
P-value bootstrapping: null distribution approximately normal.
this lets us convert a Functional Association score into a p-value
massive data sets and genomes requires efficient algorithms and implementations.
C++ library for computational functional genomics (open source, fully documented). http://imperio.princeton.edu/sleipni...
http://www.huttenhower.org to apply for postdocs
Efficient computation for biological discovery
also includes parallelization; massively speeds up
HEFalMp: predicting human gene function
HEFalMp Predicting human gene functions
see many predictions, zooming in allows to view the specific data from which the prediction is derived
to understand human diseases
Validation: autophagy.
have validated human predictions; missed one for tissue specific
have interactive interface to the data, using Grapple
current work more species and more interactions
Website: http://function.princeton.edu/hefalmp
need postdocs
# Can only recommend working with and for Curtis :)

body: HL41: Roland Dunbrack - Comparative analysis of crystal interfaces of homologous proteins

comments.body: two papers: Xu JMB 381, 487-507 2008: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed... , missed 2nd one
homooligomers: 45-60% of all proteins in the PDB are homolooligomers
is a protein an oligomer in solution?
can determine using gel filtration, analytical ultracentrification, cross-linking + SDS-PAGE
sources of information: PDB/PQS/PISA
need to distinguish between asymmetric  and biological units
Xu, Canutescu, Dunbrack, Bioinformatics, 2006: look at overlap of the 3 info sources
66% total intersection
see different annotations for the same protein family
shows an example where a dimer is formed by a small interface, the biounit dbs often don't get this correct
look for crystal forms for each family; look at interfaces for each crystal form (building cube out of 3x3x3 unit cells)
look at common interfaces in multiple crystal forms and calculate backbone structure overlap (# of matching residues)
observation: different space groups will sometimes have nearly the same crystal form
e.g. 1yak and 1yaf
176 families, 3139 entries with interfaces in N/N crystal forms (N >= 4)
try to see which interfaces are correct
benchmarking: check performance of the 3 data sources using reference set
get false positives, try to estimate how many crystal forms do you need to identify false positives
small distortion of the interface is enough to make a monomer out of a dimer

body: HL40: Gary Hon - Histone modifications at human enhancers reflect global cell-type-specific gene expression

comments.body: Different cells are different because they express different genes.
Gene expression profiles from microarray studies can be used to identify cell types
Regulation of transcription still not really understood. Coding regions are well studied, but most of the genome is non-coding. Presumably these regions contain regulatory elements.
Some regulatory elements are known. Promoters, Enhancers, Insulators.
Enhancers are the least understood elements in transcriptional regulation.
How to find enhancers genome wide?
Enhancers can be found by: sequence elements (>2500 TF motifs).
sequence based searches? >2500 transcription factor motifs...
can look at motifs, but they are highly degenerate
But such motives are short and highly degenerate.
still need to look at in vivo data, since enhancers are often tissue-specific
look at the "epigenetic code": histone modifications
Chromatin modifications have been associated with activation and repression.
previous studies: chromatin signatures of promoters
Histon modifications do mark enhancers?
ChIP-chip
are there signatures of enhancers that are specific to their function?
Previous study: Schubeler, Nature Genetics, 2007.
use chip-chip data, focus on ENCODE regions - 1% of the human genome
(Schübeler Nat Gen 2007)
H3K4me1 high at enhancers but not promoters. H3K4me3 is high at promoters but not enhancers
Study of histone modification for 414 promoters.
ChIP-chipped 5 cell lines for K4Me1, K4Me3, K27ac
Epigenetic dynamics of promoters, insulators and enhancers? How do they change between cell types? Which play biggest roll in determining cell type differences?
CTCF insulator binding sites are invariant between cell types
chromatin signatures at promoters and insulators (CTCF-bound regions) are invariant
in general, enhancer histone modifications are cell-type specific
while the profiles at enhancers are tissue-type specific
Using this signature, prediction of 36589 enhancers genome-wide.
moved to genome-wide analysis of H3K4me and H3K27ac + DNA I hypersensitivity and co-activators p300 and MED1 - predicted a large number of enhancers
Validation: recovery of well-studied enhancers.
7/9 of cloned predicted enhancers showed activity
Found many motifs specifically enriched in enhancers
Enhancers are enriched near HeLa-specific genes.
enhancers are enriched at cell-type-specific genes
(HeLa vs K562)
is the same true in "real" cells (as opposed to immortalized cell lines)
look at ES cells vs a mixture of ES-derived differentiated cells (on treatment with BMP4)
H3k27ac is also a mark of enhancer activity
H3K4me3, H3K27me3 depleted at enhancers H3K4me1 and H3K27ac are enriched
poised enhancers contain only H3K4me1 and gain H3K27ac on activation
Conservation only slightly above random for found enhancers

body: TT34: Mark Clement - GNUMAP: Unbiased Probabilistic Mapping of Next-Generation Sequencing Reads

comments.body: Workflow: hash the genome into short k-mers. Map reads on the genome using a probabilistic algorithm.
Defaults to 10-mers currently
GNUMap use 10-mers as seeds.
Alignments: probabilistic Needleman-Wunsch to compensate for the variable quality of base calls.
Takes base call quality into account
Provides a quick overview of single read variation
The algorithm uses a PWM.
What happens to reads matching multiple loci in the genome? Options: discard (repeats); map to all; pick one.
Uses probabilistic assignment (proportional) for PWMs matching multiple genomic locations
Relation to other tools via simulation studies
More tests on real data: ETS1 binding domain.
Website: http://dna.cs.byu.edu/gnumap
Planned future support for paired-end reads, SOLiD
Question: run time -- aim for balance. Higher accuracy, but not as fast as some others
No limit on the sequence size, should work on 454
Requires all four base call probabilities, can't work on FASTQ alone
Blog post: http://www.fiamh.info/article...

body: PT37: Michiaki Hamada - Predictions of RNA Secondary Structure by Combining Homologous Sequence Information

comments.body: Need for better RNA secondary structure prediction with increasing awareness of functional ncRNAs
Most algorithms at the moment don't allow pseudoknots
Minimum Free Energy approaches: Mfold, RNAfold etc. But many structures close to MFE
Maximizing expected accuracy CONTRAfold etc.
CentroidFold (their algorithm) is an MEA tool. Performs better than RNAFold, Sfold, Contrafold... (not sure what the test set was)
Using homology to further improve accuracy of structure prediction (previous approaches: RNAalifold, McCaskill)
Sankoff sequence/structure alignment of sets of homologous sequences plus MEA. Computationally unfeasible.
Approximate the Sankoff method such that it is practical to run the method even for long RNA sequences

Compared CentroidAliFold to other state of the art methods. Outperforms conventional secondary structure prediction (ie. MFE-based) and outperforms everything except RAF (comparable) for approaches using homology too.
Much quicker than RAF
Method uses Nussinov-style dynamic programming to predict secondary structure. Maximises the sum of base pairing probabilities in the predicted secondary structure.
Hamada, Bioinformatics 25 465-473 (2009). Poster U53
New software is called CentroidHomfold and will be available soon from http://www.ncrna.org
Question: Algorithm tested on structural RNAs, can it be adapted to handle mRNAs etc with more flexible structures? Answer: Possible, but non-trivial
Competitors: PETfold http://is.gd/1kf9G

body: HL39: Francisco Melo - Evolutionary potentials for protein structure and function prediction

comments.body: protein structure prediction through: fold recognition and comparative modeling, or ab initio structure prediction
after making a model, its quality is assessed to decide whether to use it or discard it
usually have several iterations of comparative modeling
will speak about model quality assessment, an important ingredient in this process
below 40% sequence identity, have larger errors in predicted structure, mostly due to sequence alignment error
one way of dealing with this is to produce many alignments and use model quality assessment to assess the errors of the produced models
detect errors due to incorrect template and misalignment, which can occur with template-target identities of 20%, 25%, or 30% id
knowledge-based potentials, mean force potentials, or statistical potentials are scoring functions for model assessment
states are represented using geometrical descriptors
obtained scores represent pseudo-energies
we don't have an unbiased sample of the folded proteins, but use the known native folded proteins
very important to set the parameters of the potentials
may have interactions between amino acids that are close in 3d space
matrix = [a][b][k][r], interactions between C-alpha and C-betas; matrix dimensions are [40][40][10][30]
traditionally derive statistical potential by taking whole pdb, then clustering it and taking representatives, in order to have unbiased sample of fold space
train on features of these to get relative frequencies, derive relative statistical potential
here instead they derive evolutionary or structure-specific potential
but homologous protein sequences contain valuable information
important or key residues for fast folding can be derived using information from known homologs
some key interactions that provide stability can be derived from homologs
PSI-BLAST, then MSA, then comparatively model each sequence using the template
use these structures to derive family-specific statistical potential
have to duck out for a meeting now :-(

body: PT36: Yang Huang - Graph Theoretical Approach To Study eQTL: A Case Study of Plasmodium Falciparum

comments.body: P.falciparum is the most deadly human malaria pathogen
Little information about gene regulation so far, eQTL might be able to shed some light on this regulation and drug resistance
SNPs might affect gee expression. Consider expression as a quantitative trait like height, weight. Identify the associated locus by statistical methods.
Traditional tests between multiple loci, all expression. Comprehensive and without biast, but does not use the inherent data structure, computationally expensive and a problem of statistical power.
Alternative approach GeD, Graph-based eQTL decomposition. Include strain data in the association graph
Graph structure: Three types of vertices: gene linked to strain linked to locus
Find cliques to reduce data complexity
Each clique has 3 vertices (G/S/L) that are fully connected, in addition each clique is a maximal subgraph that cannot be extended further
Represent inherent data structures
Heuristic approach on eQTL cliques to look for (Locus,gene) pairs with certain patterns; refer to graph/diagram in paper
Cliques help to detect eQTLs, avoiding a large number of tests; integration of strain information provides a new framework for eQTL studies
Blog post at http://www.fiamh.info/article...

body: PT35: Pradipta Ray - DISCOVER: A Feature-Based Discriminative Method for Motif Search in Complex Genomes

comments.body: The problem: find transcription factor binding sites.
In higher organisms, binding sites operate in clusters.
Two approaches: supervides / unsupervised. They used a supervised search.
Traditionally used PWMs to model motifs
PWM: position weight matrix. Used to score sequence windows.
Problem: high false positive rate.
An evolution of this idea: hidden markov models.
Two states: motif and background states / distributions. You learn parameters of these models from known data.
The performance of such models has saturated in recent years
problems with HMM / generative models: may tune to noise, rather than the signal; Seem to have hit peak performance; Difficult to incorporate other sources of information to improve predictions
New approaches try to integrate other sources of evidence: multi-species phylogenetics, distance from TSS and between TFBSs, epigenetic data.
DISCOVER allows you to integrate multiple sources of evidence into your motif model
They use conditional random fields, a discriminative model.
The estimation phase reduces to a convex maximization problem.
What features correlate with TFBSs? Motifs, for example, have high PhastCons scores. Background is linked to GC content.
and check these features are discriminatory in the context of the model.
Leave-one-out cross validation on Drosophila data
DISCOVER is 20% better than other algorithms on the F1 score (harmonic mean of precision and recall).
Precision (TP/(TP+FP))/Recall l(TP/(TP+FN)) curves. DISCOVER balances the Precision/Recall trade-off better than other tools.
Website: http://www.sailing.cs.cmu.edu/discove...
is abstracized really a word?

body: HL36: Patrick Bradley - Leveraging the context-specific coordination of transcript and metabolite concentrations to discover gene-metabolite interactions.

comments.body: [apologizes to bloggers for the long title we'd have to write down :) ]
want to find missing edges in metabolic maps, especially for non-model organisms
e.g. pathogens which have evolved novel p/ws
want to find different types of edges (e.g. regulation)
gene-metabolite interactions: AMP kinase senses concentrations of AICAR, AMP and ATP
how do transcription and metabolism influence each other on a global scale?
paper: Bradley PH, Brauer MJ et al, PLoS Comp Bio, Jan 2009. http://www.ploscompbiol.org/article...
starve yeast for etiehr carbon or nitrogen, look at transcriptome and metabolomic response
SVD (singular value decomposition) suggests that transcr. and metab. responses are coordinated
4 broad classes of metabolites: glycolysis; TCA cycle; biosynthetic intermediates; amino acids
look at GO terms of correlated metabolites and genes; show expected behavior. e.g. amino acids -- protein biosynthesis
to identify dependencies in the data, look at: direction and strength of correlation, environmental pertubation, class of metabolite
some genes and metabolites display context-specific patterns, e.g. methionine vs. MET6
in some cases positive corr. under one environmental condition and negative corr. under another condition
train Bayesian network on pathway data from KEGG
structure of network: http://www.ploscompbiol.org/article...
nitrogen starvation seems to be more informative

body: PT33: Thomas Abeel - Towards a Gold Standard for Promoter Prediction Evaluation

comments.body: definition of a promoter. Multiple transcription start sites in a given transcriptional unit.
1997: first paper evaluating promoter prediction. 9 prediction programs. 15-30% success
2004 - whole genome. Precision 5-87% and recall 27-29%.
2006 - CAGE tags provide known results to test predictions
Need a gold standard as there is no consensus method at the moment, and different tools all claim to be the best.
They use data from CAGE (clustered into transcription start regions) and RefSeq (5' end as true promoter site) to test predictors
17 programs. All free for academic use and capable of being run on the whole human genome. Ran all programs over various thresholds
Plot precision v recall and calc AUC over threshold range for each of the programs.
Four programs scoring over 20% in prediction: ARTS, EP3, Eponine, ProSOM
considered 4 best scoring programs. Found classes of promoters - some with a single peak of tss, some with a couple, a few with many tss all over the region
Many of these programs predict unique promoters the others don't provide -- merge prediction to increase information? Majority vote?
Current promoter prediction: 1/3 sites can be predicted and 2/3 predictions are correct.

body: HL35: Johannes Soeding - Context-specific BLAST detects twice as many homologous proteins as BLAST

comments.body: Not only about BLAST, but also about models of protein evolution.
Importance of BLAST searches: 400,000 searches run at NCBI per day.
BLAST (1990) and PSI-BLAST (1997) cited 45,000 times.
Protein bioinformatics relies heavily on sequence searching.
Sequence alignments are a special case of profile alignments.
The score of an alignment can be thought as the log of the ratio of the probability of the mutations needed to go from sequence X to Y over the average probability of Y.
Context specific substitution matrices used with success, among others, for protein structure prediction (Rice & Eisenberg 1997, Huang & Bystroff 2006).
Their approch: take 6 neighbours to the left and to the right of a nucleotide.
The search uses a sliding window over the sequence; the mutation probability is computed by looking at a precalculated library of profiles.
Profiles are built out of homology relations found with BLAST. The library contains 1 million profiles.
Performances: CS-BLAST finds ~2 times more homologs than BLAST.
PSI-BLAST: iterative search.
Extension with context specific pseudocounts -> CSI-BLAST
Performances increase not as much as in the BLAST case, but still more sensitivity.
PSI-BLAST 5th iteration is similar to the 2nd of CSI-BLAST.
Some problems in the E-value calculations. Repeat proteins could cause high-scoring false positives. They modified the calculation and removed the bias.
Bioinformatics is now driven by information, no longer by algorithms.
To tame information you need a statistical model.
Webserver: http://toolkit.lmb.uni-muenchen.de/cs_blas...
Poster: U08

body: HL34: Tomer Shlomi - Network-based prediction of human tissue-specific metabolism

comments.body: so far similar to Sunday's biopathways SIG talk: http://friendfeed.com/ismbecc...
want to predict metabolic activity of human genes
problem: expression level does not reflect metabolic activity: has post-translational regulation
(4% up-regulated, 16% down-regulated)
large-scale validation using tissue-specific literature data
tissue-specificity of disease genes: if a gene causes a disease in a certain tissue, it is likely to be active in this tissue
method is capable of predicting tissues where the genes are post-transcriptionally up-regulated
highly expressed neighboring genes give hints that a certain gene will be active
MEAT: metabolic expression analysis tool
follow-up work: biomarkers from genetic disorders, see SIG talk linked at the top and the paper: http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/article...

body: Keynote: Eugenia del Pino - The comparative analysis reveals independence of developmental processes during early development in frogs

comments.body: Has studied "marsupial" frogs, found in the gardens of her university.
Brief description of Ecuador, and the Galápagos islands
And, there are no native frogs in the Galapagos.
Most of frog diversity is in Brasil, Colombia and Ecuador
Why not just studying Xenopus laevis? To discover developmental differences and for training of local researchers
X. laevis comes from S. Africa as the early development of this frog is better known than that of humans.
Beautiful pictures of foam-nesting frog embryos
embryos are white for camoflage in the foam-nest frog
Dendrobatid frogs include the poison arrow frogs, though they don't study the poisonous ones.
The males find an appropriate nest spot, then call the females. Males care for the embryos for 20 days.
Beautiful drawings of the early development of the dendrobatids studied by O. Perez
Marsupial frogs (Gastrotheca), the female have a pouch located on her back where she carries the embryos
The mother transports the embroys for 4 months, and then puts them in the water by opening the pouch with her hind legs.
the eggs of marsupial fros are larger than average
The reproductive physiology of the frog resembles that of mammals.
Now a video or early embryo development in X. laevis (from Jim Smith)
Gastrulation is a common process in vertebrates
A major problem of early development is to perform the change from sphere to elongated tadpole. The important movements are called the dorsal convergence and extension.
An important gene in CE is Brachyury.
The DBL is also called the "organizer" due to the work of Spemann-Mangold in 1924.
Organizer genes are conserved across vertebrates.
The cavity formed during gastrulation is the Archenteron ("the primitive cut")
In the slowly-developing frogs there is delayed elongation of the archenteron.
Polyclonial antibodies were made for both Lim1 and Brachyury. These are TFs and accumulated in nuclei.
Notochord elongation and therefore dorsal CE begins in the midgastrula in rapidy-developing frogs.
Conversely, notochord elongation and CE occur after blastopore closure in slowly-developing frogs.
Implications of this work: frog gastrulation is modular, and CE is not essential for gastrulation.
Also, the head and trunk organizers are separable from each other
There are different ways to make a frog
About Dr. del Pino and her work: http://www.pnas.org/content..., http://www.pnas.org/content...
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...
Thanks for that guys, takes me back to my developmental biology days working on defective organiser function in KO mice..
