body: Special Session 4: PLoS Abigail Morrison on Neuroscience

comments.body: First of three speakers at the PLoS special session
All three speakers are editors at PLoS Comp Biol
In computational neuroscience, the key ideas to be communicated are mathematical and computational models as well as data analysis methods
Very little standardization in many areas of computational neuroscience
Lack of standardization is hindering progress and building on others work
Abigail Morrison can think of only one model, in all the times she's worked on it, that they've been able to reproduce without going back to the authors
Is it science, or is it travel reporting?
Approach to solve the problem: work together to create tools to facilitate reproducibility
International Neuroinformatics Coordinating Facility http://www.incf.org/
Japan node: Visiome http://platform.visiome.neuroinf.jp/ (and we have another -omics)

The Japanese node focuses on the visual side of things, and has produced Visiome, which attempts to collect both papers and figures separately as well as model parameters, simulation scripts and figure-generation scripts. This can all be downloaded, and then hopefully run it on your own system
Also the Simulation Server Platform, which uses a VM to reproduce the environment the original model was run in so others can test and run it
German node' goal is to provide open source tools for data sharing and analysis
The problem is that there are many different recording devices and analysis tools, and no standardization
German node developing unified data format + associated tools
They also want to design and implement a machine-readable declarative language to describe neural network model (like SBML) - first meeting in March 2009 so still new.
PyNN, Python Neural network simulation package
facilitates cross-checking, as it can run on any simulator that implements the common API
Simulation-code written in PyNN, can use several underlying simulators, instead of using simulator-specific languages
Gregory Wilson, American Scientist 2006 "Where's the real bottleneck in scientific computing?"
if nobody can understand you ideas and reproduce your results, have you really remove a bottleneck or just made it somebody else"s problem?
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...

body: Special Session 5: Next Steps in eQTL Analysis: Gaining Insight at the Systems Level

comments.body: Speakers: Ritsert Jansen, Andrew Su, Andreas Beyer, Rob Williams
Ritsert Jansen - find xQTLs (eQTLs, pQTLs, mQTL, phQTL) - links both to genetic and epigenetic variation
The first talk: http://friendfeed.com/biocs...
e - expression; p - protein; m - metabolite; ph - phenotype
Keurentjes PNAS 2006 - prioritize potential regulators by the number of genes they are associated to
Fu (Nature Prot 2007) - find mQTLs and recover glusinolate pathway
[ coverage of Ritsert Jansen's talk is here, http://friendfeed.com/biocs... -- not in ISMB room by accident ]
Jansen (Curr Opinion Plant Bio 2009) - integrate xQTLs; summary of results for integrating the 4 levels of association. Not all associations are shared across the levels, but some are.
Would like to infer causes, not just associations.
Can compare causal vs. pleiotropic models.
Problems - observed noise not biological; few causal associations compared to pleiotropic ones
Need large sample sizes to reliably infer causal relations. 30% variance explained by QTL for both traits required for 200 individuals.
Boerjan (Nat Genet 2009) - hotspots; few loci in genome with high number of associations for levels from transcripts to phenotype
Johannes (Nat Rev Gen 2008, PLOS Genetics 2009) - chromatin state uncorrelated to DNA sequence correlated to traits? Large part of heritable variability explained by epigenetic variants.
@Michael - thanks; any chance to move these? Anyway, next ones will be in more appropriate place :)
@Leopold: Unfortunately not, I wish this was easier. I'll make a post for the next talk and link it here (this time in the ISMB room!)
Andrew Su's talk: http://friendfeed.com/ismbecc...
Andreas Beyer's talk: http://friendfeed.com/ismbecc...
Rob Williams' talk: http://friendfeed.com/ismbecc...

body: Special Session 4: PLoS: Adam Arkin on Synthetic Biology

comments.body: Running the Net: Finding and Employing the OPerating Principles of Cellular Systems: the need for scientific standards and cooperation
synthetic biology, make simulation of cell, cheaper, more reliable and faster
Again, need for standards and cooperation!
synthetic biology is data driven
Dogs had been breed for almost anything (poor dogs)
For dogs, that such differences would cause survival effects in the "wild" doesn't bother many people.
Next is the classic example of the cane toad, which destroyed environmental diversity.
TRANSPARENCY is the key to synthetic biology - the focus of making things as predicable as they can
About the Cane toad in Australia: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki...
Engineering is all about well-characterized, standard parts and devices.
The meta-data about microarrays in GEO is so poor that almost make those microarray useless
But how to achieve those standards?
If you put two attenuators on the same transcript, it behaves about as you expect: it functions as a NOT-OR gate.
single antisense RNA-mediated transcription attenuator: NOT gate
Bacteria engineered as pathogens to target particular human tissue (e.g. tumors). To do that, you have to build many different modules with its own computational and culure unit tests.
Absolute requirements: openness, transparency, standards, team-science approaches.
what we need: openness, publication of dead ends and multiple failures.
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...

body: Special Session 4: PLoS: Donna Slonim on human development / Translational medicine

comments.body: Should be from Bench to Bytes to Bedside and Back, not from Bench to Bedside
What might be helpful in closing the loop: strongly-interdisciplinary collaborations, availability of clinical data, and standards to ensure that data are shared in useful ways.
Translational Development Genomics: while there has been progress in screening, is there anything more that we can get out of genomics data and help with diagnoses?
So they did a pilot study for Down's Syndrome (caused by trisomy 21).
There is quite a range of expression - very little is significant. BUT there's huge disregulation of the genome.
The connectivity map further implicates oxidative stress: the top compounds (positive correlation) relate to oxidation and ion transport.
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...

body: Special Session 4: PLoS: Panel Session with previous speakers plus Philip Bourne, Editor-In-Chief PLoS CB

comments.body: AA: the problem is reward. The reward for publishing a model as SBML is zero, or even negative right now. Until it stops preventing us from doing science, you won't see as much an uptake as you should. Even now, it's somewhat limited in what it can capture.

AA: even if he forced his lab to do MIAME stuff, they'd find ways to circumvent it. Need to try harder to have a reward. Linux worked because there is a dictatorial and charismatic leader at the center that started out with a core group
PB: We should start having DOIs and PubMed IDs to things that are a little less than traditional.
PB: Very few people sit and look through an entire journal anymore: they go to specific papers.  So, you should be able to navigate between papers, abstracts and other components of the paper.
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...

body: Birds of a Feather session: Semantic Web-Linked Data, organized by Eric Neumann, in T5

comments.body: linked data is: a simple set of 4 guidelines for publishing RDF data on the Web (over HTTP), developed by Tim Berners-Lee in 2006

1. Use URIs as names for things (globally unique identity).  2. Use HTTP URIs (everyone has a web browser/client) 3. When someone looks up a URI, provide useful information...in the form of RDF data.  4. Include links to other URIs (foster discovery of additional information).
Context-independent identifiers (URIs) would make things so much more useful and interoperable - like Lego pieces.
Some want to get the semantics exactly right and use formal logic and OWL, but here we're emphasizing just the linkability of things.
A URI can only refer to one thing, but one thing can have several URIs, unfortunately.

several years ago, tried to bridge use LSIDs (life science ids): thing:something:something:identifier.  But this can only be recognized by some particular software, not a web browser.  Strong influence from W3C to use HTTP URIs, per the law of least power: do what requires the least technology.  Even Mark Wilkerson who was touting LSIDs has come around to HTTP URIs.
A commenter says LSIDs still exist, it's just that they can extract them from HTTP URIs.
There are other proposals, e.g., shared names; Neumann prefers even less constraint than shared names.
So, now if you put in a URI you get something back.  You should be able to get RDF back.  UniProt does this: if you put .rdf on the end of the URI, you'll get the data back as RDF.
Now colleagues can just use the URIs in order to reuse the data; don't need to copy the data.
someone says the UniProt accession is an identifier, whereas the URI is a way to get at the thing through the web
identifiers can overlap, but HTTP URIs put things in unique namespaces
it needs to be stable: when you put this out, you're establishing a contract with the community that it's going to change

currently, the url, e.g., http://www.uniprot.org/uniprot... is also the URI. the second part is the identifier of the record and the part before the slash is the namespace. At http://purl.bioontology.org, we separate the namespace and the url. So going there we have a PO box that can eternally forward it.
Problem: this assumes http://purl.bioontology.org may go away. Thus the Banff Manifesto.
Reduce the likelihood of catastrophic failure by consolidating it into an institution, e.g., Stanford University, with longevity.
This just pushes the problem onto purl.bioontology.org.
The domain name can be transferred, so why do we need purl.bioontology.org?
Transferring a zillion domain names is a pain, transferring one domain name is easy.  The institution commits to maintaining that domain.
It should be not just the institution, but the community--the community will continue to live on.
Knowledge should be monotonic: it grows and doesn't disappear.  Even if a particular effort dries up, the URIs should still be valid so we can still see what was there.
The Linking Open Data Project: A community project started within the W3C Semantic Web Education & Outreach group in 2007
The LOD (Linking Of Data) "cloud", May 2007: many projects with various links between them, e.g., MusicBrainz, FOAF, DBpedia, etc.
By March 2008, had tripled
you can put any kind of data up and make it available to Sparkle queries
By September, WordNet and various other dbs had come in
March 2009: life sciences comes in, with Bio2RDF
now you can find the data that is in NCBI and UniProt in RDF format, but not the experimental data yet
to make this useful for interesting research, will need URIs, and to figure out what are the rules that are important for life sciences
when you publish using this data, how is your data that builds on top of it going to be able that's linked from it?
we don't really have this concept in life sciences yet, people don't know about it
suppose one looks for a concept in the LOD cloud, like "heart"; how do we know which thing to query?  BioOntology, DBpedia, etc?
one can't do the Google on it yet
bioontology guy hates Google analogy; Google gives millions of hits, but we want the contextual query
i protest, have to have indexing before ranking
this doesn't solve the problem of redundancy: we want the facts about a protein, regardless of their source
bioontology guy says you don't need the index to answer the query, just to answer it fast
someone else says, need the indexing in order to do the clustering
she says you need semantic web overlays. we need hierarchical indexing environment in order to do this at scale
one needs to be able to query on an abstraction
bioontology guy: what's more important, query or browsing?
someone else: even browsing, if something is 3 links away, may not even go there

bio2rdf guy says: first we ask everyone simultaneously: do you know about this?  then we ask what do you know about it?  we have implemented Shared Names.  But the URI just goes to the original record.  Many people have said many things about the same entity.
nobody wants to have to read all the papers in MedLine.  the punchline is the links: how does this protein relate to others.  if we don't trust a link, *then* we want to drill down

if there are 5 million sources of "A is related to B", we don't want to read all of them, we just want to know that there are 5 million of them.  we also want to know the kind of evidence, e.g., particular kind of experiment.  Then the user can decide whether to trust it.
At this conference, enormous number of people mining data.  We should be able to see their results as easily as the original sources.
Great coverage! Thanx! It's like being there... would have loved to sneak in on this BoF...
Egon: feel free to wander in...
we want just the local subnetwork, not the text.  we want the facts
people want question answering
Bing bought Powerset for this purpose
someone says this turned out to be crap, e.g., "Psoriasis causes arms"
the question can be a small subgraph, not necessarily an English sentence
when we want information about a protein, there are only a limited number of kinds of things we can be interested in, so the software can guide the query context-sensitively
we need to distinguish the problem of document retrieval from query formulation
we shouldn't just think of scientists, but also other kinds of users
this will all be possible, but many people are currently just reinventing RDF over and over again
how many here are producers of RDF? roughly 8
put the things that we create in RDF, e.g., if you make the intersection of this fact with this paper, you are in charge of minting that URI
if everyone does this, then this facilitates cross-references and exchanges
http://bio2rdf.org querying life
Nophar Geifman has been working with Eytan Ruppin on finding cliques in GO around different diseases.  A thing like that should have an URI, so other people can use it.
can we do micro-experiments so by ISMB next year, we can prove this concept
paradigm shift between hypothesis-driven query versus, the data throws the hypothesis at you
what's important is the use case: what is the question you can answer that would make them go "wow"?
David Hune is working with FreeBase and has developed Parallax, a facet browser
he also developed Exhibit
faceted browsing makes more sense to biologists
look at Google's Wonder Wheel

Jamie Gonagell (sp??!) at SciFoo camp designs games, first slide was World of Warcraft: if you harnessed the collective brainpower that youngsters spend on WoW every day, you could rewrite Wikipedia every day!
we need to figure out how to pull people in
I mentioned during the session, but forgot to link here (hard to talk and type at the same time!), Marti Hearst's new book _Search User Interfaces_ http://searchuserinterfaces.com

How to pull people in - that's the challenge to get this working. Could we get some seed money into this scientific effort and have it distributed with mechanisms similar to Google Adds? Yes if so we could have students and scientists putting efforts into this rather than some obscure webservers, blog etc with Google Adds. But how to generate the seed money? Government grants, donations or pay for usage?

body: BOF: VizBi - Visualization of Biological Data 1pm Wednesday K1

comments.body: we have had two questions and calls from the floor so far :
13-14 people interested in genomes and sequence visualization
9 interested in alignments and phylogenies
systems biology (highthrouput (omix) and pathways) - *everyone is interested in this session*

Will there be any discussion on types of indexes and containers for visualizing very large datasets? For example ways to very quickly grab the features in a small genomic region for display in genome browser?
"Jan- I'll ask your question in a second - we'll go through the sessions once again
LM session description- visualization of final processed data either still images or trajectories - ~ 6 people - seems less than expected
3-4 people interested in mri
and around 30 people have raised their hands more than once.
What about visualization of features that have more than 1 position on a genome? E.g. readpairs. => circular genome browser?
@Jan - we hope to cover that as well. I also hoped todeal with genome assembly visualization- but we couldn't find anyone willing to review it (I don't actually beleive this myself!)
usability keynote yet to be determined (we have invited someone and await their reply)- but we aim to discuss how best to create usable biological software
@Jim: regarding the circular browser: something like Circos, but for browsing rather than just presentation; not static.
@Jan - yes. interactive and analytical visualization is defintely the focus
@Jan - sorry I haven't raised your question yet - do you want to ask yourself at the appropriate moment ?
we have over 70 people registered at www.vizbi.org - and we will be opening registration soon.
question about how do we visualize textual semantic relationships - this is still a challenge in information visualization
sean explains that we really had to rationalise the sessions to make things strongly focused (as a result, his tools - as an example - may not be reviewed in the specific talks)
@Jim - I'm still in Hinxton, UK....
Can someone also ask if people would see value in a biohackathon focussed on visualization? Not a meeting, but actually getting things done?

@Jan - ah - ok. Sean has really answered your question implicitly. We really wanted to get the *interactive* tools covered - so a biologist would have an easy way of discovering the best tools for each type of focus.
@Jan - I will. I can also raise this via OBF
suggestion of having a bioinformatics web and application usability interest group that can provide guidelines on usability for our applications
often all we need it a place to start for this.. not a complete service

userbase/tool disconnect - often tools are developed by the person who originiated the database/method/etc without any idea of what the most productive user is actually going to want to do - and often without any real general knowledge of how the rational biologist works
Am working on a genome viewer that looks like Circos, but is completely interactive (i.e. zooming in/out of loci). Bumping into both design and technical issues, though.
@Jan - can you contact Cydney Nielsen ? make sure she knows about your tool - we are also setting up WIkipedia pages (see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki...)
sean -> says user interface designer must be completely in the mindset of the end user
floor: new instruments drive new tools to visualize data - and there are several levels on how users need to be enabled to visualize
suggest there is a lack of cognitive science and psychology in this meeting
poster deconstruction: images with sharp and bright colours are great for 12 year olds but not necessarily intuitively informative about the underlying information.
i.e. there could be standard coloursets for types of data (minimum numbers of colours)
NIls follows on - there are a number of visualization fields where this has been an issue and very reliable guidelines have been developed to deal with colour confusion
this conference is a first step - we hope that there will be a much stronger accent on pactical visualization theory and attract some of the experts from the more general visualization community
floor: its often about finding out what you want to ask of some data, and then finding a visualization that can give them an answer.
my response: this used to be the aim of the visualization toolkits but these are often not quite appropriate for bioinformaitcs (scaling, deployment, licencing)
floor: very important to actually watch the user to see how they use your application - great understanding about how you can improve it
floor#2 point: pure html web applications - and a 2d page is not sufficient for completely integrated visualization
sean considers its too early to start defining standards (I feel standards are actually defined elsewhere, we just need to start to see how they can apply to us)
Do people think we might be able to end up with some "design patterns" such as in software development (once the field has matured a bit more)?
Jan et al - I'm moving this discussion to its own friendfeed room http://friendfeed.com/ismb200...
ah. possibly. I defintely think there are analogous patterns in user interface design that map to the kinds of cognitive processes that a biologist operates

Nils is talking about this - systems biology visualization is all about abstract information models - networks, matrices, multidimensional time series, etc - these have all got standard (and new/emerging) models for their visualization
sean discusses occams razor - don't create a million categories
around 10 or so are interested in contributing to the wiki pages
how do we stop the wikipedia list being 'just a list of biological tools'

sean comments that there are many ways of cutting a slice out of this area - we've started at the very simplest and simply list tools with some indication of the types of methods they are relevant to and types of visualuization that they accomplish
developer comment:visualization tools require significant R&D on behalf of the developer
how to link ecological data with molecular data
sean reveals the hidden agenda - enabling different types of visualization tool to be easily combined. Wehope that bringing the developers of these tools together might happen
practically everyone here is a developer, around ten or so are users, and a scattering ofpeople came because they were just interest
offline now - please continue here or at the other friendfeed room : http://friendfeed.com/ismb200...

body: eQTL special session: Andrew Su

comments.body: patterns of gene annotation in EntrezGene: few well studies genes, almost 50% of all genes have 0 linked references
want to use GWAS to discover disease genes
use mouse diversity panel
quite a bit of phenotypic variability in mouse strains
Haplotype Association Mapping, Pletcher et al 2004, McClurg et al 2006 and 2007
eQTL maps: Probe set genomic position vs. QTL/SNP genomic position
cis-QTL band: strong diagonal, trans-QTL bands
trans: non-local regulation through diffusable factors
functional analysis of trans bands: rank according to association score, gene enrichment test on GO / KEGG
can use this to identify novel pathway members (in OxPhos pathway)
add orthogonal data set: many tissues in one mouse strain (as opposed to normal eQTL data: same tissue in many strains)
--> Gene Atlas
get 10 inferred new pathway members, sometimes see that the genes are just missing annotations
can also look for putative regulators
find Cyclin H as potent OxPhos regulator, validate experimentally
technical caveat: nonparametric estimation of background requires careful permutation strategy, Breitling R et al, 2008, PLoS Genetics
Thanks for the live-blogging Michael! Your notes made me realize I never included a reference to the PLoS Genetics paper describing the work. It is here: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed...

body: eQTL special session: Andreas Beyer

comments.body: future will be data integration: eQTL plus other information
Suthram et al, 2008 Mol Sys Biol
eQTL electric diagrams: simulate flow as electric current
need to improve eQTL methods, switch to multi-parametric methods
random forest eQTL mapping, as opposed to traditional regression methods
eQTL should rather be a classification problem
people are worried if they have enough power (individuals) for multivariate regression
Regression trees on genotypes as a multivariate approach
random forests (RF) are based on decision trees, search for marker that separates pop. into more homogeneous subgroups
split subgroups again based on different markers, groups become smaller and more homogenous
randomly pick splits, get forest of decision trees: thus random forest
importance measures for markers: increase in variance when marker is randomized; reduction of RSS when used; number of times marker is used
(last one is simpler, but less established)
should work on real data, rather than simulations
benchmark on known pathways to identify regulators and regulated genes
KEGG enrichment in yeast: RF methods and lasso outperform univariate methods
Lasso 2nd best, beating two of three RFs
RF1 > Lasso > RF2 > RF3 > univariate methods (in yeast)
similar ranking in mouse data (although more noisy overall)
The different RF approaches best in mouse; marginal differences
RF will fall back to univariate if power is sufficient for only one marker (by giving back confidence values)
(metric for real data  tests - fraction of locus-gene pairs in same pathway)
have 2 different mouse populations BXD, MDP [see Andrew Su's talk]. can data from one population inform studies on the other?
find consistency much above random between the two strains
most agreement on cis-band between the two populations, but also some interesting trans bands
have consistent eQTLs, want to finemap
want to use MDP data for fine-mapping BXD. BXD is more homogeneous, thus less markers
MDP data: more markers!
but also lots of noise...
find a gene in the same pathway next to 2 high markers
again, validate on pathway membership
also combining eQTLs called with different methodology (RF vs another test)
MDP data significantly boosts hit rate: increasing from 15% to 30%
finding genetic interactions with RF
want to know if two significant markers are interacting or just have independent marginal effects
look at split symmetry: significant markers A and B. After split with A, is B a marker in both of the sub-populations or just in one?
look for conditional effects by comparing the relative levels at which two markers were selected in the tree
if both sub-populations: no interaction, if one: probably interaction
can create interaction graph
find new regulations for gene Auts2, but know little about the gene
find 4 genes which interact with Auts2
multiple testing issue? will find these effects in a random dataset..
take home: do second level analysis after multivariate mapping; finding epistatic interactions might be possible even with small pop. sizes if you have high quality data
Confirmation of results on top of simulation studies - consistency in pathways, categories as a quality metric

body: eQTL special session: Rob Williams, The phenotype revolution

comments.body: genetic reference populations: "fixed" populations
BXD genetic reference population
BXD: homozygous strain
F2 cross between DBA/2J (oldest inbred) and C57BL/6J (standard black)
inbreed the crosses, headed towards 100+ lines
have homozygous permutation of the parental genomes
inbred strains originally to avoid southerns
GeneNetwork: http://www.GeneNetwork.org
http://www.genenetwork.org
can select species and tissues
can resemble the same genome over and over again: thus can suppress environmental influence
dense microphenotypes for the bxd strains, specifically brain
few recombination events a problem - large linkage blocks with a lot of genes
can use geneNetwork to straightforwardly get a QTL map
and zoom in on cis and trans associatios, follow up genes, create expression network
then plot heatmaps for hypothesis generation
explore trans bands for the bxd collection. One for the pigment mutation. Many usually artefactual (in mouse datasets)

body: ISMB Light Factory: Party on Wednesday night open thread

comments.body: Left the party relatively early to allow the long queues outside to move into the party (at least by one person!). had fun - thanks to the organizers
yes, thanks to the organizers
there is no dancing at math conferences
now you know why i'm in bioinformatics ;-)
@Ruchira - very good point!
Yeah, you need to reserve some time for the coverage! :)
deeply disappointed that nobody live-blogged the party - I had expected real-time updated playlist and more ;)
Would be fun :) Seeing the comments become more non-sense as the commenter gets drunk...
Well, about the playlist: Good tracks included James Brown, various reggae stuff, and Tainted Love :)
wished the venue would have been bigger so everyone could get in.

did y'all hear about the thief?  took someone's backpack, someone's purse, and someone's camera.  owner of the backpack noticed it was missing, walked outside and saw this guy with an enormous backpack.  when he called to the guy, the guy ran.  it was the same guy who was bothering a lot of women earlier (in one case, took her purse).  i was so annoyed by him getting in my face that i left--so my things are safe, luckily for me!  heard all this from the owner of the backpack at the services desk.
@David I don't think that they thought so many would attend :) Victim of its own success?
@Ruchira - that's awful! I'm really glad I put my bag in a locker. So, a few people have descriptions of him? And does that mean he was a conference attendee, or just gate-crashed? Yikes...

@Allyson, I expect so.  You may have noticed him at some point--short, dark complexion.  I hadn't seen him before the party, but that doesn't mean anything.  I was asked only "CS or bio?" at the door, but I had my badge on.

Hey guys,

Allyson is correct. Based on last year's party, we expected far fewer people to come. For everyone who came and could not get in initially and had to wait or got frustrated and left -- we are really sorry. It is a priority for next year to make sure that doesn't happen again. Regarding the thief, we believe he snuck in aided by a couple of friends who distracted the security. We regret that this happened and hope that nothing irreplaceable was taken.

For those who came back after the initial crush, we hope the wait was worth it. The party was still going strong when we finally had to shut down about 2:30, in part because we had consumed the entire supply of beer from the hotel and from their sister hotel across the street.

Thanks to everyone who came and partied with us. We had a great time putting on this event for you and look forward to doing it again in Boston next year!

extinction

which species are in trouble?

3 stories

3 studies: Tasmanian tiger, Mammoth, ...
explains how DNA can be found in hairs.
For extinct species, mitochondrial genome is easier to sequence, as it is up to 1,000 times more abundant than genomic DNA
aDNA = ancient DNA
background of ancient DNA ...

1. phylogenetics
2. population genetics

genes

short reads are good enough for aDNA junks
next-generation seq of aDNA

aDNA from hair shafts enclosed in a plastic bag  like ....
Tasmanian tiger: extinction date 7/9/1936
over 700 know specimens
http://thylacine.psu.edu
thylacine = tasmanian tiger
attempts to study thylacine DNA
observations
2 mitochindrial genomes in GenBank
in GenBank two genes 12S, cytb both were wrong
both wrong at 10% of nucleotides
tasmanian devil closest relative to tiger
split at ~40m years ago
30% of new sequence data are from nuclear genome
-> maybe sequence whole genome?
one imp question ... did an epidemic contribute to extinction?
Epidemic probable cause of extinction
(the quiet comments are hillarious. 'we sequenced one from Stockholm swimming in alcohol. Long way from home, extinct, drowning his sorrows...')
story 2 wooly mammoth
Mammoth:
hair sample from eBay
we found sample on ebay
most samples are from Sibiria
have now 18 different complete mtDNA sequences
what we draw from this analysis ....mammoth separated from living elephants 6m years ago
like chimp and human
want to sequence the full nuclear genome
already got 0.7-fold coverage
= 3.3 billion bp
assuming real size of genome is 4.7Gb
aa identitiy is nearly 99.8% between mammoth and elephant
99.4% overall nucleotide identity
This equals 1 mutation per protein
(all this excluding indels)
90% seq from the sample from the wooly mammoth
Mammoths differ from all other vertebrates in some highly conversed genes, such as MRTO
maybe due to living in cold places
extinction scenario ...human killed them all
certainly not
extinction szenario: killed by humans.. become to warm... -> but thats' not true
humans arrives to late in Siberia
3rd story Tasmanian devil
tasmanian devil now
threatened by extinction due to cancer
cancer cells passed around by biting each other
cancer is passed through infection (biting other individuals, spreading cancer cells)
some resistant individuals
Trying to preserve the species, keeping the gene pool large enough
compared two individuals: one who is resistant, one who died
Finding out about the resistance: considering an ortholog of a human tumor supressor gene
the guy who died, has a mutation at an extremely conserved position
but not much is known what it means..
want to look at non-coding nuclear SNPs
closest sequenced relative is oppossum
90m years of separation
-> computational problem: SNPs without a reference genome
produce sequences from many individuals instead
and compare SNPs there
-> extract population structure
seems to work.. but no final data...
Quick summary: Bioinformatics very helpful, but much more data needed
Role of genetic diversity in extinction still not really known.. no simple story
but genetic diversity not necessary a good indicator for risk of extinction..
e.g. panda has high diversity, but endangered

body: HL62: Richard Green - A Complete Neandertal Mitochondrial Genome Sequence Determined by High-Throughput Sequencing

comments.body: Neandertals: closest extinct relative. existed 400000-30000 yrs ago
chimps are closest living relatives, but deviated longer ago
first DNA from extinct species was in 1985 from the Quagga
Neandertal mitochondrial genome, as it is present about 1000 copies per cell vs 2 copies of genomic DNA
mitochondrial genome is easier to recover since there are many copies per cell
http://www.mitomap.org/WorldMi...
Mitochondial genome is useful for tracking maternal lineages, and it accumulates mutations slowly -- ideal for building trees
seems like there was no interbreeding between Neandertals and modern humans
Deep sequencing with high-throughput next generation sequencing, used to be direct PCR
ancient DNA fragments are just 60nt in length
Roche/454 and Illumina sequencing was used, no need to fragment DNA (more fragmented than one would like anyway)
many C to T transitions, also G to A
COX2 protein has 5 differences between chimp and human, 4 of 5 differences happened in the last 600,000 yrs, so Neandertals also have 4 different AAs compared to Homo sapiens
Maybe fast evolving sites? Reverting to previous (=monkey), more advantageous  AAs?
sequencing errors: 3% of all Cs are Ts, same for G->A. Reason: C is deaminated to U, then seen as T
higher probability for deamination at the end of fragments. Perhaps because cytosine deamination is 100x faster in single-stranded DNA and end of fragments are single-stranded
MIA: mapping iterative assembler. manuscript in preparation
Measuring protein evolution with a ratio of non-synonymous differences to synonymous differences dN/dS: indicative of a small Neandertal population size

body: HL61: Lee Newberg - Global Measures of Uncertainty: Long Overdue in Computational Molecular Biology

comments.body: two papers: webb-robertson & lawrence; newberg ... lawrence
what is a good e-value?
E- and p-values are small when random data in unlikely to do well
E-values and p-values tell you about random data but not whether there are other solutions.
but there still might be other solutions which equally good E or p values
need to define confidence / credibility limits
e-values and p-values are poor proxies to credibility
an example from RNA 2D prediction, MFE is not the best representative
today's goal: compute a global measure of representativeness of a point estimate
solution spaces are immense, but we often choose a particular point estimate... misleading e.g. if there's a bimodal solution
Goal: Compute global mesaure of representativeness of a point estimate
Related publications: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed...; http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed...
Many problems are tackled by dynamic programming, HMMS, etc, collectively they are Hidden Boltzmann Models
compute / estimate credibility: look at distribution of differences from point estimate
SW alignment of nt sequences, score distribution can be modeled by exponential distribution. For a 3000x3000 alignment, the  Fourier approach is fast.
Will not explain all about Fourier Transform (in 15 minutes).
use the credibility limit, is a simple number, even a biologist can understand that
Author: http://www.rpi.edu/~newbel/

Able to measure decay and de novo synthesis
this methods tries to solve a long standing problem in transcriptomics, ]
i.e., bias for differential expression of short-lived RNAs
and thus in subsequent analysis
solution is to perform gene expression analysis of newly transcribed RNA
using 4-thiouridine
Kenzelmann et al PNAS 2007 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed...
after tagging,normal analysis techniques for microarray or RNA-seq can be sused
bur of course new methods could exploit features specific for the tagging of newly transcribed RNA
directly observe changes in de novo transscription
observe changes relative to basal transcription
no bias for short-lived trnascripts
It can offer evidence of the stability of RNA (decay)
(room pretty full)
New methods for normalization are necessary when comparing total RNA to newly transcribed RNA
after normalization the RNA half-life can be calculated using and exponential decay model
the exp. technique with the new normalization increases the precision on the estimation of RNA half-life
Friedel et al, 2009 NAR; http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed...
Q: is 4-thiouridine toxic to the cell? A: No, at least in the time points looked at.

body: HL57: Erik Sonnhammer - FunCoup: global networks of functional coupling in eukaryotes

comments.body: How to reconstruct networks - experimental networks are incomplete.
Up to 300.000 interactions are proposed for human
only 35000 known
Each experimental method can give you more than 20% of the interactions.
experiments have high false negative and false positive rates
e.g., false positives from in vitro experiments: the interaction may never happen in a living cell
Interactions have to be combined and evaluated.
FunCoup
there are many kinds of evidence for functional coupling
Lots of evidence for functional coupling, not only from PPI but als from localization, gene expresson, interacting domain, TFBS; miRNAs.
domain interactions
See also http://ff.im/4xrCV
Integrate different kind of data from various organisms.
Some links are continous, some binary, etc.
using Naive bayesian training
full Bayesian training would be too computationally heavy
Naive Bayesian training, going from continuous data to distinct bins.
compare with positive and negative reference datasets
There is no negative reference data set out there, genes in different compartment might actually interact.
therefore use random examples as negative set
calculate enrichment as likelihood ratio=P(+)/P(-)
Learn log likelihoiod ratios  for each evidence, requires large negative set.
sum all the log-likelihood ratios to get full bayesian score
4 different flavors of training sets: metabolic pathway, signaling pathway, physical ppi, and complexes from UniProt
Training sets are from KEGG (metabolic and signaling), HPRD and Complexes from Uniprot.
using the curated data only for training/validation, not as input to the networks
No curated data used in the network, only in training.
7 model organisms and human are combined with 50 individual data sets.
Convert log scores to confidence scores.
predict coupling between 2 genes, for each model FC-PI, FC-CM, FC-ML, FC-SL model
convert into confidence scores, which may be different in different models
convert the Bayesian score using the probabilitly of functional coupling, which is unknown but they just set to 1/1000 ad hoc
algorithmic innovations- we have to develop new evidence scores
Used input from PPI as continuous data, using experimental counts.
discretization caused problems
they figured out how to discretize
test significance with chi-squared test
integrate evidence from orthologs used by InParanoid
using inparanoid orthologs
Used transfer of ortholougs information under the same Bayesian framework
new phylogenetic patterns using orthologs
http://inparanoid.sbc.su.se/
Except for yeast, most species had more information transferred rather than generated for the organism.
most support coming other species, other wise we may miss
many links would not have been found without evidence from other species
only yeast is well supported all by itself
validated networks, TCGARN science 2008
Validation using cancer pathways, recovering 29 of 36 links, found an additional 25. Not entirely independent.
Independent validation from recovering tumour mutation sets.
applications - 1 . exploring local networks, 2. analyzing network conservation
Easy exploration of the data sources leading to an edge in the network.
graph visualization: started with Medusa, but it didn't fulfill needs
now developed JSquid (sp?), published last year
used jSquid .. Bioinformatics 2008
New view of the human disease network, build tree of disease interactions.
conclusions
to discover novel functional coupling between genes
Cancers group together, neurological diseases do not.
can expand gene sets such as pathways
http://FunCoup.sbc.su.se

body: TT47: Chris Rawlings - Semantic Data Integration for Systems Biology Research

comments.body: Also speaking: Catherine Canevet and Paul Fisher
Two systems to integrate data.
BBSRC-funded research collaboration in Newcastle, Manchester, and Rothamsted : ONDEX and Taverna
Demo on the integration and validation of yeast metabolome models.
ONDEX: http://www.ondex.org/, taverna: http://taverna.sourceforge.net/
Taverna is a workflow workbench to integrate tools (including web services).
Taverna can link ONDEX and external (ex. PubMed) data sources via the web-service interface.
When ONDEX works with Taverna, instead of using the pipeline manager you use the ONDEX web services and access ONDEX from Taverna. This means you can use Taverna to pull in data into ONDEX.
Outline of the demo: starting from Janboree Network SMBL, parse it into Ondex, remove currency metabolites and annotate using network analusis results.
Then switch to Taverna. Identify orphans, retrive related enzymes, assemble a PubMed query and link results to the graph.
the workflow for relevant pubmed entry retrieval seems staggeringly complex - but I guess this is because each input appears as a node in the workflow (is that correct ?)
# ondex vs cytoscape?
@Andrew - not sure - ondex uses Jung as the underlying layout engine (and Alan Kuchinsky of Cytoscape is asking a question!)
Question: how does the system scales for large amount of data?
@Jim, but they are similar use cases covered btw the two systems?
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...
@I think there are but the response to that question seemed to suggest that ondex was aimed at denovo network generation rather than massive visualization (this needs to be clarified)
@Jim, thanks...

body: HL56: Kevin Cohen - Nominalization and alternations in the language of molecular biology: Implications for text mining

comments.body: nominalizations are dominant in biomedical texts, e.g. "expression" is much more used than "express"
Cohen et al, 2008 [not a very useful reference]: nominalizations are more difficult to handle than verbs, but can yield higher precision
http://www.plosone.org/article...
alternation: variations like active/passive. much less characterized for nouns than for verbs
e.g. pre-nominal arguments: agent: "phenobarbital treatment" or patient: "cancer treatment"
previous work has tried to handle nominalizations, e.g. Ono et al (2001): interactions, association, complex and binding
genescene: http://doi.ieeecomputersociety.org/10... [?}
use in-house tool to do annotation of nominalizations
alternations are very diverse, contrary to previous prediction that there would only be a limited number of alternations in scientific literature (sub-language model)

body: HL54: Mona Singh - Search and discovery of recurring patterns with interactomes

comments.body: Hairballs.
Different large scale data sets, genetic, phosphorylation etc. exist but how to interpret?
Add protein annotatons, sequence, structure, motifs, domains, functional characterization.
Particular interested in interaction domains, analyzing cellular organization and interactomes. Can we discover and analyze recurring patterns.
Analogy to multiple alignment of protein sequences with PROSITE pattern
For networks schemas, nodes are description of proteins, e.g. domains. An extension of network by attributes, e.g. PFAM or PROSITE.
Examples for network schema are homologous pathways.
Netgrep has visual interface.
No details of the algorithm, tricky problem but can solve it fast.
Triangles, quad topology (linear combination of four), Y star topology of four.
Automatically discovery of overrepresented schemas with direct interactions and sequence motifs. Using Y2H with filtering to address quality of the data set.
Counting occurrences of labelled subgraphs, brute force approach using Netgrep.
score each possible schema
count how frequently it occurs, but different annotations have different frequencies
need to account for overrepresentation
Some annotations are more frequent than other, score has to incorporate both the frequency.
Randomized network
take each network, randomize it, count how often the annotation occurs in the randomized network and compute the overrepresentation term
Estimate false discovery rate, look at features with FDR < 0.05
count how often the score occurs in the random graph, to estimate the false discovery rate
when making the random graph with the pair schemas, preserve degree
for triplet schemas, also preserve annotation
For 3-vertex schemas, need to presever pairwise annotation acounts.
for higher order schemas, also preserve triplets
used Stub Wiring from Uri Alon's group for randomizing the pairwise schema
no known algorithm for randomizing uniformly, need to approximate
151 pairwise schema [...]
do the proteins making up these schemas share biological processes?
Hypergeometric evaluation of schemas.
check enrichment versus background
Graph of the pairwise schema network.
For triplets, nodes are themselves pairwise schemas.
Hubs in the graph are ras, kinas and [...]
cross-interactomics: repeated the process in human
Example of the DUP family in yeast, and pair comparison between human and yeast.
Human-specific schemas, some consist of domains that also exist in yeast.
Q. Robustness of the resulting networks. A. Removed 5%, found the network to be stable. Different results in different organisms.
Q. Use of subgraph sampling? A. Can use any topology for searches.
# Not sure I understand the question and answer but they do.
Q. (Ruchira) Human-yeast network did you check orthology? A. Used PFAM annotation, did not worry about orthology. Some motifs in human are from the expansion.

body: HL53: Chris Taylor - Promoting coherent minimum reporting guidelines for biological and biomedical investigations: the MIBBI project

comments.body: Standards are hugely dependent on their respective communities
Much of biological experiments can fall under an ISA (Investigation-Study-Assay) structure.
You should then use three types of standards: syntax (FuGE, ISA-TAB etc), semantics, and scope. MIBBI is all about scope.
Why do we care about standards? Data exchange, comprehensibility, and scope for reuse.
"Metaprojects": FuGE, OBI, ISA-TAB - draw together many different domains and present in structure/semantics useful across all.

When the independent MI projects overlap, arbitrary decisions on wording and substructuring make integration difficult. This makes it hard to take parts of different guidelines - not very modular. This is what MIBBI helps with.
MIBBI promotes gradual integration of checklists.

Nature Biotechnology 26, 889 - 896 (2008)
doi:10.1038/nbt0808-889
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...

body: HL52: Georg Zeller - Characterizing transcriptome plasticity using whole-genome tiling arrays and machine learning

comments.body: Motivation: find all genes in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana.
profile transcriptome changes under stress
tiling arrays: cost-effective, but noisy
normalization pipeline: background correction to reduce imaging artifacts
quantile normalization: comparison between arrays
Normalization: background correction, quantile normalization between arrays, transcript normalization (to remove probe sequence bias)
transcript normalization: probe sequence bias reduced
Not all exon probes show the same level.
assume that ideal transcripts have constant level of expression, try to predict deviation between actual and ideal signal intensities
Sequence-based quantile normalization: exon and intron sequences are normalized to 2 distinct levels
Website: http://www.fml.mpg.de/raetsch...
transcript normalization improves normalization between background and exon signals
developed own segmentation algorithm, http://www.fml.tuebingen.mpg.de/raetsch...
Goal: characterize tiling arrays probes into exonic, intronic and intergenic.
mSTAD: a hidden Markov-SVM
mSTAD approach: Zeller et al., Pac Symp Biocomp 2008
mSTAD approach: a state is associated to each probe given its level and its context.
mSTAD vs Affymetrix TAS
URL: http://www.weigelworld.org/resourc...
can also find new transcripts that are not covered by ESTs/cDNAs so far
can validate 37 out of 47 tested cases
Examples of differential expression: stresses induce the transcriptions of extra regions.
mSTAD can identify previously unannotated exons
find new stress-induced TARs
could be: stress-induced alternative transcripts, overlapping transcripts, or new stress-induced genes
Validation via RT-PCR.
Zeller et al, Plant J, 2009
predict new genes if distance >500 nt to the nearest annotated gene
last part of the talk: analysis of dicer mutant (DCL1). DCL1 is unvolved in processing miRNA precursor genes into functional miRNA
in dcl1 knock-out mutatants, substrate transcripts of DCL1 accumulate
findings: many intergenic TARs are targets of DCL1
dcl1 is also involved in the silencing of transposons.
DCL1 is involved in transposon silencing: find strong expression of transposons in dcl1 mutant
outlook: include sequence effects (e.g. GC bias, seen in RNA seq) into transcript normalization

body: HL51: Jüri Reimand - GraphWeb: functional analysis of genomic networks

comments.body: A tool for large, genome scale networks is applied to yeast data.
The modular nature of molecular cell biology can be seen in today's large networks. A broad overview over the different, complex networks.
Many biological entities can be seen as networks, e.g. proteins and genes, measured by DNA binding, physical and genetic interactions, which can be combined into heterogenous networks.
Edges are not born equal, we need edge-weights, easy in gene expression networks. SAGA and SWI/SNF example. Assign local weights to rank edges in the network
Data set are not born equal. Small scale data set are more reliable than global approaches.
# Not sure I agree fully here, but he is merely motivating the weights approach.
Some data set are trusted more than others.
Different scores for global and local weights can be combined.
Hairball.
Everything is interconnected, no way to interpret. Needs to be dissected.
Cliques, hubs, set of neighbors can be used to find the modules. Graph clustering are unsupervised approaches, using MCL or between centrality clustering.
Functional enrichment can be studied using miRNAs, KEGG, Reactome, GO, TFBS.
The statistical perspective can be computed by hypergeometric tests, could be normalized with the number of proteins in the module.
Graph partitioning to detect dense regions, than enrichment, only highlight those with high scores.
Analyze public data set from yeast, breaking down into hub based modules.
Ah, the proteasome.
Interacting with YHB1, probably makes sense to a yeast biologist.
Available online at http://biit.cs.ut.ee/graphweb/
Export to cytoscape for visualizaition.
An Estonia endeavor (Postdoc positions open)

body: Keynote: Mathias Uhlen - A global view on protein expression based on the Human Protein Atlas

comments.body: Introduction: Works a lot on affinity reagents. Invented and developed pyrosequencing technology (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki...) now used in 454
Out line of the talk - 1. systematic biology -introduction, 2. HPR project 3. The Human protein Atlas

18th century - biologist. 19th - chemist (1/3 of elements discovered in Sweden in this century). 20th - physicists and at the end, computer scientist. He'd now like to say that the 21st century is the century of medicine.
HPR one of the largest projects in Sweden wrt funding, about 100 million euro so far
An impressive log-scale plot of number of bases sequenced since 1965.
developer of sequencing by synthesis via pyrosequencing in late 90s -- basis of 454 technology
Personalized genomics ... 454 technology developed in our lab
Bioinformatics is the key in the new era of genomics.
95% of drugs (still) aimed at proteins
(Personal opinion: I like how it's not the "post-genomic era", but a new era of genomics :) )
95% of drugs today target proteins. Thus, studying proteins is studying for the future
Systems biology /omics is going to be fantastic in the next 10 years.
(That, or we find better ways of interfering with RNA)
Image of contradictory sign in Paris: you know where you want to go, but not how to get there.
We know where we want to go (characterize all proteins), but not sure how to get there (due to a lack of high-throughput methods)
The generation game - Nature july 7, 2007
antibodies are the core tool for probing proteins
but they are too cross-reactive
Human antibody initiative HAI
human anitobdy initiative (HAI) -- uhlen, M. Synyder, P. Hudson -- generate comprehensive and validated antibody collection
validation of commercially available antibodies
average success rate of commercial antibodies is 49%
some companies 100% antibodies works fine, some companies 0%, in general 50% works fine
http://www.antibodypedia.org/
Antibodypedia -- a portal for validated anitbodies (we need to add a link from Gene Wiki...)

From the website: "The antibodypedia is a community-based portal showing application-specific validation of publicly available antibodies to human protein targets. Each protein binder (antibody or other affinity reagent) has been scored in an application-specific manner into three main categories (supportive, uncertain and non-supportive)"
@Oliver - nice!
If you have 2 antibodies, you can compare results in various assay platforms so he wants to develop paired antibodies for every protein target.
Nat Methods 2008: High-througput method to identify epitopes
6 months ago published a paper Nature methods (december 2008)
(bummer, antibodypedia doesn't use mediawiki so can't assess current usage...)
(I am entirely too short-sighted to read the author lists half of the time. Sigh)
HPR - The human proteome resource
http://www.proteinatlas.org/
(grumble grumble, antibodypedia creates YAI -- yet another identifier)
(++ HPA -- uses ensembl gene IDs...)
hpr is a multi-disciplinary program
(Proteinatlas seems to be using ENSG/ENSP/UniProt)
The gene factory does about 200 clones per week, and is in full production.
(HPA ids- mapped to uniprot also)
Close to 34.000 clones in the database
(@Andrew - indeed)
200 clones per week, 33,925 clones total (all human?)
Open source (but in-house?) LIMS developed
(would be interesting to compare to origene collection of mammlian clones)
The antigen design uses PRESTIGE, which is a bioinformatics approach to select antigens using the protein epitope signature tag (PrEST).
antigen design -- used PRESTIGE a bioinformatics approach to select antigen for antibody
read of this project is protein expression profiling
readouts -- immunohistochemistry (IHC) and IF (immunofluorescence)
Organ, tissue, cellular and sub-cellular expression profiing on a protein basis
apply antibodies to tissue arrays (cancer focus, I think)
(140+ human samples, around 200 tissues.. did someone catch the numbers?)
(Faq from the website: spatial distribution of proteins in 48 different normal tissues and 20 different cancer types as well as 47 different human cell line)
annotation of images taking place in Mumbai in India
image annotation -- difficult problem.  automated anaylsis would be good, but now using indian pathologists for manual annotation
$60 /  500 images for annotation?
Confocal microscopy for subcellular localization, difficult to scale up to high-throughput
high-throughput subcellular localization in A0431 (squamous cell carcinoma), U-251MG (glioma), ???
(I think Bob Murphy talked on a similar project to map subcellular localization of proteins en masse...) (Oh, looks like it's a collaboration between the two...)
They have a SVM that seems to be able to annotate 28 different parts of the cell.
2TB data each week (courtesy of 50.000 images in the same time)
2/3 of data come from in house data and 1/3 comes from different companies
(I wonder how the protein expression compares with our gene expression atlas http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed...)
About 33% of the sample space done (6850 genes)
progress - started in 2005 , last week released version 5.         8,832 antibodies, covering 1/3 genes in uniprot
(And I suppose there's always more to do.. check for splice variants, truncated versions...)
Most recent release: 7 mln images.
(@Andrew: if there is overlap in the cell lines that could be an easy correlation analysis)
The next 5 yrs are also about getting the paired antibodies mentioned earlier.
all antibodies available to the public
(good good, HPA is already BioGPS plugin.. http://biogps.gnf.org/#goto=p... </shameless_plug>)
Rodent brain atlas at http://hprdemo.genpat.uu.se/rodentb...
central questions in proteomics
(Rodent atlas seems a bit redundant to Allen Brain Atlas? -- Oh, ABA is via in situ / RNA, this is protein.  Again, would be interesting to compare...)
how many proteins are expressed in a given cell?
how many protein are tissue specific?
@Oliver, probably not directly comparable by exact cell lines, but might be worth comparing by parental tissue.  Need to wait until they allow downloading of data though...

Ensembl "thinks" that the genes are up to 23,000, but UniProt "thinks" 20,000, but the number is probably with that (for genes coding for proteins). ("thinks" in scare quotes, as databases don't think - yet)
the size of human membrane proteome .. 5,514 human membrane proteins; covering 26% of protein-encoded genes
proteins expressed in normal cells - 6,800 antibodies towards (>25% of all protein encoding genes). 65 normal cell types (from 45 different tissue types)
70% of proteins expressed in a given cell, approx even distribution across # of cell lines (not what we observed on gene expression data, which had distinct peaks at tissue-specfiic and ubiquitous)
80% of proteins expressed on average in cell lines (surprisingly high to me...)
(@Andrew: protein selection might be biased towards the ones that are well expressed / had known anitbodies / ...)
9% of proteins cell type specific, 62% expressed across 3 different cell types
ubiquitous expression, but differing levels
(interesting cytoscape visualizations of cell type / tissue specificity)
In the Atlas: < 2% specific to a single cell type (84 proteins), well known ones like insulin
Includes a number of uncharacterized proteins with no known function
EU project http://www.prospects-fp7.eu/
PROSPECTS: PROteomics SPECification in Time and Space

"Complementary technologies, including mass spectrometry, cryoelectron microscopy and cell imaging will be applied in innovative ways to capture transient protein complexes and the spatial and temporal dimensions of entire proteomes."
MCF-7 data with IHC, Mass spec
next generation seq of cDNAs from U2-OS human cell line 76% detected by mRNA seq
76% genes detected by next gen mRNA sequencing in U2-OS
again -- mostly ubiquitous expression (now on mRNA level), but differing levels
high fractions of all proteins expressed in human cells, tissues and organs
Lack of specificity not good knows for those looking for good antibody targets for therapeutic purposes
the quantity of proteins, rather than their presence /absence, is the key to cell identity
few cell-specific proteins (<1%) and group-specific proteins (<10%)
find biomarkers for early detection of disease ... it is very good for human mankind
(Proteome 2008) Suspension bead arrays
mg/ml to pg/ml range (dynamic range of protein concentration in blood 10^12 )
working on kidney disease in collaboration with astrazanica .... for detection of biomarkers
Developing 'next generation' plasma profiling, scale to one million assays / months
(has he mentioned availability of these antibodies?  Commercially available?  antibody-producing lines?)
They're part of ENGAGE.
commercially available @Andrew
first draft of the human proteome by 2014
Aim to have the draft version of the human proteome by... see above
(@Andrew I think via Prestige Antibodies (I remember the cute advertising slide). Does that mean advertising works?)
Nature, "The big ome" - 24 April 2008, editorial
tissue-specificity is achieved by precise regulation of protein levels in space and time
Prestige Antibodies through Sigma: http://www.sigmaaldrich.com/life-sc...
science 26 sep 2008, vol 321 pages 1758-1761
"Proteomics Ponders Prime Time", Science, 26 September 2008, in response to the Nature article
new lab in Stockholm coming soon, Science for Life Laboratory
Blog post: http://themindwobbles.wordpress.com/2009...
New Science for Life laboratory being established, see http://www.newsdesk.se/pressro...
Q: importance of splice isoforms -- A: complexity that is currently not considered due to technical complexity (to be saved for second phase)

Q: conclusions on tissue specificity have bias based on antibody availability?  A: bias of commercial antibodies possible, but only 1/3 of data.  Data they are generating based on walking down chromosomes (I think?), so don't expect bias...  Also, some of ubiquitous expression is due to cross-reactivity.  (first mention of this...)

Q: perspective for gene therapy or antisense therapy, more generally non-protein based therapies.  A: pharma shifting from small molecules to biologics (not sure about a "shift" rather than "expansion").  Gene therapy problem is getting into all relevant cells.  Ubiquitous expression of proteins the root cause of side effects for protein-based targets, possibly...
(only to get the blog on top of the ISCB portal site; the figures messed up our layout)

body: ISMB/ECCB Stockholm 2009: Bioinformatics Core Facilities Workshop, Fran Lewitter

comments.body: Project priorities: just long term misses new customers, grant opportunities. Focus on money or project size misses pilot projects, does not allow diversification. Suggestion: based on merit, what allows the core to grow in new directions, expand, supports the institutional community in general
Hiring: 50% FTE available for a new person, enough to get someone started. Identify new technologies, hire to get an early start. Consultants can fill gaps.
Time: maintain an overview of timeframes (putative project starts). Wrap up projects to avoid task switching overhead as much as possible. Make time for the planning stages.
Expectations: be open and transparent with regards to availability, feasibility, stick to realistic time estimates and turn down work if the resources are not available. Collaborate between Cores
Cancer UK, Cambridge Core. Prioritize short tasks, genomic tasks. Use queuing system, use steering committee to guide on participation in long term researcher-based projects
usually 6-10 projects per person at any given time (ouch...)
Manage workload: define scope early, manage using collaboration software, deliver data in stages
automate and standardize
Training / empowering researchers the most important aspect
Report regularly to all groups / departments, communicate
Request co-authorship (but do not seem to require it)
Start of discussion
Current developments and changes: focus on next-gen
Benefits of training
Chargeback model. half of participants fully supported by their institutes
Hourly charges between 70 and 120$
Authorship: mostly just acknowledgement, many cores with focus on master's level students
Collaboration: central place to share knowledge of methods, tools, evaluation. One place to deposit this information could be the http://www.bioinfo-core.org/index...
Try to find ways to pool information and resources (similar to the BOSC OpenBio projects)
Switch of topics on how to handle next-gen seq influx

What kind of questions are being asked, can they handle the data themselves, and is there any way to build re-useable workflows? Experience seems to be that so far no question (beyond the assembly step) has come up twice.
Develop method agnostic tools that help the biologist to get a handle on their own data, Eg http://www.bioinformatics.bbsrc.ac.uk/project...
Lots more notes over at http://www.fiamh.info/article...

body: Special Session 6: Regulatory Genome Architecture and Noncoding Mutations in Human Disease

comments.body: Talk: Veronica van Heyningen, "Lessons from regulatory mutations in developmental anomalies"
Highly conserved non-coding DNA seqs emerge as regulator elements - bind multiple TFs
Genes with complex expression patterns require complex control
Disease-associated chromosomal breaks outside gene highlight distant regulatory elements, often within neighboring genes
Different mechanisms of disruption:
key elements separated from transcriptional unit - total loss of function
altered chromatin organisation (originally position effect variegation)
Pax6, Spx2, Otx2 - genes with important role in eye development that are also important in the brain; continue to be expresed in the adult organism as well
Explore Pax6 long-range control elements - up to 180 kb away from the gene

use distant elements in reporter transgenic analysis to look at expression patterns they drive - different elements drive expression in different tissues at different times. however, find large overlap, so there's no easy rule according to which distant regulatory elements work together to establish the expression pattern
some distant elements are within a neighboring housekeeping gene
study deletions in various regions by using a reporter construct, compare with isolated enhancer function
find an element in Pax6 intron that drives expression in the (zebrafish) heart - unexpectedly
also find a Pax6-response element: autoregulation - Manuel et al, Development, 2007
a mutation in a Pax6 reg element located in the intron of the neighboring gene has been associated with (a mild form of) epilepsy
some enhancers work only at later developmental stages (eg, E17.5)
need methods for phenotype prediction based on regulatory mutations - eg, enhancer-driven knockouts
in zerbafish, there are pax6 forms - pax6 a (expressed in the barin), pax6b (expressed in the pancreas), both are expressed in the eye
the regulatory elements for the brain were lost from pax6b, pax6a has lost its neighboring gene (ie, the reg elements located within it),  pax6b retained some a part of it
Move to Sox9

haploinsufficiency causes campomelic dysplasia and sex reversal - the breakpoints can be very far away, the severity of phenotype decreases with the breakpoint position being further away - however mutations causing Pierre Robin syndrome may localise to a very specific long distance element ~1.1 Mb away from the gene, small deletions at 1.4 Mb upstream _AND_ 1.4 Mb downstream. How these elements work together is yet to be determined.

Another example: Van der Woude severe phenotype caused by intragenic mutations in IRF6; a regulatory variant of IRF6 (a SNP upstream of the gene, disrupting an AP2alpha binding site) predisposes to sporadic CLP (cleft lip and palate)
Discuss developmental abnormalities caused by mutations in SHH (sonic hedgehog)
a related phenotype is produced by an insertion in the intron of a neighboring gene - LMBR1
Pax6 and Sox2 interact to cross and autoregulate, mutations in the "double" binding sites (ie for both) at different cells result in mutant phenotypes. Note that TF dosage is important.
Next talk: James P. Noonan, The Role of Developmental cis-Regulatory Change in Human Evolution
what makes us human? unique abilities <- developmental changes (brain, limbs etc). What's the molecular basis of these traits?
changes in gene regulation vs changes in genes themselves. perhaps there's a lot of the former (in the evolution of primates)
two approaches: 1) in vivo chacaterization of cis-regulatory modules with human-specific developmental functions, 2) whole-transcriptome comparative analysis
start with (1). how to identify developmentally active CRMs in the human genome?
the more conserved an element is the more likely it'll function as an enhancer
also look at chromatin signatures - for example, p300 binding sites are 90% predictive of enhancers (Visel et al, Nature 2009)
look for noncoding elements that are conserved across species but rapidly evolve in humans - human-accelerated conserved noncoding sequences (HACNSs), Prabhakar et al, Science 2006.

Developed stats models to measure evolutionary rates, estimate probability of human-specific substitution, calculate likelihood of observed pattern of substitutions in each noncoding element - estimate acceleration p-value. Identified 992 HACNSs out of ~10000 conserved elements

associate with neighboring genes -> GO analysis. only 1/734 functional categories showed significant association: cell adhesion! More detailed look - neuronal cell adhesion, axon guidance, synapse formation

Do HACNSs function as reg elements in vivo? Transgenic assays in mouse (select elements based on overall constraint and human-specific acceleration). Many elements show specific developmental patterns of expression in these assays

Focus on HACNS1 - associated with gbx2, highly conserved in all terrestrial vertebrates, evolving 4x faster than neutral rate in human, sequence changes are fixed. The sequence change is association with a gain of function: human-specific anterior limb expression.
this gain of function has been achieved by 13 substitutions in the sequence compared to chimp (proved by "humanizing" the chimp region and "chimping" the human region by making these substitutions)
drives expression in the anterior-most digit at e13.5 - may contribute to the development of longer thumbs in the human compared to chimp/orangutan?

HACNSs: selection or biased gene conversion? Biased gene conversion - postulated to increase the fixation rate of AT to GC substitutions. Mutagenic effect of recombination hotspots + preference in recombination-associated DNA repair toward GC vs AT pairs.
Synergy between positive selection and BGC in HACNS1?
HACNSs are not biased towards high-recombining regions. The human-specific substitution rate is not elevated outside of HANS1 - but GC rate is.
Move from genotype to phenotype: comparative gene expression profiling in developing cortex.

Mouse vs human fetal forebrain, look at gene expression profiles of several cortical stem cells by RNAseq. Purify cell populations by laser capture microdissection. (collaboration with Rakic/Ayoub @ Yale). Recover 50 ng of total RNA from ~10,000 cells, which is more than enough for RNAseq. Comparison of different cell populations in the developing mouse cortex - very high correlation of expression. Differentially expressed genes "make sense".
Ultimately, want to associate differentially expressed genes with HACNSs
Next talk: Steve Montgomery, Population genomics of human gene expression using next-generation sequencing technology
looked at two different quantitative traits: exon reads and splicing pairs
~80% reads map to known exons. 40% reads span multiple exons (insert size: ~150bps)
data normalisation of RNAseq data is still a challenge. used a simple scaling approach
test data filter criterion: <10% of individuals equal to zero
see ~ 11,000 genes, corresponding to ~95,000 exons; ~23,000 exon pairs -> from 1 lane per individual.
there's a decent correlation between any two individuals (same sample same run: corr=0.93, diff sample, same run: corr=0.89, diff sample, diff run: corr=0.86)

Correlation of exon reads within genes (test for freq of alternative splicing) - corr is good, but not perfect for exons with high mean read count, so some information is escaped by array analyses that assume a fixed exon structure for each gene.
Adding a number of lanes / individuals increase the number of identified splice variants => many of alternatively spliced transcripts are rare
Detecting eQTLs with RNAseq data: assume an additive model of gene expression, for each SNP look at the number of reads, use spearman rank correlation to assess the association
detected 2431 genes (4219) exons associated with SNPs at p~0.01
eQTLs detected with exon counts centred around TSSs
consider using RNAseq to detect SNP association with known splice variants - took 1767 known splice variants from Ensembl, tested for association against splicing pair counts, data look promising

Q: what cells used? A: EBV-transformed lymphoblastoid cells. Q: is this a bit of a constraint to look only at these cells? A: looked at eQTLs in other lymphoblastoid cell lines collected long time ago, see a lot of correlation. Did not look at other tissues.
Q: did they look at 20% unannotated exons? A: No, can't do much until new gene models are built from them.
Q: where are the SNPs? Association with HCEs? Gene functional categories enriched for SNPs?
A: in 1Mb windows, see enrichment for eQTLs right around the TSSs rather than remote regulatory regions. Not a large number fall within known regulatory elements.
Next talk: Nadav Ahituv, Deconstructing gene regulatory elements

Geneticists are good at finding genes from sequence, can do much less with detecting regulatory elements - in the vast space of 98% of the genome that is non-coding. Also don't know the effect of nucleotide substitutions at regulatory elements.
What can we do about it? 1) use comparative genomics to find conserved non-coding regions. 2) high-throughput characterisation of enhancers

At Berkley, looked at extremely conserved non-coding sequences (n~3000, 70% similarity, >=100bp human-fugu) and ultracobserved (n~250, 100% similarity). Many of them turn out to drive expression in transgenic assays in the mouse. Now moved to UCSF, are setting up the same assays in zebrafish - easier to move it to high-throughput analysis
enhancer.lbl.gov: resource for experimentally validated human noncoding fragments with gene enhancer activity as assessed in transgenic mice.

These data can be used in a variety of ways. They aim to understand the regulatory code at enhancers. Look for limb-specific signatures, check whether they see them at limb-associated genes, check for new regions with these signatures in the human genome, test in zebrafish (expression in fin), if positive check in mouse (expression in limb)
look at ~480 ultraconserved elements (>50% non-coding, 100% identity and <=200b human-mouse-rat), depleted for SNPs
extreme sequence constraint = extreme functional constraint?
took four UCE: positive in enhancer assays, near genes when mutated lead to either a lethal or sexual development phenotype, variable in size
generated mouse knockouts for these UCSs - heterozygous KOs are fine, even homozygotes have no apparent phenotype!!!
so why is it?
maybe we just can't detect the phenotype?
maybe there's gene / reg module redundancy? It certainly exists - eg at UCEs upstream of ARX
maybe it's because mutations will cause gain-of-function (by binding of other TFs) rather than loss-of-function? in this case, deleting the whole thing altogether won't help identify this

support for this model: replaced a limb enhancer in mouse with a bat enhancer that has only 20bp difference -> observed limb elongation. Also bioinfomatic support showing that these seq's are prone to substitutions and indels (?)

Take four UCE that they KO'd, put an 83bp indel and introduced a 3bp change, both chosen more or less randomly. Very preliminary results on the 83bp insertion into two of the enhancers: made mice, after 10 generations of backcross, het:het mating recovers fewer heterozygous and homozygous mice than expected.

body: Thanks to everyone for all the live commentary! In return, I give you a Wordle cloud based on all the comments that were posted in this room :-)

comments.body: Surprised 'Allyson' is not one of the large keywords :)
I used only the comments themselves - not the names of the people who posted them
Maybe make a Wordle out of the contributors?
Did someone spot the 'Open' yet?
Cameron, contributors cloud done and posted :)
I see a homologous word in the two Wordles!  Latin data = Sanskrit datta, "given". :-)
@Oliver - to answer your question there are a number of "@" names in the wordle, if you look closely, but yeah, it's very nice of @Lars to do both wordles! I can see @allyson and @oliver for instance
Looks like we should ramp up our vocabulary of verbs - use, using and used are all prominent items by themselves.

I'm amazed by the difference between the Wordle based on abstracts (http://larsjuhljensen.tumblr.com/post...) and this one. The abstracts seem to focus on methods whereas the FriendFeed comments focus on data.
At least partially because it is much easier to quickly describes test data set than a complex method that might require notation or a schema, I think
